Which i would say that they succeeded in doing so, i enjoyed the fact that there was a lot of action, too many times people ruin the pace of movies by trying to balance out the action with love stories or some other garbage. Certain movies are not meant to be that way, and this is one of them, that is why i hate when people gauge it against other movies that are made with different intentions. And i am also a big Dracula fan and i realize that they fudged the Van Helsing legacy, but you couldn't have this movie with Anthony Hopkins running around fighting all of these creatures, even though he did an amazing job in bram stokers Dracula as the real VH, but this is a different movie, with a different story, and a very different purpose.....overall i enjoyed this film for what it was worth and i will be purchasing it when it comes out on Oct. 19

O.k., so it probably won't get an Oscar nomination, but it was good stuff.Kate Beckinsdale looks hot, so guys will enjoy it. Hugh Jackman looks great with long hair, so the ladies will enjoy it. Plenty of special effects, stunts and major a** kicking mean that guys will REALLY enjoy it (and the ladies probably won't mind too much). Probably not suitable for kids (can get a little graphic; watching a vampire get skewered, then decompose before your eyes could be a little disconcerting to a kid).Typical summer blockbuster: eye candy, special effects, stunts and a** kicking. Check your brain at the door; you'll enjoy it more.

Review title: You'll definitely enjoy it, 'cos it's fun.
Review_body: When it comes to SFX, the guys have been doing pretty good stuff with computers these days. But that has not been true with many horror movies like An American Werewolf in Paris or Underworld. This movie is on the good side and it rocks. You'll definitely enjoy the spectacular SFX along with chilly atmosphere, classic horror story and good casting (Mr.Jackman was a VERY good choice)... and a surprise ending too. Not a moment in the whole movie I remember being bored or something. For me it's already a classic.

Review title: A lot of money and a big hat
Review_body: This is simply the worst film I have ever seen. It is mind-rotting muck of the highest category, and is written and directed by a man who should at all costs be prevented from churning out any more of this dumb garbage (see also THE MUMMY, and that other polyp on the backside of film-making: THE MUMMY RETURNS).Hugh Jackman is a fine actor and given the right script and character he can be extremely watchable, ditto Kate Beckinsale, but both are wasted here, being given cruelly awful dialogue, and characters with all the depth and interest of an episode of SCOOBY DOO. Speaking of which I've read lots of reviews on-line by enthusiastic(presumably) 13 year olds who say how great the CGI effects in this film are. Cobblers. It just looks like a lot of money has been spent on creating a lot of very cartoon-like images designed to give the viewer sensory overload and prevent him/her from actually THINKING. Naturally this has much in common with video arcade games, and so those with a mental age of 12 or below are more likely to be impressed.The biggest offence that this film caused me is the fact that writer/director Stephen Sommers claimed to have been "inspired" by the classic Universal horror movies of the 1930's and '40's. Aaaaarrrghhh! This film has NOTHING but the names of the characters in common with masterpieces like BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN, WEREWOLF OF London etc. These films had atmosphere, great performances, characterization, a sense for romanticism and for the eeriness of the supernatural...all qualities that this excrescence of a film cries out to be blessed with. VAN HELSING has errr...a lot of money thrown at it and Hugh Jackman in a big hat.I cannot tell you how much I hated the performances - the guy who played Dracula was about as effective a replacement for Bela Lugosi as a pencil would have been. But worse...so much worse was the bloke who played the comic sidekick monk. His barely-disguised irritating Australasian accent didn't help matters, but he just came across as an unfunny moron one just ached to see impaled on one of those silly crossbow bolts that Jackman was firing hither and yon. What did they teach him at drama school?My abiding memory of watching this putrid rubbish,(and indeed the only happy one of the entire film-going experience)was the roar of laughter in the cinema when Kate Beckinsale's ludicrously accented gypsy got killed and Van Helsing in werewolf form let out an absurd howl of grief. It reminded me of Oscar Wilde's comment on the death of Little Nell in THE OLD CURIOSITY SHOP - to paraphrase: it is impossible not to be overcome with mirth.Terrible, just terrible.

+simple interesting plot
+captivating universe
+cool character design.+-average cinematography-Awful acting, awful accents
-awful CGIA breath of fresh air compared to movies today. Nowadays movies are only a means of pushing a political agenda. This is just a fun experience.

This was so bad, I had to walk out on this film 15 minutes into it. Absolutely appalling. I loved the old 1930's/40's horror flicks but this is just not them. If you watched Van Helsing and The Mummy back to back you'll see how unsuccessful Van Helsing was at re-capturing that familiar sense of engagement we had with the old classics. For those people saying "Oh, it's just a bit of fun, camp fun", I do not think that was Sommers intention and if it was fair play to him. But I will argue that those classics were not just 'camp', they were a lot more textful than that. They had weird, eccentric characters in them but the films were crafted to have your sub-consciousness take the story seriously, that's what made them great. You know what to expect from them, watching them is the closet feeling to that one you get when you sit round a camp fire out in the dark with friends and freak each other out with little spooky tales. Van Helsing fails at this. I am a fan of CGI, but only if it looks real. The CGI in this made me cringe, its part of the reason I walked out the cinema. CGI can look incredibly good, or it can look incredibly bad in movies. You look at the CGI in Van Helsing and cannot help but be disengaged with the film and think, that's not a vampire, its a silly looking computer animation. And there was lots of it too, even in just 15 minutes. This wasn't fun, it was poor. Whenever puppets, costumes or make-up was used in the old horror films, obviously it looks silly but it can be real enough to accept it as being real, for the sake of enjoying the film. As much as I tried, this did not and would happen in Van Helsing with the CGI monsters. I find with most CGI characters in films they just don't have the correct body movement physics or facial expressions to justify themselves as believable characters, its a very serious issue that is overlooked. For me, the CGI in Lord of the Rings was superb, I didn't feel myself being disgusted with it such as in Van Helsing or in the Starwars prequels. Please, save your money and do not buy or rent Van Helsing its just a poor movie which fails as a tribute to the old classics.

Review title: Buffy Van Helsing, The Vampire Slayer (2004)
Review_body: I usually refrain from writing negative reviews, but in this case, I think that I'll make an exception. If I can save one person from renting or buying this film for his or her collection then I've done a very good thing. Let me begin by saying that I admire Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale as actors, so the problem is really not them in this movie, but rather how the movie is presented. First of all, I have a problem with the hero's name. I was certain that Dracula's nemesis was named Dr. Abraham Van Helsing, however in this movie version, his name is Gabriel. Secondly, Gabriel proceeds to use what appears to be modern day gadgets that one would find in the arsenal of Buffy Summers, if one were to look. If the setting of this story is supposedly sometime in the 19th Century, then why does "Gabriel" have these modern day "Bat-toys?" Thirdly, the script, what is up with all of those silly one-liners? And again, the characters are speaking in the modern vernacular, and not the eloquent, dignified speech of a 19th Century European settlement. These glaring discrepancies are what ruined this film for me. The silly one-liner jokes, modern day speech, and Bruce Wayne/Buffy Summer Vampire fighting gadgets cheapened the entire enterprise for me, and as a result, the film lacked authenticity. I did not like this movie.

Review title: The look of a video game
Review_body: I was looking forward to seeing this movie. The thought of all the great monsters(together)and the ultimate good guy sounded like it would be good. I was wrong.The film was not only full of holes but had the flat no depth look of a video game through-out. I am tired of computed generated films. I want to see as much "real" as possible and not be short changed. All the unnatural moves and absolutely impossible things do nothing to make the hero look like a human.Whatever happened to cinematography? I'd like to see a return of realism to the movies. If I want to see a video game I'll fire up the X-Box.

Review title: Could have been a great movie, but...
Review_body: ... they packed too much and spend a lot of money in a movie that is not quite as good as it sounds.The CGI leaves a lot to wish for, specially after watching The Lord of the Rings. The movements are great if you are playing a video game, but this is a movie and the CGI creatures sometimes look too "robotic" and the action scenes are like playing Super Mario Bros. Is a pity that ILM animators didn't do a better job. I would like to know in which parts is Weta involved.The story sometimes packs too many ideas at the same time as to try to get the viewer confused or lost. A love action movies, but in this one, they overdid it.  Although the performances are very good, the film at sometimes feels over-saturated and in other tends to be a little bit boring.Loved the Dracula's girls dresses and their performances.In general, not a bad movie, but could have been much better.

Review title: (POSSIBLE SPOILERS)I wanted to get up and leave!
Review_body: POSSIBLE SPOILERS!!!Ok...This one ranks up there with UHF as the worst movie of all time. After about 20 minutes, I asked my Wife if we could leave and she replied "no". A definite regret for her in hindsight.No character development, no story, poor CGI, horrible screenplay and absolutely no feelings for Van Helsing himself or his Crusade.  Some background on Helsing and why he became so bent on wiping out Monsters other than a "life-debt" he owed to the Church would have been nice.I wanted him and his ANNOYING sidekick - Carl (played by David Wenham) to randomly take one of Helsing's bow-gun spears to the head very early on! With the 100's flying around as Helsing - being the ultimate Assassin he is - somehow avoids to hit his targets in what seems like a bad space chase with "lasers" gone awry!  I guess the Church is not good at creating weapons or Warriors!The movie ends as hopelessly as it started - with a bond so strongly cultivated throughout the movie with Monster Frankenstein - Van Helsing and cohorts show their love for BIG FRANK by placing him on a raft - 3 logs wide - and sending him out into the watery Abyss.  Nice!  Truly what a savior of humanity would do!I often wonder why I contemplate writing about a movie so wretched? Hopefully, in my altruistic nature it is to save you money, time and the disgrace of having to watch garbage.

Two hours of my life I desperately want back. Not even Kate Beckensale in a corset can make up for this films issues. This film tried to do too much and had too little to offer, aside from the afore mentioned corset. You have the wolfman angle, you have the vampire angle and you have the Frankenstein monster, why not add Creature from Black lagoon and some giant rats (Ben (1972)), so we can have some representation from all aspects of monsters. I was waiting at any time for an alien to walk out or for another monster to make a cameo. It had such potential if it had just steamlined and kept more along with what the original intent was when it was drafted following Brom Stroker's Dracula (1992). Don't go into with any expectations and you wont be disappointed.

Review title: Check your brain at the door and have fun.
Review_body: "Van Helsing" starts off with a sort of homage to the Universal monster films of the 1930s, with improved visual effects. You'll have to see it yourself to know what i mean. But it also sets the tone for an action film that rarely lets up. In a good way that is. Hugh Jackman might have a Harrison Ford-like future if he wants. Imagine a good looking guy, who can handle the big budget action films, but with more depth of character than Ford has ever brought.(Possible Spoiler)This Van Helsing, not to be confused with the better known Abraham, is a 007 for the late 19th century. Fighting larger than life villains (Mr. Hyde, The Wolfman, etc.) under the auspices of an organization (the Catholic Church) protecting the world from disaster. Only now he must fight his deadliest enemy, Dracula and his minions.Despite the length (over 2hrs 15min), the pace rarely falters to blandness. Credit this to director Stephen Sommers. Seems more confident in his creative choices then in The Mummy (the less said about the sequel, the better). Granted, Kate Beckinsale did nothing in this film that Rachel Weisz couldn't do as well, so maybe a little money could have been saved. And like The Mummy, Sommers needs a comic sidekick. In this case, David Wenham as the cowardly friar making weapons like Q to help out Van Helsing. Wenham and Jackman's interplay goes well, as they rise above their dialogue. No such luck between Jackman and Beckinsale.But this isn't an actor's or a writer's piece; this is an ILM piece, and boy do they come through. The effects are a standout, with the best computer-generated morphing/transformation sequences i've seen in quite a while. Thumbs up for the sound effects and editing crews as well. The formula seems familiar after you leave the theater. But while you're watching, you don't care. You're just enjoying the ride. Like i said in the summary, check your brain at the door and have fun. 7 out of 10.

Review title: No plot, bad acting, even worse dialogue
Review_body: I was disappointed in the movie. It has such great potential but fell very short of that. The dialogue was so bad that at certain points it was too cheesy to sit through. There was little to no logical connection between the characters. The brides of Dracula were so under developed that it would have been more effective to not have them speak. The claim was that this movie would be like Indiana Jones, but the only similarity was the hat Jackman wore. Beckinsale relied way to much on her looks and didn't bother to bring any real acting to the movie, which is a shame because I enjoyed her in Underworld. Other then that it was a bad attempt at what could have been a good movie. I wish I could go back and retrieve the two hours of my life that were wasted in that theater.

I was highly expected this first 2004 summer movie. Available in Thailand 5th May. No story, low quality screenplay but excellent CGI. Non-stop action had no fun coz it lacked story. I give it 6/10. Think THE MUMMY RETURNS was bad, this one is worse. And please, Mr. Sommers. No VAN HELSING RETURNS ! One time was enough, I didn't care about him at all.

Review title: Cold as a slab of marble
Review_body: A dreadful attempt to cash in and update the classic monster movie. The best part was the Wolfman's transfiguration although it was hard to see details. Plot and drama were weak and only a couple of real frights in the whole movie. Performances were ho hum although Samuel West was effective as the Baron but he is quickly dispatched. I longed for some suspense but it never happened. I recommend the originals on DVD now and also Hammer's updates with their beautiful cinematography and charismatic stars. I wish Hollywood would stop trying to improve on the classics and concentrate on script. No matter how much special effects you can load into a movie without a decent script and characters you care about the movie is bound to be a dud. D+

I loved the special effects in this film. And Hugh Jackman is the best cast for the role of Van Helsing. But the Americans have the bad habit to destroy the entire film with the too sentimental ends of their films! Why do they do that? It is too slushy and that irritates. The role of Dracula is a bit miscast. He does not play it very mysterious and he does not look dangerous in all scenes. Kate Beckinsale plays very good as well. She has not been the wallflower she was in "Pearl Harbor" and she looks well trained! Hollywood may give her more roles of this kind. She acts more mysterious than Dracula and his brides together!

Considering that it was such a low-budget film, I respect much of what they did and how they went about on doing it. Although, the accents given were nothing to be proud of. It seemed that they worked hard on many of the costumes. But it seems, also, that they went much too overboard on some of them, or hadn't thought of them enough. Some things that happened, or were said, seemed to be completely irrelevant with everything else, such as Kate Beckinsale's, or Anna's, weird obsession with the sea. Which was, by the way, completely and utterly RANDOM...I think. Some of the props did not seem well made, and looked like they had broken before, but either way, many of the sets, such as villages etc., worked out fine.

If you want to hate this film, it gives you plenty of ammo.  The pacing is abysmal, it's full of pointless sub-plots that don't go anywhere, including a horde of evil monsters whose sole purpose is to explode pointlessly (err, make that three hordes in fact), so many 'deus ex machina's it's surprising they didn't all fall over each other, dreadful dialog, and everyone's favourite annoyance: gratuitous use of CGI.So my advice would be: DON'T WATCH IT.  That is, unless you just want to sit back, switch off artistic judgement, suspend all belief, and just enjoy the show for what it is: a cheesy action flick with a few novel ideas.  See it with friends; laugh at how stupid it is; laugh at the cartoon laws of physics; laugh too at the witty one-liners, occasional comic timing, and joke references to other stories.It's a shame that with better script-writing and direction, this could have been an excellent film.  It certainly had some of the right ingredients.

Review title: People expect WAAAAY too much from this kind of movie.
Review_body: Van Helsing is a fun action/adventure flick which pays homage to the Universal horror films while still aiming to be an entirely different movie. At what it's trying to do, it largely succeeds; with good action scenes, likeable main characters, tons of classic film references, and a Dracula who is basically an over-the-top version of Bela Lugosi (though played with enough charisma to make it work).What it does not try to do is be a remake of any of these classic horrors, or to be anything other than an action movie. Therefore, to use these more serious titles as a yardstick for this film is absurd.The two biggest flaws are the CGI, which does look fake in places, and the acting, which includes some wooden moments from Jackman as well as a lot of overacting from everyone else. That being said, the over-the-top nature of the story helps stop these elements from feeling out of place.In my opinion, it's a film which has held up well, and which makes for a good watch around Halloween. Especially if you've already had your fill of slasher movies and are now in the mood for something light-hearted.

Review title: Why's everyone taking it so seriously?
Review_body: Sure it's camp and over the top, but it's all in good fun. Like, it's not a true story, and there's been a million and one variations on all these stories, so what's the big deal with adding a few little bits? Sommer's hasn't done a bad job combining them together. I'm Hugh-centric and a big vampire fan so I enjoyed it. There were enough twists in the plot to keep me going and a little surprised here and there. The humour's okay too. The David Wenham character is funny. The original Frankenstein's  monster had a compassionate nature and was intelligent; he just didn't get what he wanted, so in the book he killed folk- his creator had a choice in that, whereas here he is a pawn and aware that he doesn't have to be a bad guy.People watch worse television everyday and don't complain about it. Leave your disbelieving brain at the door and enjoy the ride...And, uh, don't take it so seriously!!

Review title: Van Helsing: Fun to watch with friends! Purists: run for the hills!
Review_body: First of all, I'd like to say that I do understand the people who really hate this movie. It's got A LOT of CGI in it and almost more action... and that makes it a great movie for some and trash for others. I myself have now seen it about 7 times, including a time with audio commentary and I just can't get enough of it.**The following might contain spoilers**So, the story is a little cliché. A man goes to some country to vanquish a great evil, while that great evil plans to take over the world. But this cliché formula can make a great movie when used in the right way. Sommers and his cast and crew managed to do so. The movie is beautiful, great special effects, wonderful locations and a funny and well-chosen cast. The jokes are good, the accents even better (accept for Kate's, she overacts in my opinion) and Richard Roxburgh is a marvelous Dracula.Let's take a look at the cast. First there is our monster hunter and all-round evil vanquisher Hugh Jackman. Too bad he left out his Aussie accent. He is a rather boastful hero, but the only steady thing in this story. You know his goal and he seems to know too, so just go for it!Then up pops David Wenham, with a real funny walk and talk. His hair's funny too and those ears... Poor Daisy... He's still great, despite his strange behavior. I think he should also join the Australian baseball team because he throws almost everything.They needed a bad-ass girl, so Underworld's leading lady Kate Beckinsale came over... No offense, I just don't like Kate Bacchanal...Who I did like is Richard Roxburgh. Richard does great, had a really cool accent and even seemed to BE Dracula! His international brides Elena, Silvia and Josie rock and look wonderful accompanying their dark master.Whatever anyone says, Shuler Hensley played an unforgettable Frankenstein's monster and Will Kemp is adorable as Velkan.Good cast, no wait, GREAT cast. Anyone who dislikes this movie should see the bloopers, the interviews and making offs. You really start to adore the actors and maybe, with a little good will, you could even start to like the movie too.I recommend this movie to any person who's open-minded enough to not flip out because there aren't any lengthy conversations and no deep character studies. It's also good to have a strong stomach. More importantly, this movie is best when watched with friends, because making fun of David Wenham's wrong ears and Dracula's pop star-like ponytail is a lovely thing to do on your average Friday night. There's only one thing that bothers me and that is the way the Wolf man looks. The ears aren't what they should be...One last thing: Do watch the movie with Richard Roxburh, Shuler Hensley and Will Kemp commenting on it. They have juicy stories about some scenes...

...yum. Unfortunately, I've just enumerated all the reasons for seeing this movie.I went into this movie hoping to see a decent action/horror flick, light on plot, and was surprised to find that the movie didn't live up to even those meager expectations. Van Helsing never seems to be in mortal danger at any point in the movie, which left me with a "Who cares?" attitude throughout. The arch-villain, Dracula, is something of a wimp, who spends most of his time letting his wives do his dirty-work while he sits around various castles and walks on the ceiling.Besides seeing the breathtaking Kate Beckinsale in a swashbuckling outfit, the only other bright spot to the film was the performance of David Wenham as Friar Carl. Wenham shows his acting abilities as he goes from the proud but troubled Faramir in Lord of the Rings to the stooped, studious, witty and faithful sidekick in Van Helsing.If you want an action/horror flick, in which you can drool over Kate Beckinsale, go see Underworld. If you want a loud action movie with gadgets, gizmos, supernatural powers, and great special effects, go watch or re-watch the X-Men movies. But if you want a ludicrous movie where you find yourself bored silly, laughing at the script, plot, and fight scenes, and checking your watch while you wonder how you could have been so stupid to have wasted $8, then catch Van Helsing in theaters today!

Review title: A tragic slaughter of an idea with immense potential
Review_body: This had the potential to be one of the best monster movies ever made. With the superlative Hugh Jackman on board as well as Kate Beckinsale - specifically and brilliantly proved in this genré in the vastly superior Underworld movies - matched to a good idea, a sound plot, and a healthy budget, Van Helsing should have been a shoe-in for the #1 slot for the best horror/action/adventure flick of our time. In particular, the creature designs were nothing short of spectacular. Van Helsing's werewolf is hands-down bar-none the best I have ever seen in a motion picture of any vintage or budget. The transformations, the vampiric and other monsters, and the motions thereof were also absolutely top-notch and were paired with smart cinematography to create an astounding visual treat.Sadly, all of this was sent spiraling into the ground courtesy of the most atrocious dialog I can ever recall seeing on the big screen. It's an odd feeling covering one's eyes, shaking one's head and blushing with embarrassment over a movie that you had absolutely nothing to do with creating ... perhaps it was because a group of friends was there with me at my enthusiastic urging. How awful it is has to be heard to be believed, as I lack the poetic talent to describe it adequately. Add to this two-dimensional characters, very weak character development, and inability of those characters to connect with the audience, and what we are left with is a total failure of writing.This movie proves that the script is key to a movie's performance. Even world-beating actors/actresses and world-beating special effects fall face-flat in the dirt when matched with weak characters and a script that sounded like it was written by a melodramatic tweeny-bopper girl just beginning her run of puberty.As an especially avid werewolf fan, I am angry to this day that the best werewolf ever to grace the silver screen was wasted in what was perhaps the most mortifying letdown in the genré's history. As much as I champion the Underworld series, I'll be the first to admit that the Lycan design for those movies (barring William at least), while not horrible, did fall somewhat short of expectations. However, good cinematography, excellent use of lighting, and above all else, STRONG CHARACTERS AND SOLID DIALOG more than compensate for this. Had Underworld had Van Helsing's werewolves ... wow ...So in conclusion, to all fans of this genré who have not yet seen this movie, two suggestions: One, either avoid this movie entirely, or Two, if you must watch it, do yourself a favor and hit 'Mute' immediately after hitting 'Play.'

Review title: One of the worst movies ever.
Review_body: This was absolutely below anything I can remember. Idea was great and it had huge possibilities, but yet, somehow director/writer managed totally mess this up. He didn't get anything out of the actors. I'm bound to think that Hugh Jackman really can't do any other role than Wolverines due to this movie, Kate Beckinsale didn't do any better than Hugh.Films editors most likely aren't doing the job they should be doing. Cuts were strange and abrupt. Dialog was awful and abrupt. Draculas actor? He should be doing something else than acting, or if he would act he would belong to role of doctor Gangreen in some Killer Tomatoes movie series.Only thing good in this movie when i saw it was my friends whom i was there with. And for the price of ticket we should've headed for a pint instead.(And I thought Operation Mars and Battlefield Earth sucked were the absolute bottom, I stand corrected.)

Some had a cool idea for a movie, but definitely pitched it to the wrong people. Oh wait, the guy that had the idea for the movie wrote the script. Which leads me to one conclusion: Sommers should have stopped writing movies after The Mummy Returns, at the latest. This movie had so much potential, but was wasted on terrible scripting, and way too much CGI. And not even good CGI. They should have just done the whole thing in CGI, a la Final Fantasy (even though I didn't much care for that movie, either). The only humor came from seeing David Wenham go from Faramir to a dorky, horny... friar? I forget what he was, even though he made the same joke about it twice. The second time was the funnier. The love interested between Jackman and Beckinsale was sophmoric at best. All in all, I thought it was lame. But hey, I work in a theater, and some kid saw it three times in a row, so to each his own, as they say.

Kicking off the summer movie season with a bang, Van Helsing is a wonderful reminder to why one should just go in to cinematic hibernation from May until September. The story makes no sense what so ever, the mythologies of all three monsters are horribly distorted, and Kate Beckinsale is 2 for 2 when it comes to Vampire/Werewolf movies that suck. I would have had a better rime if I had paid $6.00 to watch a middle finger on the screen for two hours. Either that or have Lon Cheney come back to life and kick me in the balls.

From the previews, I expected this to be a "serious" monster movie, about a man who is called on by God to fight the forces of evil.  But, it was clear that after the first 10-15 minutes, that the movie was absolute camp.
I was wrong though, but I wouldn't ask the filmmakers to classify this movie.  It's obvious that they didn't know what the movie was either, because at some points it's camp, trying-to-be-camp, kitschy monster movie, serious romantic drama and a few others.  It gets very annoying.And the only character I found to be likable, was Carl (David Wenham). He's the typical sidekick character whose job is to help the hero.  Oh, and he talks funny.All-in-all, I was disappointed.  *C-*

When i watch this movie i was really amazed that such a graphics can be produced in the world.I really enjoyed this movie a lot and i think everyone who like the fantasy movies like this movie as well.When i watched the scene of human being turned into a werewolf I was really amazed as it looks so real.Then there are scenes related to three beautiful brides(vampires with beauty)turning into vampires with wings,then there was brilliant scene related to Van Helsing himself, when he turned into a werewolf my god it was really a great special effect and then it was Richard Roxburgh's turn to turn into vampire.There was all fun in the movie.It has werewolf, vampires, Frankenstein, beautiful bride vampires, and all above the great actors like Hugh Jackman, Richard Roxburgh, Kate Beckinsale,Will Kemp and David Wenham .It is though guaranteed that no one can get bored while watching this movie.It is just a great fun with amazement.In short it is one of the best movie of all time for me. Van Helsing rocks.
Kate and Hew very good tandem, very nice and good Fairytale , I like it lot , and good acting for this ripe of movie !!!

I cannot understand why a movie production would put money in behind such a terrible storyline and terrible idea. I have seen films that pay homage to the great monsters of our time but this just rips that to pieces. Bram Stoker honestly will be rising to kill Steven Sommers in a fit to some how right the wrong that was this movie. I am sick to death of films being made purely to make money. This was in noway a good film. It was not slick, no sophistication that usually accompanies vampire movies. I could not take Dracula seriously, there was a comic relief monk. I strongly recommend avoiding this movie for the purposes of trying to put stop to Hollywood cheese. The ending was pitiful with Jackman looking into the clouds seeing Beckinsale's character uniting with her family, is this type of cheese really necessary, brutality is what was needed especially when dealing with the vampire of all vampires Dracula. Sommers has destroyed the story in every sense. There really is only one thing i can say had any substance in this movie and that was the special effects and they should not have been wasted on a film such as this. I seriously hope that the monster movies as a genre have not disappeared. I would love to see a more serious approach being taken towards them, maybe this is the movie that could change things, if movie directors are as disgusted with this as I am maybe it is possible, I'm looking for a solid monster movie from maybe someone like Peter Jackson to restore the genre to its former glory.

Let's face it... here on IMDb people only enter reviews for films they truly love or truly hate. I can't see many people logging in to write a review of a film they found mildly entertaining. Well there may be some but they probably should get out a bit more.In the case of Van Helsing I think I can honestly say that it's the film I love to hate. I feel it's so bad that it belongs up there with Batman & Robin as a possible contender for the worst film of all time.Where to begin....Almost the entire failure of this mess can be attributed to Stephen Sommer the director. When he directed the Mummy he was relatively unknown so the studio kept him on a tight leash and as a result we got a well balanced kind of Indianna Jones film with horror homages. It worked well and I thought it lots of fun.Then I saw what Stephen was capable of when you take the leash off in The Mummy Returns. Dear god what a mess. Plot goes out the window, tonnes of cheap, lazy and pointless CGI comes in and characterisation is completely ignored. Sommer had become the king of CGI for the sake of it...The film begins in black and white as an obvious homage to the classic horror films of Dracula and Frankenstein but it quickly becomes apparent that the huge CGI budget won't be used to any decent effect when you realise that the only alteration to the actual picture is that the colour has been removed. No CGI is used to give the black and white section a grainy or authentic look. You could get the same effect just turning down the colour on your TV.Then we meet Dracula. He's awful. A caricature of the classic horror villain rather than an actual depiction. There's no threat to him, at all. He looks like he's just turned up at your parents Halloween party in a slightly expensive outfit.Van Helsing himself is just Hugh Jackman playing Hugh Jackman in a Van Helsing costume.David Whenham's sidekick is rather embarrassing to watch as the Aussie actor does his best to take on a comic English accent and has a go at slapstick (which he fails at miserably by the way).Kate Beckensale is always easy on the eyes but aside from being a woman with a need for vengeance there's very little for her to do.After a slightly odd battle between our hero's and a bunch of flying chicks in the local village things descend into the incomprehensible.The story jerks along between one CGI set piece and the next and takes so many ridiculous turns that you give up trying to follow it after a while. Instead you sit back and let the CGI awfulness wash over you until you decide to turn it off.The problem is that because no time is spent on any of the characters or the story, you just don't give a toss about what's happening on screen no matter how mind-boggling a stunt the CGI is trying its best to suggest.Bottom line this film should have been a wonderful homage to the age of the classic horror movie. Each character, good and bad, should have been lovingly represented with the care and attention they deserved.Instead each character is shoehorned in as an excuse to show more badly rendered CGI.There's no love here, at all. It's just vacuous action with no point to it other than to make you say "wow look at all that CGI".If you're the sort of person who complains about a film because there's too much talking in it then this may be for you.The rest of us need to be aware that drivel like this actually exists and needs to be avoided at all costs.

One of the main Dracula movies...which
I've watched more than 10 times!There are mystics, romantics, fights, friendship, action, religion, emotional end, save the world theme and so many things in the scenario...
And a good squad in the making, maybe one of the 2,3,4 Dracula thematic movies with the best Cast when we talk about class of the acting.Okay it's fiction, but it's with great effects for 2004, and how much I have to write to prove better say that if they broadcast again on the TV...I'll watch it again..?

Review title: I expected not good, but never that bad
Review_body: Might have spoilers. Van Helsing is a waste. A waste of characters, each known separately and having good stories behind them, however all of them got twisted to the point of making the spectator feel that the screenwriter is just manipulating everything behind the name of all of them. Adding insult to injury the dialogs are ridiculous, and the story even worse, I felt like watching the League of extraordinary gentlemen all over again. Also the actors in the movie were drastically wasted behind a mist of CGI and a lot of scenery. It got to the point where it seemed like a badly knit bunch of scenes where Van Helsing was tried to be made into a sort of 007 from the past even recreating the laboratory where all his gadgets are made and just took Q for a ride including him in the mission. It seemed like a bad stew of stories from past authors with a new and bad twist mixed with CGI. Just plain bad. Although Kate Beckinsdale looked beautiful but we can always get a magazine for that.

Review title: Stop Sommers Before He Kills Again!
Review_body: As a fan of 1) good horror films, 2) Bram Stoker's novel, 3) Murnau, Browning, and Terence Fisher's 'Dracula' takes, 4) Peter Cushing; and having detested Stephen Sommers' 'Mummy' films, and having read all the reviews, I was not exactly in a great hurry to see this film. But I was willing put my purist's taste in the closet, along with my critical faculties, all my higher brain functions in fact, and just take this as zippy moving wallpaper, and finally renting it on the cheap on DVD, I found that even my spectacularly low expectations were not only stooped to but surpassed by this woefully empty exercise in CGI doodling off. The 3-page script I would reckon to have been packed together by a bunch of excitable pre-teens riffing on their favorite Horror and Adventure flicks, but I suspect such kids would have provided more solid characterization and plotting than this thing provides. Firstly Mr Sommers et al toss out everything that was interesting and meaningful about the Van Helsing character and the Dracula legend and fill in the gaps with a lot of agony aunt superhero stuff and a few good ideas (the secret Vatican anti-monster force, the warrior Gypsy clan) that are of no interest whatsoever to them, as they are only interested in layering on effects and stunts, the cumulative effect of which is incredibly boring. Making the heroes nearly as indestructible as the villains - as in the bit where Kate Beckinsale falls about four stories down through a tree's branches and lands with nary a scratch - really helps to make you care and believe in them. As with many modern movies, it is magnificently shot and dazzlingly designed, but provides no sensual pleasure whatsoever in its technical wizardry. Hugh Jackman does the intense superhero bit surprisingly well and all he requires is a script with lines of dialogue that make sense. Richard Roxburgh I wish would stop playing villains, for here as in 'Moulin Rouge' he goes right off the deep end with a stupidly campy performance. Beckinsale lacks steel, humor, and anything resembling sex appeal; I've followed her career since 'Cold Comfort Farm' and she gets duller by the passing year. David Wenham, the most talented of the three Aussies wasting themselves here, manages to make a couple of lines work with a good comic act. Compare this film to the genius of Tim Burton's 'Sleepy Hollow' (from which it steals a steroid-pumped version of the coach chase) which combined old and modern movie tropes so cleverly. At the point when I checked how much of it I had sat through - 81 minutes - and realized it still had something like 40-50 minutes to go, it was high time for the eject button. Abominable.

Review title: this movie is so bad, you have to see it to believe it!
Review_body: i couldn't believe this movie was as horrible as my friends described, so i had to see it. that should be their advertising campaign. "it's so bad, you have to see it to believe it!" this movie is nearly as bad as "contact" and for any of you that think contact was a good movie, this is my argument: 2 and a half hours and she still hasn't gotten into the friggin machine? but i digress. this movie was made to upset the audience. if you want to leave a movie theatre angry, then see this movie. you'll be upset with yourself for not being paid to make a movie better than this. i do recommend taking a date on this movie though. after watching all the horrible acting and special effects, your date will think anything you say or do is a hell of a lot more clever.

Van Helsing is one of the best executed 'Special Effects type of Movie' that has ever been made. Don't listen to the negative reviews for people who wanted more of a drama storyline. The story is there: Van Helsing hunts down monsters (Mr.Hyde, Werewolves, Vampires,Dracula) and he does it very well. I ask anyone not to be impressed with this movie for it's efficient action and story-telling, to give it a 2nd look because this was one very enjoyable movie. Start with the sequence with Van Helsing hunting down an amazing life like Mr. Hyde and dare not to be impressed. I have not witnessed this kind of special effects in any other movie to date! And...the fine work keeps coming: the transformation of the werewolves, the flying vampires, Frankenstein, and finally Dracula himself, with his amazing castle. Let's face it, this is the kind of movie that brings back memories of when you were a kid. But with today's technology, the imagination comes to real-life. This will definitely be part of my limited selection.

Review title: Such an awesome movie (may contain spoilers)
Review_body: First, let me just say that this was an INCREDIBLE movie. I think it's right up there with the X-men's. Hugh Jackman really sold this one. It exceeded all my expectations, and left me wanting more and more. I heard a lot of bad reviews from my friends before I saw this, and let me point out that they are no longer my friends. Nobody has any right to think this movie is less than perfect.The story was so incredible! The way they worked in Frankenstein and the Wolfman was beyond sweetness. Each forming their own intricate part of the fabric of the movie. The plot was so full of suspense that I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. Oh, and I can't even begin to describe how amazing the special effects were. They were probably the best I've ever seen.And lets not forget the characters. They were probably the best part of the whole thing. Here are just a few aspects of how cool they were:Van Helsing: From the previews he looked like one of those Spiderman "Oh, my life's work is also my curse, it's so hard, boo hoo hoo..." but this guy wasn't all crybaby about it. He took pride in nuking the hell out of all evil. I know what you're thinking, how all vampire hunters are automatically cool, but no other ones can even touch him. He doesn't just run around with a stake in his hands like these other idiots do. No, he gets a kick-ass auto-crossbow and blasts the crap out of them. Screw garlic necklaces and all that other pansy garbage. This is, like, the new age of vampire hunting.The Friar:Now this dude was my hero. He's like some quiet monk guy who's helping Van Helsing with all this high-tech equipment, but he still finds time to do the no-no cha-cha with a random chick. Plus, he was always there when somebody needed his helpDracula:No more of these boring old geezer vampires who look like they'll have a heart attack any second. If you cross him the wrong way, say good-bye to your soul. He'll be like talking to you one second, and then all of a sudden *chomp* you're dead. Before you know it he's picking pieces of your neck out of his teeth.Anna:Cool. Frankenstein monster:You except him to be some mindless monster going "ugg....uuugggg..." all the time and just being a huge inconvenience to everyone else. But once again a character's not what you expect. He looked so ugly, yet he was so peaceful and friendly. He was willing to sacrifice his own life for others. Now that's a stud right there.Torches, flying, darkness, crossbows, bombs, gravestones, ooze, secret passageways, huge jumps, pitchforks, insane laughter, racing coaches, revenge, thunderstorms, and more. WHAT ISN'T THERE TO LIKE????If you thought this movie was bad in any way, shape, or form, please kindly tattoo the word "worthless" on your forehead and bury your face in the sand. Your opinion will never matter. 10.34/10See this movie.

Review title: Relies to much on CGI which isn't that good anyway
Review_body: I was looking forward to seeing this movie and was disappointed when i did.The story is fair but the script is poor. The unnecessary use of humour (which isn't that funny) makes a mockery of what should have been a classic movie and the use of cgi way over the top. Mr.Hyde cgi (1 out of 10) The transformation of wolfman looks like it was done by an amateur (2 out of 10) the vampire transformations extending the vampires mouths when they bite was totally stupid.(2 OUT OF 10)In essence, not bad for an animated movie. Disney would be proud.

The movie Van Helsing has a thin plot but great action and special effects. It left a lot of questions unanswered.... possibly leaving room for a sequel? You definitely need to pay attention throughout the entire movie, otherwise you will have even more questions at the end. An interesting depiction of Dracula, although it could be said that the writers took their artistic liberties a little too far. I don't regret seeing the movie, but it left me feeling rather unsatisfied.

Van Helsing collects the worst aspects of summer movies into one giant, two -hour mess. Special effects take precedence over any kind of script or acting, and the movie is so ham-fisted and cliched in its dialogue that a better part of the movie is laughable. Dracula's performance borders on parody in the earlier parts of the film, and new characters and plot twists are introduced without any sort of rhyme or reason - see if you can catch such oddities as vampires in the daytime or at least one character who keeps falling into the same cliffside river. As if that weren't enough, the whole thing goes on for over two hours; by the time the final scene rolled around which goes for the sentimental ending, the audience was chuckling.In short: worse than The Punisher.

Another conversion of a comic book hero to a movie lead. Very little plot with multiple inconsistencies and confusing action interspersions. Frankenstein's monster becomes a good guy and Van Helsing wears Dracula's ring (no formal engagement, however). Holy water kills Dracula's brides but a werewolf has to bite Dracula to knock him off. Good acting by Hugh Jackman but Kate Beckinsale's acting was stilted and unconvincing. The special effects were reasonably good and the music was suitably creepy but much too loud. I had the foresight to bring ear plugs and wore them throughout the film. This film should appeal to the teen age crowd but won't play as well to adults.

Review title: A nice surprise, I loved it!
Review_body: After seeing the mixed ratings on this site, I wasn't sure about going to see this one. Glad I did. The action scenes were great and the sound was killer. Muvico theaters have great sound anyway, but several times throughout the movie especially with the werewolf noises, the walls and seats were vibrating. Unbelievable. Had me on edge, and it's been a while since I've been to a movie like that. Definitely worth the price of admission.

Ok I have to admit I like mindless action, but to some extent shouldnt there be a plot. I honestly liked the special effects and the non stop action but Why who what where when how and why is Van Helsing. We don't even get to know the character. Neither do we get to know the female lead. I understood she was from a long line of vampire hunters if I am not mistaken. Frankenstein looked pretty good but did he have Shakespeare's. He was more dramatic than anyone in that Titanic movie. Now from what I understand wasn't the wolfman only 1 person. He was about three in this movie. And the kicker is the ending....... WHAT IN THE WORLD WAS THAT PILE OF DOO?!?!?!? At that point I wanted to get a stake to the heart. Good grief. Now honestly the movie is watchable for those who love mindless action and pure mayhem. Now keep your eye out for when the guys turn into the Werewolf. Interesting stuff.

A fantastic film, see the special effects and drool, and the imagination and scope of the designers on this film. I enjoyed the film throughout, not sure what age rating it will receive as there are some scenes that are rather scary and I am a 25 year old bloke!Could have done without the James Bond style refs at the start of the film, and maybe its a tad too long, but the humour in the film balances out the scary parts of the flick. Put it this way it is a far superior film than the League of Gentlemen which is in the same genre, Coltrane's Mr Hyde is excellent compared to LoG! Jackman & Beckinsale are fine in this but don't expect any oscar nominations for either. The support Friar chap is funny, and helps tone down Van Helsings macho bravado.All in all its not going to move arthouse film lovers in the same way that it will move popcorn movie fans. You get exactly what you expect from the posters, big special fx amazing scenery and location work, a visual feast that takes the vampire hunter film genre up a big notch or three. Look forward to the TV spin off, hope its as good as the film was.

Well, it was yet another Sunday afternoon and I had just watched the Breakfast Club, so I was in the mood for the movies and some good acting. Thus I decided to try out the new Hugh Jackman-movie, Van Helsing. Good. I hadn't much expectation anyway, believing that it would be yet another nicely done action film similar to the Mummy. Unfortunately, I was mistaken. I don't know when it hit me (probably when the heroine in the high heels opened her mouth to speak in that weird, completely unnecessary accent), but suddenly I knew that this would be a film focusing on the impact of the special effects rather than the plot outline. I wasn't exactly expecting Shakespeare, anyway, but there were some things that made an "old" movie buff like me cringe: -There were hints at some deeper involvement between Dracula and Van Helsing, as well as his role in the ancient history of Transylvania , but somehow, all was badly explained. -There is no way one can understand why Van Helsing was, like, 400 years old, being human. He was human, wasn't he? -If the people in Transylvania were speaking their own language, why did they bother putting on that preposterous accent anyway?-Why didn't Van Helsing have that accent(from what I know, he was German anyway), if he lived there 400 years ago? What did he do in the meantime? How did Anna know about him? Was she speaking English? -Did anyone else notice how often the heroine was hurled against rocks, spun around, beaten up and God knows what else without breaking so much as a fingernail? And in the end, Van Helsing throws her on the couch and she just dies out of no apparent reason. It struck me funny and I wonder who thought of that lame ending for her after she'd proved to be unbreakable.Last but not least, the main character curiously reminded me of X-Men's Wolverine: his charming, innate grumpiness, his quest for recovering his memories, yadda-yadda-yadda. I can't imagine I was the only one who noticed that. All in all, Van Helsing is a movie packed (over packed) with action, wonderful special effects (which are becoming tiresome, to say the least), a hilarious, sneering villain and a great sidekick... but absolutely no story. It is cliché after cliché and appallingly shallow. Nice for a Sunday afternoon, but I wouldn't watch it again... ever.

Review title: No stretch but a lot of fun.
Review_body: If you loved the Mummy and the Indiana Jones flicks then you will enjoy Van Helsing. Hugh Jackman and Kate Bekinsale turn in credible performances and the special effects are second to none (the horse and carriage scenes are fantastic). My one concern is the opening sequence. Filmed in black and white it comes across as a bad parody, I wasn't sure wether to laugh or not. Happily the film picks up as soon as the opening sequence is finished.On the whole I really enjoyed this film. It looks amazing and the action is plentiful. This film is FUN!! I hope there is a sequel but only as long as there is no annoying child actor as in the sequel to the Mummy.

Review title: Great monster movie throwback, fun movie on its own.
Review_body: I keep seeing bad reviews for this movie, and I can't help but wonder why. I came into the movie expecting the worse. I've been disappointed by movies often lately, and the trailer for this one had all the symptoms. I wasn't even comforted by the fact that it was directed by Stephen Sommers, whose Mummy movies I really liked.However, I can safely say that I left the movie completely satisfied and my faith in Stephen Sommers as a great "adventure" movie directory has been solidified.Maybe people are looking to get too much out of this movie - I don't know. I never expected it to be an award winning movie. I just went into it to have fun. I'm a big fan of old monster movies, and this movie has numerous throwbacks to the old movies... I started laughing out loud at a lot of the camera work because it felt so much like a classic monster movie. They did an excellent job at paying tribute to a lot of the classic moments from these movies without obviously straying from the story.The story was decent to good. There were a lot of elements I liked, but there wasn't a HUGE amount of depth to it (not necessarily a problem, in my eyes). My only real problems with the story were some rather large jumps they did from one scene to another without explaining the events in between very well.The action was very well done, as was the accompanying computer graphics that made a lot of the scenes possible. The special effects weren't always on par with other recent movies, such as LGX, but they were definitely believable for the most part.My vote for this movie was 8/10. I think it did what it set out to do - make a movie that paid a tribute to the monster movies of old, while giving audiences a fun filled two hour ride through a large cast of characters. The movie was just the right length, and besides some plot holes and CG problems, I was a happy movie-goer at the end of the experience. If you liked the Mummy, I can definitely recommend this movie.

Review title: THE WORST MOVIE OF THIS YEAR
Review_body:
Gabriel Van Helsing (Hugh Jackman) is a man-on-a-mission, determined to rid the world of its most evil, nightmarish creatures. Working through a clandestine Catholic connection, he's off to slay Count Dracula (Richard Roxburgh), along with Dracula's jealous, bloodthirsty brides. But in Transylvania, he's not the only vampire hunter. There's intrepid, corset-clad Anna Valerious (sexy Kate Beckinsale), plus Frankenstein's Monster, the Wolf Man, even Dr. Jekyll/Mr. Hyde.The movie is a one big disappointment. Wooden acting, VERY BAD VISUALS EFFECTS and boring like hell.Oh, did I mention this.Kate Beckinsale is the worst actress ever.The movie plays like one long preview for a video game.  The film's CGI sets are as handsome as you'd find produced by the finest game machines.Many, many times dialogue is idiotic: It has about as much life as a drained corpse. "You can't kill me," Dracula actually says. "I'm already dead!" You're telling me.
I went into Van Helsing expecting a cheesy B-movie.  Unfortunately, what I got was a very bad cheesy B-movie.  I give it a Z.

When I saw this movie there was no doubt in my mind that it is the single GREATEST movie of all time according to me!!! I really have no idea why so many people gave it bad reviews. I noticed nothing that was bad about it. I've noticed that a lot of reviews say that there was no plot to it. What the heck are they talking about!?!?! I followed the movie quite easily. And the special effects just blew me away!!! The transformations of The Wolfman and Dracula were spectacular! I've really never seen any better!Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale were in my mind Oscar worthy and if no one else agrees well the heck with you!!! Because I really don't care what other people say about this movie except for me! if you're wondering why I"m putting just this on, I'm doing it so that I may have some peace of mind knowing that I put my opinion out there and don't care what you say about it. That's right I'm doing this for me!!! I don't know why I waited this long to say this! I saw this movie the day after it came out.Oh yeah and to all you people who think Stephen Sommers has never directed a good movie, you should really think about watching The Mummy, The Mummy Returns, and Deep Rising some of the best movies I've ever seen!!!

It was glorious, it had all the elements it needed to be perfect! It had action, adventure, mystery, horror and the locations chosen for the filming were excellent. I've got a friend who has seen tens of films with me at the movies and always managed to have nerves of steel but when the first vampire spawn sprang out he jumped off his seat! He felt really ashamed because I keep refreshing his memory on the incident. He is my horror meter and he went off the top so Van Helsing certainly had it's great horror moments. It is much better than films like Scream or I Know What You Did Last Summer as thrillers are concerned which give you that one second fright which passes after you munch a bit of popcorn because you feel the atmosphere changing slowly when a scare is coming up (lowering background music and sounds, heavy breathing by a character(s),etc...) and the audience thinks "Oh no, I forgot to empty my bladder before the film!". I am a huge vampire-hunting fan and I was really satisfied on the explanations given about vampire slaying (although I have to check the Dracula vs Werewolf legend out). Go see it. It was great fun and I hope that this genre will be revived after many years of abandonment.

Review title: I just... really love this movie
Review_body:
While it might not have gotten a lot of praise, I gave it a lot of praise as I must've watched it constantly as a kid. It featured a long-haired Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale - I know what I'm about, right?
I saw it's also a new movie or an anime and there's a tv series too, so those will go on my watchlist (where it will probably stay for a long while 😂😂).

I thought it was one of the best movies made in years, pure fun, pure fantasy. They could not have picked ANYONE better to play Van Helsing, Kate was just cool, Richard did an excellent job (who cares if his accent faded a time or two). The Effects were great and I especially loved the werewolf, best one that I've seen in years.Exactly what I always have imagined one would look like.Steven Sommers is an excellent director and I have loved all of his movies, he does monsters excellently and realistically, and keeps the fun in the movies. I will go see anything he makes, and buy it, too!Ya know, if you stop picking apart movies, you might just learn to enjoy them.

I thought this movie rocked! Lots of action, fast moving , and the ending wasn't what you expected either. The special effects are very good, great computer effects. The story is entertaining, taking an old venue and mixing it with a new twist. I never heard of this writer, director, producer before, though I am a bit naive in that way, but it was a top notch production to me! I recommend that you Watch it on a large widescreen TV for a real treat! You will not be disappointed at how interesting the movie will keep you as it is action packed and always moving from scene to scene. One of the things I did love about this movie was its pace and the characters are wonderful too. Two thumbs up for me!

Review title: The ruining of a could be great story
Review_body: This movie has all except a good story. All fans of Dracula knows the magic of van Helsing. In Coppola's movie he is there when Dracula resents God, and becomes an undead. The doctor pursues Dracula for the 400 years until he has the final encounter in London when the count goes there looking for his life's,and death's, love. Taken from this scenario van Helsing could have been a very good movie about the hunt for the master vampire during those 400 years. But obviously they have saved the money from the story writing and chosen to go with special effects and half naked beautiful women. Mixing to much of modern action and modern weapons, looking rusty old fashioned,in to a medieval scene is in my opinion not helping this movie. Also it must be said that after Oldman as charismatic dangerous Dracula(In Coppola's movie) it just will not do with a plain nice looking "James Bond" type for a Dracula no matter how long his hair and bad his words. At best Dracula should be Oldman, but at least they should use an actor with a "sting" to do the role.

Review title: One of the worst movies ever made
Review_body: This campy spoof of monster movies, James Bond movies and adventure films is probably destined to be a cult classic, it's so awful. By turns hilarious and excruciating, one watches in disbelief that the writer of some of the very best adventure movies of the modern age could have been involved in this mess. I'm not sure that the scenes that left me almost literally rolling on the floor in tears of hysterical laughter were actually meant to be funny at all. There are some familiar names involved in the supporting cast, who were all brilliant in other movies but fall far short in this one, and the cgi work is erratic at best. In fact, I can't imagine how a post-Gollum movie could turn out something as lousy as the disgustingly amateurish Mr.Hyde. The plot is ridiculous, the supposedly clever comments and catchphrase-wannabes are lame beyond description. There's nothing to recommend this to anyone, unless you like being tortured by a really bad movie. Avoid this one like you would a huge flock of winged demons! Actually, if I had a choice between being attacked by demons or watching this again, I'd take my chances with the demons.

Review title: Watch Dead and loving it instead
Review_body: First a confession. I gave up watching this travesty after the first hour. As a human rather than an immortal vampire, I decided that I could not waste any more of my limited lifespan on this appalling film.I watched the monochrome opening under the belief that this was a spoof shown before the main feature.As it featured Dracula and Frankenstein I expected Abbott and Costello to appear in the manner of the recent deadstar-studded Virgin train commercial. Richard Roxborough's, camp as a field of tents, performance then lead me to believe that it was going to be a re-imagining of Carry on Screaming.As for supporting performances, special mention must be made of Alun Armstrong's accent - scary although it has to be said that it was not as unconvincing as the CGI effects during the aerial attack by the brides of Dracula.If you want to see Kate Beckinsale in a vampire flick watch Underworld. If you want to see a better vampire film watch "Dead and Loving It", If you want a reinterpretation of the Van Helsing character, may I suggest Von Goosewing in "Duckula"

Review title: Epitome of cliché (plot points but not spoilers inside)
Review_body: I would have loved giving this a 1, but that wouldn't be appropriate unless every facet of this film was horrible.There are a few saving graces. Namely, the fairly good CG work and obvious high production value. But the plot is atrocious! It steals exact, specific lines from other movies, it steals entire scenes from other movies, and I'm not sure, but it looks like whatever else was original was already present in an earlier Japanese animation series called Helsing, and was probably stolen from that as well.There were a few moments that were so stupid that they were funny. About ten minutes in, Van Helsing is fighting Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, tosses him out of a window, and the monster turns back to a human on the way down to his demise, letting loose a hilarious, "huh?" before he smacks pavement. Later, in the middle of a calm conversation between Helsing and Dracula, Helsing whips out a cross and shoves it in Dracula's face. Dracula proceeds to grab it, catch it on fire, and scream at the top of his lungs for an extended amount of time. Helsing (I believe) drops the cross. Dracula continues talking as if nothing happened, the previous ridiculous grimace faded from his face.The only thing that made this watchable was Kate Beckinsale, she was beautiful in this role.

This movie has nothing to recommend itself. There is no plot, no character development, and no re substance. Everyone involved should sue the director of this travesty for career endangerment. It seems like the director tried to create too many various sub-plots and lost all of them about half-way through. The Frankenstein's Monster B-Story gets lost amongst the Werewolves, Dracula Babies, and Fallen Angels. The latter being introduced far too late in the story to be anything, but a total distraction. To be honest, I gave up half-way through it and only finished the movie because my friend had the car keys. Needless to say, that friend does not get to pick the movie any more. I walked out wanting my money back.

After fifteen minutes from the beginning, as the plot (?) was unveiling, I realised that sooner or later I could have seen Van Helsing fighting against Godzilla or Alien VII, so I decided to take a deep nap. I started dreaming about genuine B movies, which have been whipped away by computer generated effects. I suddenly woke up because of my neighbours' complaints - (yes, I snore loudly). I blamed myself for every penny I spent for renting this movie. Then I realised that somebody else paid for the rental and I felt a little better. And I felt much, much better because I didn't go to a cinema to see this boring potpourri. Definitely to be avoided.

I don't know why people hate it. I think it is one of the best films ever. It's blend of action, story, and characters is amazing. The special effects were incredible and so was the make-up. The best characters were none other than Frankenstein's Monster and Van Helsing. Their acting was wonderfully breathtaking. Kate Beckinsile was beautiful. The scenery such as the ballroom were fabulous. The best scene was the very first, ballroom scene, and all of Dracula's castle, and don't forget the chase scene with the Wolfman. I recommend it. Frankenstein's Monster though I must say was the most spectacular. This movie should please everyone because it has so many elements combined so wonderfully along with great music surprises, and more. Please watch this movie everyone. It is a triumph of cinema.

Van Helsing is basically the story of a monster hunter who lives in the world of Gothic 19th century creatures. The movie is not so much horror but steam-punk science fiction. He works for a worldwide peacekeeping service that employs anyone from Islamic to Buddhist and is surprisingly enough based in the Vatican. Van Helsing looks an awful lot like the WWE wrestler the Undertaker.Van Helsing is called to Transylvania to kill Dracula. Even though its cold, dark, and a few people every month die as sacrifices to the vampires there are still quite a few people living there. And even though the town is in Europe people still use feet and inches. There he finds Anna who looks like a 16th century pirate in fancy clothes while everyone else wears rags. Anna's family has basically fought against Dracula for centuries and no one can kill him, now she is the only one left and Van Helsing has to save her.The computer graphics and special effects are very good and the story is decent. All the monsters are nicely animated except for Frankenstein's creature who looks very fake in the costume. The movie looks very corny from the beginning with items like automatic crossbows and self spinning throwing stars. Its basically batman set 100 years before and with a lady buccaneer. While not nearly a classic, Van Helsing makes up for a well entertained 2 hours.

Let me say that I am a huge fan of Hugh Jackman, Kate Beckinsale and David Wenham, and I don't really have a bias against popcorn flicks or mainly action and CGI-based movies. I enjoyed The Mummy series, and I expected Van Helsing to be somewhere along the same lines: good actors, action adventure, a few snappy funny lines and a very basic but suspenseful storyline.It is not.It is very, very bad.The film has a very flimsy storyline, gaping plot holes, and terrible dialogue. The CGI is very poorly done and is glaringly obvious, to the point where you are unwilling to forgive it. At first, I was very happy to suspend disbelief and continue along as the plot took me. And then, very early on in the film, the plot totally vanished, and I was left saying, "What the hell is going on?" Count Dracula requires the machine invented by Dr. Frankenstein (along with his monster) to bring to life his offspring who, because he and his brides are undead, are naturally, born dead. This makes no sense, but you can kind of accept it and that's not a problem. Dracula has lost Frankenstein's monster, however, and has been trying to make the machine work with Werewolves. It fails. At the same time, he's trying to kill off the Valerious family, the last remaining survivor being Kate Beckinsale's character, Anna.Anna is by far one of the absolute worst heroines I have ever seen in a film. She is completely useless! Nothing she EVER does in the ENTIRE film is AT ALL HELPFUL. She prevents Van Helsing from killing the werewolf that her brother has turned into, she is a major disruptive factor in his killing the vampires, and is constantly offering nothing but incredibly annoying and petulant dialogue. "I don't need any help" (directly before displaying how totally awful she is at defending herself against vampires, and directly after completely botching an attempt to kill a werewolf), "We've been trying to find Dracula for 400 years, I doubt you can do it in 2 hours" (moments before Van Helsing and Carl discover the door to his lair which was so glaringly obvious it's impossible to miss it), "You fool! Nobody knows how to kill Dracula!" (after Van Helsing's failed attempt to kill Dracula, after she has refused to disclose any information whatsoever that would be helpful).Van Helsing is no better, really, but would have been much more interesting if his storyline was actually, I don't know, EXPLORED instead of just HINTED AT CONSTANTLY? At the beginning, we are told that he has no memory of his past, and grabs at the chance to go to Transylvania for the opportunity to learn more, but right at the point that Dracula is attempting to TELL US, he says, "Some things are better left forgotten" and then kills him. Thanks, that's great, but what about the audience?! Maybe we want to know? Dracula himself is a complete failure at being scary, and is a complete failure at being camp. The characterisation is just bad.And the gaping plot holes? The parts of the movie that just don't make sense? There are SO MANY. Like, they leave Transylvania at a full moon, and then, by the time they hit Budapest, it's already 2 days until the next full moon? It took them A MONTH to get there? Okay, I accept that, but explain to me how it took them only a few hours to GET BACK to find Dracula's lair? How about how at the end, Dracula is apparently missing a finger, but he hasn't been missing a finger for the rest of the entire movie, and even after that moment of revelation, he miraculously has the finger again? And how does a man who is undead and can heal continuously, even not have a finger to begin with? The ending is sappy and unbelievably stupid. Oh, there's CGI Anna, up in the clouds with her family, near the sea (a throwaway line of dialogue earlier that made no sense, and was apparently put in just to enhance the "emotion" of her funeral) which is glittering beneath a sunset. And then, as Van Helsing and Carl leave, back for Rome, they walk out, towards land, towards...oh, the sunset again. It wasn't cheesy enough with just ONE sunset, I guess.AVOID THIS MOVIE. IT IS BAD. FOR REAL.

Review title: I loved it but if it isn't the kind of film you usually enjoy- don't go there!
Review_body: Van Helsing, a film I went to see purely because it was raining outside. And I was surprised at how much I enjoyed it. The basic genre is action/adventure/horror; that pretty much sums the film up. The plot isn't up to much and it looks as though it was just a big get together of all of Universal's favourite monsters. But sit back and enjoy the action and the film is pretty good, the effects work and the music is fitting. Yes, the acting isn't going to win any Oscars and KAte Beckinsale does what she seems to do best- kick butt in a tight costume (Underworld + its sequel). If you look at Stephen Sommers' other films 'The Mummy' and 'The Mummy Returns' it becomes evident that fun, sometimes silly and generally poorly plotted action adventures are what he likes to do. Again, films like this won't appeal to everyone and won't win any awards but don't we go to the cinema to relax and enjoy the film and Van Helsing fits the bill (though be careful not to spill your popcorn- there are a few bits to give you a fright). I have seen Hugh Jackman do much better and for people who have only seen him in this film I say that he is really a very talented actor. The actors are mostly well cast and there is plenty for the boys (Beckinsale) and the girls (Jackman) to enjoy. Don't watch the film if you want to see something sophisticated and well-scripted with stellar performances and superb dialogue, please steer clear. However, for a night in, this movie is great- especially for the younger generation who will probably be able to look over the mistakes and plot to the action sequences and CGI. All in all this is an easy going low-budget flick which you will either love or hate, decide for yourself. Some of you may enjoy the comedic references and one-liners and others will think they are silly and out of place but I liked the overall effect of the film and think that too many critics took it too seriously and therefore the film was underrated. Van Helsing is worth renting at least, you may enjoy it as much as I did!

Review title: Hugh Jackman Makes Van Helsing COME ALIVE
Review_body: Scary vampire movies are NOT my favorite, but I have made this one an exception. Hugh Jackman just makes the movie more real, gives it credence- more believable. I have watched it several times and will watch it again. This is the first movie I have ever seen Kate Beckinsale- She is good. I also want to mention Will Kemp who portrayed her brother Velcan WOW! I am now searching for movies with Will Kemp - he is HOT! However, it's VERY hard to realize that Richard Roxburgh (who plays Count Dracula) is the same guy who plays the geeky dweeb in Moulin Rouge (?) Yes, I give this movie a solid 10. Loved it- the only scary movie I will watch.

I've seen this movie yesterday when I rented it, It seem good. Hugh Jackman, Kate Beckinsale. pretty nice cast, but yet such a lame flick. I think that you can tell the story of Van Helsing, so much better, and with some mystery and Intesity. but here Its just non-stop action, From what could be a great mystery/horror/Thriller movie Stephen Sommers made It pure and only action movie and thats too bad. I Think with a better script and different director This story could have been preformed much better.p.s If you even think about rent it , DON'T. The only place that Its worth seeing is on cable TV, and thats if you really needs to kill some time... :)

This is Hollywood at it'a worst. Bad script, bad directing, bad acting, unnecessary characters, no internal logic, disregard for the laws of science, lousy special effects that rely too much on CGI,lack of understanding (or appreciation) for the material, and just a mindless attempt to make money by creating merchandising tie-ins.Want good modern Gothic horror based on a literary monster? Watch Tim Burton's "Sleepy Hollow" instead. You'll be glad you did.Burton is a genius, a master storyteller who could care less about making money, has a true appreciation for horror, and gives you genuine characters whom you feel for.

Review title: This movie is its own Frankenstein monster.
Review_body: A regrettable waste of talent and resources. Aside from the acting, this was a heavy-handed effort. Were it not for some lighter moments with the female vampires and a re-imagined Frankenstein monster, I would consider this the most pointless movie of 2004. Some reviewers have noted that Van Helsing borrowed elements from a number of other recent movies. I agree. In that vein, this movie is its own Frankenstein monster. The acting was satisfactory -- I just wish there had been more boldness, creativity and imagination on the other end of the camera. I must add, though, that at least some of my fellow audience members were hugely entertained by the film.

Not quite what I was expecting.  I was expecting much more.  Considering Hugh Jackman was in the film, I was expecting a X-Men quality movie.  My hopes were sadly disappointed.  Richard Roxburgh played also in League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, which fell into the same category.The characters were shallow.  The film was 2.5 hours of a lot of comic book style action, which was great to watch.  The only character which had the most development was Frankenstein's monster.  He actually had dialogue. The rest of the characters were lacking in dialogue and depth.  One scene had Hugh and Anna kiss, which practically came out of nowhere.  I just wish Hugh signs up for X3.

Review title: Can anyone sell me back 2 hours of my life?
Review_body: Within 5 minutes of the opening, I knew I'd made a mistake by entering the theatre.
