After 20 minutes, I began to think that the box office should issue cyanide capsules along with your ticket to this show. It's not much of a horror show, but it is a nightmare ordeal to experience.There isn't much of a story or character development. There's barely an effort to create any sense of time and place. The dialogue and action is laughably insipid. There is never any sense of peril or suspense, because almost everything is obviously pasted together on a Mac. (NOTE TO DIRECTORS: If I can see that the hero is fighting a CGI monster on top of a CGI Notre Dame, rather than a monster with some physical presence on a set that resembles a real cathedral, what's so thrilling about that? Where is the sense of real danger? If I see a runaway stagecoach driving down a CGI path heading for a CGI canyon, what's supposed to make me care?) Even the costumes are out of place: Jackman is dressed like the mysterious, brooding hero of a postmodern Western, and Beckinsale in her bodice and lycra pants appears to have been pulled from a Meat Loaf video.All that's here is Wolverine from the X-Men fighting some CGI versions of famous monsters, presented with a relentless assault of loud noise (in Surround Sound!), going through the paces of various ridiculous and implausible scenarios. I had to sit through it until the end because I was with a group, but I actually slipped out for 5 minutes in the middle just so I could get a break. Towards the end, I started to feel like I wanted to cry. Seriously. Like another reviewer said, I felt like Alex in A Clockwork Orange being forced to watch such horrible images until I broke. As I walked out after the show, I wanted to ask the concessions people if they could sell me back the last two hours of my life.It was one of the worst movie-going experiences of my entire life. If somebody asks you to see this next weekend, save yourself. You might even consider breaking off a friendship to avoid this drain on the soul. Life is too precious to waste on dreck like Van Helsing.

Review title: Big and dumb- and I loved it.
Review_body: I'd read quite a few reviews on different sites where people were complaining about the lack of substance and how the movie didn't take itself seriously and so on and so on. And, well. I really don't know what in the world those people were expecting from a movie with vampires, werewolves, *and* Frankenstein's monster directed by the guy who made The Mummy. Van Helsing was everything I expected it to be: big stupid monster fun. For crying out loud, it had villagers with pitchforks and torches in the beginning! How can anyone expect a film that starts off that way to be high art?Speaking of the beginning, I was absolutely delighted with it. Some people might call it a rip-off but I thought it was a brilliant homage to Frankenstein (it's been a while since I've seen it, but I'm pretty sure up until Dracula pops up, it was shot-for-shot the same).Also, Dracula! Quite a few people have expressed the opinion that Richard Roxburgh wasn't portraying him seriously enough, but, again, why would he? As soon as he began to speak, I was all, 'ha!  Bela Lugosi!' and, oh, I loved the way he camped the entire thing up. Along the same lines, I also loved his brides. The scene of them all overemoting and wailing after the vamplings all exploded? So cheesy! It was fantastic.Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale were okay, although I spent most of the movie wondering when Kate was going to say, 'Ve must get moose and squirrel!'The best part of the movie, though, and the main reason I wanted to see it, was David Wenham. Absolutely darling and funny! And it was kind of weird because I've only ever seen him as Faramir, aka The Saddest Man in All of Gondor, but I loved it. Maybe I'm just easily amused, but I had a giggle-fit almost every time he appeared on-screen.  I don't understand why Carl had to be so short, though. Well, okay, maybe I do a little, to make Van Helsing all the more larger-than-life and all that crap, but, still. My back hurt watching him slump around. awww, poor Daisy.I do have to agree with everyone who said the CGI sucked. The brides weren't too bad but, god. Jekyll? bleh. Didn't like that at all. And the werewolves all looked...well. Fake. Come on, folks. If you're going to CG, at least make an effort.So, yeah. overall, I loved it. I went in expecting non-stop action and lots of pretty, and that's pretty much what I got, plus some laughs (some maybe unintentional, like 'The roof, the roof, the roof is on fi-yah').And I am all about a sequel. More Daisy! YAY!!!

I enjoyed this story and anyone who likes a good vampire flick will like it. You can't expect too much from this genre but it has a good mix of action, horror, romance and even a bit of comedy (There are some great 'tongue-in-cheek' comments) It also looks good; the sets are lavish and some scenes have a glorious over-the-top 'Hammer House of Horror atmosphere about them. The makers of this film didn't take it all too seriously - neither should those who watch it.D.

Review title: Things I would rather do, or have done to me instead of watching Van Helsing again!!!!!
Review_body: 1. Be a passenger on the Titanic.2. Have an alien burst out of my chest.3. Be piloting the space shuttle Columbia on it last flight.4. Have all my teeth pulled with no Novocaine.5. Be the 4th backpacker in Hostel.6. Slipped the date-rape drug in a gay bar.7. Jump into an active volcano.8. Watch King Kong again...really 9. Give Hillary Clinton a Gynecological exam.10. Have a 25-foot shark swallow me whole.This comment is dedicated to Laura............

Review title: Starts out good,and then DOO DOO
Review_body: Van Helsing is a interesting movie,because it starts out GREAT.I mean the opening black & white scenes are a tribute the horror movies of old.It looks just like the movies our parents (and some of you older folks) grew up on.And after that,we are introduced to a character that (Again,was more well known with the older folks)is rude,crude and kills for fun...Dr Jekyll.I liked Dr. Jeckyll,I thought he was fun and funny, and that it sucked that he was killed.I was kinda mad,lol,cause I thought he was a great character.And after that,the movie goes quickly downhill,it's all by-the-books action movie stuff.Nothing totally new and exciting.And Hugh Jackman's character is the movie version of Wolverine without the X-Men abilities...Lots of action and one-liners.Oh and of course it wouldn't be a by-the-books action movie without the pointless hot sidekick,this time it's Anna Valerious(played by the sexy Kate Beckinsale)It's a damn shame this movie had to go downhill like that,it started out so well..but like they say "The best laid plans of mice and men go oft astray"

Review title: Straight through ridiculous into sublime (VERY mild spoilers).
Review_body: I apologize to all of you who didn't get the joke. Particularly to those of you who were sitting near me in the theater while I was cackling maniacally.Even the people who liked this movie don't seem to have been mentioning what I considered its biggest feature: it's a massive parody. Apparently they overdid it so far that most of the audience couldn't see it.Imagine, if you will, the scriptwriter. He's been given the right to put in *anything* from Universal history that he wants. So he makes a movie about Dracula AND Frankenstein AND the Wolf-man. Then, to make sure people will get the joke, he puts in baby pods like Alien and lights them up like the Matrix. Then, to make *really* sure people will get the joke, he makes the lead Wolverine with Batman's toys, and gives everyone multiple opportunities to swing from ropes of exactly the right length at exactly the right time.We go to the movies to see things that can't happen, but we'd like it if they could. Fantasy movies often stumble when they try to do one of the Great Plots, but they're ashamed to go all the way because it "won't be realistic." Come on. It's Dracula. None of this is realistic. Revel in the cheesiest plot of all time! I'll be in the fifth row. Come cackle with me.

Review title: One of the best comedies made this decade! (Everybody rope swings!)
Review_body: What a hilarious movie! This version of Dracula was the most foppish, nonthreatening fancy boy ever to be on screen. Don't make him mad or he'll sneer and make a snide comment. Or worse yet, he'll get one of his undead midget zombies to... uh, I don't know, uppercut your knee cap and bite your ankle? Frankenstein's monster was not only loaded with hackneyed dialog but was a great addition to the absurdity. And his retarded gait is one of the funniest ways of walking since David Cross's impersonation of a strut in "Pootie Tang." Not to mention the funniest scene in the whole movie where we get to see Frankenstein's monster swing from a wire three times in a row in what looks like the same scene looped over and over and over. It made beer shoot out of my nose I was laughing so hard.The Wolfman was simply ridiculous. Werewolves are big, sure but when are they supposed to be twenty feet tall? Bigger than Frankenstein's monster? And am I supposed to believe this Saturday morning cartoon quality computer generated thing is actually interacting with the characters on screen? Please tell me this was supposed to be funny.The sexy heroin was also a laugh riot. The thought that anyone could fight anything supernatural or not while wearing a corset with stiletto boots is worth a few chuckles. Sexy? Sure, but so impractical. It's like fighting off zombie Nazis with Bettie Page and Dita von Teese or ghost hunting with the Playboy bunnies.And Van Helsing? Apparently the creators of this movie never bothered to read "Dracula" or even see all the "Dracula" movies. This is a cookie cut facsimile of exactly what American cinema does to characters from classic literature: Take a good character and make him a macho cowboy. This version of Van Helsing doesn't even know what a freakin' vampire is.And he works for the Vatican which apparently manufactures spy gear for supernatural slaying like the Q- branch in James Bond films. (Obviously, the director like James Bond movies so much he copied the Q- gadget scene with little to no scruples. Is the Pope M, then?)About the special CGI effects? The computer animation from "The New Adventures of Johnny Quest" was not only more convincing than "Van Helsing's" but was also a more noble effort. The battle between werewolf Helsing and Bat- form Dracula looks like two guys playing "Soul Caliber" except the graphics in the movie aren't as good as an Xbox or Playstation 2. As a horror/ action movie: this simply sucks. Oh, my god, I can't convey in words how much this sucks. Watching someone else play "Castlevania" is tenfold better than suffering through this tripe.But as a comedy? Absolutely hilarious. Grab some beers and some friends and get ready to let the absurdity and hackneyed Hollywood crap that is "Van Helsing" rip your sides open.

Saw the preview last night.  Disappointed ... they were handed the Horror Crown Jewels and screwed it up.  Fortunately, you can't screw up established properties to the point of no return, but they give it a good try. I saw many people get up and leave for pee breaks even though exciting scenes were happening. I need to see it again, without the running commentary from the guy behind, who thought he was doing MST (without the jokes). It is watchable, trashy but watchable with some very good performances. However instead of them taking time and developing characters for a franchise run, they just squeeze in everything they can and it doesn't work. The brides are the best part of the movie.

Review title: Fast pacing, terrific effects, good story
Review_body: Some may say that this movie has no depth, a typical popcorn flick. But I don't agree at all; it's not literary depth, but it isn't the typical linear plot either. This movie is 2 and 1/4 hours long, but the pacing stays fast throughout. The visual effects are really great, and they blend in well. And the story ... well, it's not quite linear, but has appealing twists and turns.In summary, this movie is better than many others. It is a genre movie, so if You do not like fantastic vampire stories and are totally and exclusively into Rosamunde Pilcher or Pedro Almodovar, better do not watch it; for the others - 7/10.

When a movie depends on Computer Graphics as much as Van Helsing did, you know there's a big problem.  Some of the dialog was witty but it  just didn't move in any direction that made sense. Kill the vampires. Okay, I'm with that. People running outside to SEE the vampires come to get them? Not so much.  Nothing much between the characters that would make you think they had a thought for each other.  When Van Helsing transforms into a werewolf and attacks Princess Anna, shouldn't she have looked a little more.....well, ATTACKED?   The best part of the CG glut was the wives of Dracula transformations.  That I enjoyed. But basically it was a loud, violent, mishmash of monsters.  No,  I pass on this one.

Review title: Watched this on Halloween and genuinely don't have a clue what happens.
Review_body: This is the best comedy film I have seen in a long while. I watched this a few years ago on Halloween with a few friends and we laughed for the full 127 minute run time. Overall, maybe watch this but it could also be awful because I don't remember anything.

This movie really belongs in a special category: the worst 250 movies with a real budget. As it stands the current worst 250 are populated with movies where an argument could be made that the producers were not *that* much to fault, as they may not have had enough money, cast or resources to create an adequate movie.But in this case, there *are* characters and special effects galore so it could be only actual intent to create a bad movie of this caliber with terrible dialogs, no story to mention and overall stupidity. The only audience that could be captured here would be 6 year old, but then again, it's too bloody for them to watch.My advice is to stay away from this as far as possible.

This is the first time I have ever been tempted to walk out of a movie within the first five minutes, but since I paid 11 bucks for it, I figured I would stick it out. Hugh Jackman was miscast, and Kate Beckinsale looked great but her accent was horrible. Richard Roxburgh (as Count Dracula) was actually pretty good. He was the only one who really looked like he was having fun as he chewed the scenery. Unfortunately, he was the only one who took this route for his performance. The comedy was stale, the action was cookie-cutter, and the plot was uninteresting. I felt like this movie didn't know what it wanted to be. I think it could have been a pretty decent, campy, fun film, but instead, it just takes itself way too seriously and ends up scoring extremely high on the unintentional comedy scale as a result.
I gave this movie a 7/10 because the story and effects was good. I really liked the movie. But IT wasnt ekstreme topp all the time. The vissuals was good. The effects was good.

A lot of special effects and a storyline that tries to justify them all. It was typical summer fare.  Hugh Jackman gave an admiral and strong performance as did Richard Roxburgh.  There were just some terribly annoying things to watch throughout:  (1) Kate Beckinsdale's perfect make-up, especially eyeliner, (2) her ridiculous clothing (3) the horrendous make-up job on Igor.I viewed it as the first movie of the summer and gave it leeway as such. I thought Hellboy was a much better movie (considering what is in theaters now). I expect spectacle for summer.  This had the spectacle effects. However, I've seen bigger and better and will expect that from each movie in coming weeks.

yes... a childish jab to say the least, but thats all i can summon after seeing this piece of garbage.  from the opening sequence I was aware of what I was getting into.  i couldnt believe how exponentially more hilarious this movie became from one scene to the next.  not in a funny, entertaining way, mind you, i mean in the ashamed, embarrassed kind of way.i do not get the urge to walk out of movies very often, and yet after twenty minutes I contemplated that every 5 minutes for the rest of the film.  i stuck it out though, just because I was intrigued to see how bad it could really get.  what a waste of 2 hours of my life.  i considered after watching the film that it was an attempt to recreate the corny B-monster flicks of the 50's and 60's.  that's the only excuse I can make for it. the formulaic characters, the abysmal dialogue and acting, the over-the-top attempts at drama and suspense, the effects...  oh my lord the effects were just horrid!!  please save yourself from this experience.  wait for it on video, at least you have the opportunity to make it stop.

Review title: Vampires and werewolves, what more could you ask for? A better movie!
Review_body: I have been waiting with anticipation for this movie. I'm a big fan of monster movies, especially when they include vampires or werewolves. Van Helsing has both, AND Frankensteins monster, so I have been eagerly awaiting this title. And last night was the world premiere, with Galla, monster outfits, push-up Vampirella outfits and so forth, what a JOY!!*****Minor Spoilers below*********** Unfortunately the movie is very disappointing. The storyline has so many holes, it must have been bitten by a rabid vampire. The plot is pretty standard, with no surprises at all, leaving your guesses from the start of the movie, confirmed at the end.Right from the beginning, you are told that the main character is several hundred years old, which makes him some kind of immortal. Hence, you never get to feel that he is in any kind of danger. You know what kills vampires, you know what kills werewolves, you don't know if there is anything that can kill Van Helsing. This is probably the biggest problem of the movie. IT NEVER GETS EXCITING OR THRILLING!! Add to that, Van Helsing is the James Bond of forgotten days, armed with an arsenal of "futuristic" weapons and devices which are always there to save the day.Acting is good. Casting is decent.The graphics are pretty OK.The backgrounds are great, leaving you submerged into a dark and creepy world. Most of the effects are decent, with a few glitches, and some poorly created CGI effects here and there.The soundtrack is unobtrusive, creating a good atmosphere. Sound effects are for the most part decent, but not good enough to bring on extra ambiance.I'll not recommend this movie to anyone. You might enjoy it on a lazy Sunday evening,  but do not expect anything exciting to happen.Best Regards Robert ToftePS.: While I do not dislike that Van Helsing has been turned from an elderly wise and knowledgeable man, into an younger and more action oriented hero. I DO dislike that they can't pronounce his name correct. The "V" in Van Helsing is pronounced as the German "V"(Fau), hence the name is pronounced Fan Helsing, but in the movie, everyone pronounces it as if it was an American name.

Review title: A Waste of time and money.
Review_body: This was not only a waste of $8.50 per ticket and my Sunday afternoon, it was a waste of Hollywood's cash and Hugh Jackman's time.There were more holes in this movie than Swiss Cheese.  It is one of the most poorly written scripts I think I have ever seen.  Nothing was developed well, be it the characters or the plot.  I wanted to leave after the first 30 minutes, but figured that it would get better.  Boy was I wrong.I can't say much about the actor's performances, because they were given so little to work with.  Roxburgh was the highlight of the film, as he was somewhat convincing given the script.I gave it 2 stars, and only because Kate Beckinsale and the vampire girls are smoking hot.

Review title: Don't waste your money or snooze time
Review_body: I dozed off twice in this one. The closing credits were as creative as the animation in the rest of the movie. The continuity was lacking in a number of scenes, which is critically important because of the constant jumping from human to animated action. The soundtrack was actually the best part of this movie. Acting was terrible. I kept being reminded of other movies' characteristics: aspects of James Bond and Alice in Wonderland; Wild, Wild West (failed attempts at interesting 19th-century technology) and Jumanji (CGA was outdated); Indiana Jones (anachronistic wisecracks), Frankenstein, and Young Frankenstein (an erudite monster). The main characters are all attractive but hardly three-dimensional, Save your $$$.

Review title: Wolf(erine) Man Jackman?...this one bites the silver bullet
Review_body: So the dialogue is canned, the story is lacking humor, and the direction is weak. I cant really blame the actors too much here you can tell its what they had to work with, but the whole movie takes itself too seriously for what would be, sans the budget, a B movie. These guys should have taken a cue from League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, another compilation of characters, that movie has a strong comic relief type character to balance all the unbelievable action, there was no relief here. Also it was hard not to make fun of the way too depressing Frankenstein. All and all this movie could have been done much better, but any time you have a writer, writing and directing, you are gonna lose perspective.I gave it a 2. And I usually give marks for special effects, but I even saw a group of 15 year old boys walk out of this movie.

I had great expectations of this film, and it delivered...to a degree.You will be shown fantastic looking creatures who make you wish you could play as in a game Van Helsing has a cool look with his full length leather coat and hat with an army of James Bond style weapons of an older age and references to classic horror fiends. And of course, shots of Kate Beckinsale's brilliantly formed ass in tights close up.However, the story does tend to bore after a while and you may find yourself fast forwarding to the fight scenes. And a lot of whining from Van Helsing's side kick who couldn't do a simple thing without first having a fit of fear before leaving it right to the last moment to do something.All in all, this was a good film but it could've been made a bit better in my opinion

Review title: A little bit too corny for my liking
Review_body:
***Warning--some spoilers...sort of***The movie ticket should have come with a complimentary glass of wine, with all the cheese we had to take with it.  Some scenes were more improbable than the Canucks chances of ever winning a Stanley Cup.  This movie seemed to have left over bits of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, and Hugh Jackman's role seemed almost exactly like his role of wolverine in X-men, complete with the nightmares about his hidden past and oh, the fact that he becomes a wolf too.  Is this a coincidence that this movie was filmed around the same time as X-2?  Maybe the scripts were accidentally mixed up while filming.
On the good side of the movie, the action in it was definitely entertaining, and I thought that the CGI was very impressive.  If you are just looking for a movie that's entertaining, has good action scenes, some pretty girls (like Josie Maran), and will give you a couple laughs, than see this movie.  If you want to see how a real vampire movie is made, go see Blade.
Rating: 6/10

Review title: A Real Treat - pay no attention to naysayers..!!
Review_body: Van Helsing is a wonderful popcorn movie, and you're bound to enjoy it if you're not going in looking to rip it to pieces. Like the previous Mummy movies, the plot is treacle...but with every corner there's a fantastic action sequence that goes on forever. The main thing with Van Helsing is that it makes no quips about what it is...and then the movie delivers in spades. A lot of spades. Saying that there is a tremendous action sequence every five minutes or so is not exaggerating..! There are plenty - plenty - of cool, elaborate battles, very well executed and shot beautifully. The film itself is absolutely gorgeous to look at - the scenery playing probably the most important role in the film. If you like Gothic, fog-enshrouded landscapes along the lines of Hammer films - then you're in for a treat. Van Helsing is set not only amongst a beautiful, beautiful backdrop of foggy landscapes...but also has a very nice nod to the old B&W Universal sets as well. The cinematography and scenery are worth the price of admission alone - for those with a classic eye. If you're trained in your classic horror films and literature, you're bound to appreciate the effort put into this piece a great deal more than someone who, say, was raised on Terminator and NFL. The negative word of mouth I've been hearing seems to be coming mainly from cultureless lunk-heads who haven't researched anything before 1977. Do not pay attention to them - Van Helsing is a real crowd pleaser, and an awful lot of work on every level went into this film. There's not only beautiful scenery and sets - the monsters are really gorgeous. The brides of Dracula are really something - and the battles with them are fantastic. The actors are all gorgeous, as well - but the director has a good eye for character...none of these people are good looking in your typical, bland, storefront means. They're lovely in the sense that they're people that you would genuinely be attracted and endeared to...rather than a flavorless sculpted Barbie or Ken. The writing allows for just a minimum of character development...but, honestly - it's just popcorn...and if you're looking for more than a great looking, high-flying action movie - then you're in the wrong seats. But - if you know what you're getting yourself into, and want to have an absolutely wild ride..! Van Helsing is a wonderful summer action movie...and good word should be spread about this baby, so we can at least get another one..! And by the way...the lusty soundtrack by Alan Silvestri is the very best movie music out there right now..! No kidding - the music is delectable. Most everything in Van Helsing works - just don't go in being a knob...or you're not gonna get it at all. It's a blast!

Review title: The Aussies were the best bit
Review_body: Going into this movie, i was extremely excited at the fact there were 3 fantastic and very talented australian actors in it. Being Australian myself i felt a sense of pride to see the movie due to an Australian having top billing in a hollywood blockbuster. And i must say if it wasn't for them i would not have made the effort. i saw the movie last night and was extremely disappointed with what i saw, visually it was a stunning movie, the cgi they used looked very good, but that all fell down at the fact that there was no story! if there was, i'm still trying to find it.The movie had a lot of monsters and characters with out really introducing them properly, and the audience was left wondering why they were in fact there. im still not sure what kate was doing there! i really didn't think that she fit in with the rest of the cast, also was she meant to have some sort of "super power" as she is the very slim figure of a women who gets the absolute s*** kicked out of her in some scenes and then she would jump up and run off with hardly a scratch???The three aussie boys, Hugh, David and Richard did very well and brought to life their characters even though they were written so badly. David as Carl was great, although if the character had of been written better there could have  been endless possibilities with what he could have done with it. For me Hugh Jackman was a stand out, this man is charming, he can act plus he can sing and dance like peter allen, all in all he is perfect! and the scene where he rips is shirt off, is a must see for any female!so overall i think this movie will go well in australia due to the casting, but i know that i would not have gone to see it if they weren't in it. 8/10 because of hugh, david and richard but take them out and it is about 5/10!

Review title: Meant to be a campy monster flick - and delivers!
Review_body: Van Helsing was never meant to be a world-shattering, ground-breaking feast of cinematic platinum by any stretch of the imagination. What it stood for was pure fun. Unfortunately, in this 'enlightened' day and age, a lot of people do seem to consider this idea somehow inferior and primitive."Fun?? Forsooth! Movies aren't supposed to be fun! What do you think this is, the entertainment industry?"This isn't one of the best movies ever made, nor is it among my all-time favourites. But I can watch it any time and still be entirely pleased by the time the amazingly spiffy credits roll around. You don't go to see a movie like this with the same standards in mind as going to see 'The Shawshank Redemption' or 'The Godfather', and nor should you judge and review it as such. I went into theatre with a taste for popcorn, iced tea, and campy thrills and got everything I wanted.One thing that got my attention was that it's clearly designed to be a throwback to the equally campy old B-horror movies of the 30s-50s, a genre I love. This is best showcased in the black and white prologue. And let's face it, those films aren't revered for their realism. The action was unlikely, to say the least, and to say the most, awesome! The dialogue was cheesy, but funny and enjoyable, and occasionally quite witty. The plot was suitably far- fetched. Overall the effects were breathtaking - seems to me that if someone hates a film they will automatically trash on the effects regardless of their quality. And the casting, regardless of what you thought of the performances, was next to perfect.So, if you want to see something that's going to make you think, ponder the human condition, take a reflective walk round the block, this film isn't for you. But if you want to curl up on the couch with your girlfriend and just watch a fun movie together, I'd wholeheartedly recommend Van Helsing!My humble opinion is yours for the taking.

Review title: What's worse than the storyline... it's the music!!
Review_body: Movies take a step to being a living entity with the music that is accompanying the play. If it's action, dramatic accords with a driving rhythm try to accelerate your heartbeat, if it is a love scene... (insert violins here...) and so on.Since this is a movie, that never really lets go of the action, the music seldom takes down a step from the dramatic rhythmic accords, but even when the scene suggests a breather... an example.The heroes ride across the country (insert sweeping helicopter shots like LOTR 1 - Fellowship here), lots of action (insert sarcasm here...), driving score... the heroes enter the Transylvanian village ("DOOM! DOOM!..." "DOOM! DOOM!..." "DOOM! DOOM!...") and get off their horses. (one more doom doom and I would have left the movie... in hindsight sitting through it was a mistake).I am normally a sucker for soundtracks and I own many of them, even though the movie itself is so-so ("Crimson Tide", "Waterworld" as examples for great scores accompanying mediocre flicks), but this score only detracts from the experience.

Review title: .:: Pointless action, uninteresting story, very linear ::.
Review_body: [May contain spoilers!]Very very weak and stupid. So many annoying points to mention, that it would be no fun to think about them again. To me it seemed to be a children's film. And it certainly would be one, if there weren't so many brutal scenes at all. The director mixed-up information about all kinds of creatures: vampires, werewolfs, frankenstein's monster, Dracula, jekyll & hyde  in the end, vampires are even killed by silver pegs, which are originally invented to kill werewolfs. Everytime monster-killer Val Helsing starts off to fulfil his orders, a whizz-kid provides him with the latest stuff to properly kill any evil creatures (like the supplier in James Bond films before every big task). This time Van Helsing leaves to get rid off the big boss' Dracula. Young amazon-lady Anna living in Transilvania carries out her duty to help him. There are a few problems like the people in town who were accomplished to being surrounded by vampires and not willing to support chaos, Frankenstein's monster being the target of Dracula due to the formula of endless life and Anna's brother mutating to a werewolf. But whatever may come into the way of Van Helsing seems to be no real problem, he simply rips it off. I rated it 3/10, because of the great surroundings and atmosphere in the film. This is really something mentionable: the special effects are quite good (but not well integrated into the film at all, unlike in the film Alien e.g.), the places and localities are somewhat interesting. Besides that, this film is a waste of time.

I watched Van Helsing after hearing a lot of critics about it. And I was really surprised ! Was the movie misunderstood ? I find it quite funny actually (the situation with Hyde/Jekyll is hilarious).I think most people thought it was going to be an adventure story, and that happens quite often. When you think a movie has a precise genre (adventure) and it turns out being more funny, you're disappointed. I had that with From Dusk Till Down, at first I thought it was going to be a kill, kill, kill movie and when those vampires arrived I just couldn't watch it anymore ! But after a year I "tried" to watch it again, knowing it had some fantastic spirit in it, and I really liked it. For those who didn't liked Van Helsing because it wasn't adventurous enough, try to watch it again and think about it as a comedy ! You'll really enjoy it (I hope so :)Morgie.

If you see the trailer, you see the whole idea of the movie. That may sound bad, but can be a good thing if you are into cartoony specialFX-ladden, none-to-serious action movies like Batman, LXG, The Mummy Returns or even the James Bond Franchise. Don't see this film for the plot, which is mediocre at best, just enough to carry the arrangement of specialFX. See it as a fun cartoon, only done with real-life actors instead (at least some, as at least 50% of the cast actually are CGI). One serious warning though: The film tries very hard to be cool, but often overdoes its own themes. Some scenes are just pure ridiculous and seem to be straight out of a spoof like Scary Movie, but generally the film is as much fun as a themepark ride capitalising on proven, non to surprising but well done shock and awe FX (I especially think that the Werewolfs were done very well, far better than in the horrendeous "Underworld"). On a special note, I have to say I liked the hints to H.Jackman's Wolverine Character in his Werewolf scenes (the claws, the bad temper...) Enjoy it, even if you just enjoy slacking about it with a friend you bring along...

Stephen Sommers should be found guilty of destroying, corrupting and ruining the most beloved movie monsters to walk across the screen.  My questions is how can somebody, who is educated, experienced in directing and writing, given a great cast and crew, completely destroy great fictional characters and absoulutly fail to tell a story.The only saving graces of the film (if it can be so called) it the great talent that the cast had to shove into thier roles.  And while I admit, the scenery looks good, the story will have you shaking your head.  The CGI was over the top (MORE HUGE JAW EFFECTS), the plot was empty, the twists were pointless and the changes to the "Dogma" of the Monster Characters irritating.Only Stephen Sommers could create this garbage.  I beg and plead anybody with the power, PLEASE MAKE HIM STOP!!!

I was disappointed. The plot tried to incorporate too much, and wound up failing in all respects. They go out of there way to incorporate most monster mythologies, but they are skewed, and don't really fit together well. Much of the plot, and character motivations don't make sense. Kate Beckinsdale's accent is mildly ridiculous, and I don't think she really pulls it off believably. Hugh Jackman, as always, is a pleasure, both in performance and and as scenery! There are a few humorous moments, but they often seem forced. And the female vampires are so over the top, and to take away from the movie. There were points that I couldn't wait for the scene to be over, and the stupidity to end. In all, the effects, costumes, and scenes look fantastic, but it is not enough to compensate for a bad plot and an uninspired script.

Well what can I say without feeling that I'm using too many words on a film that doesn't even deserve a mention? Any film that requires Hollywood actors to do Eastern European/Russian accents is bound to fail because, let's face it - nobody can pull off a convincing performance.The score is horrible, the characters are the kind you wish just want to die and the effects beg the question - if you can't get into a film because there is far too much noticeable CG, then why don't they make the whole thing CG?Of course, the hopes for this to succeed were non-existent ever since Stephen Sommers (Mummy, Mummy Returns, Mummy zzzzz) got his grubby little hands on the project. His direction sucks, his writing sucks - and he's done little more than wreck three decent actors, one decent actress and the entire monster list for Universal.The only purpose for recommending this film to you, would be to realize how hype can make a film seem promising. Take my advice, make a switch to Asian cinema and Anime. They can manage an original story, because this one sucks well before the Vampires show up.

I was really looking forward to this movie. Even with all the bad reviews, I thought it would be great! I was wrong.  Van Helsing was the most boring movie I have ever had to sit through.  The acting was horrible, even by Hugh Jackman.  My Grandma could've done a better job acting as one of Count Dracula's wives.Within the first half-hour, one of my friends was asleep. I ended up falling asleep for like 10 minutes, then waking up and falling back asleep.  All together I probably missed about a half-hour of the movie. I have never, ever, fallen asleep in a movie theater before...thats how boring this movie is!Van Helsing was horrible as a movie, but great as a nap-time! I give Van Helsing a 1/10.

Review title: Cinema goers have one name to fear...
Review_body: Ok, don't get me wrong, I love an expensive overblown Hollywood blockbuster when the time is right but this just isn't funny. What a waste! Hugh Jackman should be a huge star by now considering how he was plucked from near obscurity to be in the "X-Men" films, especially as he went on to steal them from under the noses of far more experienced actors. And when I think about the fact that Stephen Sommers career started out so wonderfully with the near genius film "Deep Rising" ("What are you looking at?") and has gone downhill so much I almost cry. I have to say, if it wasn't for the fact that I'm in love with Kate Beckinsale I would've walked out of this film... and I've never walked out of a film in my life. And I go to the cinema about 60 times a year; so there! Just to rant a bit more: I bet this film gets better reviews and better receipts than last year's "The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" even though it borrows heavily from it and has half the wit of that film. OK, rant over. I'm just a bit drunk but really more than a bit disappointed. Kate Beckinsale is fantastic though isn't she..?

I went to this film expecting some really cool and atmospheric vampire slaying action; though I did expect not a masterpiece at all, I was badly disappointed.Actually, I'm not quite sure if this movie is meant to make fun of itself or not, for there are many scenes with obvious jokes (which are basicly very flat) but as the scene continues I often believed it to be meant serious, but this was the actual fun part, because all scenes are so overloaded with computer generated effects, bad acting, flat jokes, "fortuities", prejudices and sterotypes (mixed all fantasy myth stereotypes in a very postmodern way (e.g. Dracula, Werewolves, Mr. Hyde, Frankenstein)) that it caused almost a physical pain in me by merely watching those scenes.During the whole movie there was no suspense created at all, the happy end was foreseeable all the time. Especially the last scene was badly overdone and tawdry.This is not the kind of vampire movie I like (and I do like vampire movies). If you have a certain pretence to a movie, don't pay for seeing this one. If you are drunk and want to have some fun, it'd probably be ok. I really kind of despise this film.

when i was a kid, other children used to tease me because i liked sf, fiction and adventure movies. they thought my favourite movies were naive, silly and childish, instead preferring hard core action and car movies. 15 years later, after watching, one after the other, blockbusting but lousy titles like x men (pt 1 and 2), hulk, or mummy (pt. 1 and 2), now joined by this ridiculous van helsing stuff, i must finally admit that the other kids were right. these movies suck, and they suck big time! van helsing is idiotic special effect roller coaster ride, with characters which would not fit even into a cartoon, worst "mix it all up and swallow" script of all times, and boring over-excessive non stop action and stunts, which made me unsure where is the beginning, and when will finally come the culmination of this embarrassment of a film.

Review title: By far - Not the Movie to 'Kickoff the Summer'
Review_body: Well, this happens to me only once in awhile. I decide to see a 'Blockbuster' movie on opening day. Problem is that I don't have a chance to assess creditable reviews on media blitzed Hollywood movies, which exaggerates false promise and almost always disappointswith few exceptions (i.e. Spiderman 1, Gladiator).Van Helsing was no-exception. This was out write terrible. I guess this could have been my fault. I new the direction the movie was headed. A Stephen Sommers (The Mummy) directed, PG 13 rated, summer blockbuster that needs to cover its cost by grabbing the widest possible audience. Lets make a vampire movie for the family, so to speak. OK, with that said, I will expect a fast action, corny (yet sometimes funny) dialog, computer animated joy ride. If this is your cup-of-tea, then the 'formula was there.' However, the movie lacked all the major support elements. The story was muddy and boring. What was Dracula's end result? Gremlin babies to fly around and do what, torment the world. This was never really clarified for me. Besides why in the world would Dracula want to create little gremlin vampires when he has an endless count of full grown, equally as menacing vampires chilling at his masquerade. If death by a certain creature were the only way to destroy Dracula, then why wouldn't he eliminate or keep the threat as far away as possible??? There are many questions like these you'll be asking yourself during and after the movie. Like, what happened to the original ware wolf, and did they literally bite that idea from Blade 2 (you'll understand when you see the movie).Maybe the Friar Carl played by David Wenham (Lord of the Rings), would have been a nice comic relief but the exhausting vibe of the rest of the movie absorbed any liking one could have for the witty Friar. In fact, all characters were boring; I don't care how good they looked. Kate's character had fluctuations in her accent. Hugh's character has flat. Dracula had a clip in his hair, and the women vampire's were sexy, but unnecessarily screamed and wined. I could care less what happened to the characters in the end. It turned out to be comical and I just wanted the movie to conclude.Kate and Hugh are terrific actors; they are both attractive and have immense screen presence. Putting Kate (the Vampire movie lover) aside, I'm extremely disappointed in Hugh. I don't expect him to pick up the slack for a horrific screenplay, but I do expect him to make better decisions in the future. I have no problem if Hugh is chasing money and popularity, but at least set a standard for movie selections. This is your first big mistake 'Hollywood Hugh,' please don't make another, at least not anytime soon. I'd hate to compare your movie selections to your Aussie counter part Heath Ledger.I was hoping to see a different movie here, one for adults or the less squeamish child. I needed Van Helsing to follow along the lines of 'Allen Hughes's From Hell,' 'Bram Stoker's Dracula,' and/or Sleepy Hollow. These movies were dark and had an eerie feeling. They as well as director M. Night Shyamalan prove that subtle suggestions and a brilliant story can have a greater effect, then CG and overwhelming media hype. I hope this movie isn't an inclination of this summer's silver screen newbies. I'm very skeptical of 'Troy' and 'Spiderman.' However, I'm extremely excited about the Village.

Review title: Van HELLYES!!! Not bad at all!
Review_body: I was very skeptical of this film since the reviews I read on IMDb were well, not very good. Then I got to thinking about Hugh Jackman in all his sexiness slaying monsters and I thought, "Hey, why the hell not?" And as it turns out, it was a pretty good film. Will Hugh be up for an Oscar any time soon? No..but it was entertaining all the same and it was worth the $4.50 I paid to see it. He delivered quite the performance and Kate Beckinsale did well too. I didn't feel that is was drawn out and boring like some of the reviews had said. I felt it was entertaining the whole way through and I liked that the whole movie wasn't exactly based on slaying and that it had aspects of romance and friendship as well. I give it 8* out of 10* and I would recommend seeing it. All in all, to me, Van Helsing was more like Van HELLYES!

Review title: A Movie You Can Only See Once
Review_body: I remember when I first heard of this movie. It looked great because: 1. I thought Frankenstien's monster might be a bit scary. At least a BIT. - Wrong 2. I thought that Hollywood would finally steer away from those annoying vampire legends (sunlight, garlic, holy water...), and come up with something inventive and realistic - Wrong I have seen worse movies, true, but this was terrible. I've seen it a load of times, because I couldn't really say "no" to friends who had lowered it down to Van Helsing and The Day After Tomorrow (which was one of those "worse movies").I agree with everyone's thoughts on Anna's accent; very annoying. I understand that she needed the accent because of where she was from (Transylvania), but the story, really, would have made more sense with more of a dark, travelling heroine. A woman who has been running from her hunters for many years, a woman who has seen he friends and family die in the snow, a woman who has escaped death by inches. We got a local.Jackman, overall, did his job - he wasn't that bad. No overacting, a traditional angry character, and a decent accent. I should say that I didn't like the religious aspect of his personality (I won't spoil the movie, but once the truth about him was revealed to me, it blew the movie), but, I suppose, that's just a point of view.I HATED the vampire women. The overacting they did made me wish for the movie to end quickly, because with all that screaming, crying and groping around Dracula, I just wanted to be sick with embarrassment. "I spent nine bucks to hear a bunch of bad actresses scream their way through the auditions?" Frankenstein's character was boring, period.The movie followed that same pattern with the werewolf: Becomes human again; tries to tell heroine/hero the truth about himself/his master; then suddenly becomes a werewolf - very predictable.With a very predictable storyline and unoriginal characters, this movie blew it. It had great potential, but just turned out to be another "League of Extraordinary Gentlemen". It's fun to watch the first time, but you'll find yourself strumming your fingers and checking your watch every other time you watch it. NOT something to buy.

Review title: story baaaaaad. story stinks! but nice special effects
Review_body: Saw this movie tonight. That is properbly the worst story i've ever encountered in a movie. It's tring to mix _a lot_ of different myths and legends together in one movie.BAD idea!!!! From the very start it is clear that this story sucks! The two stars i'm giving it is for the impressing special effects. If you, like me, like the old stories, then do not go se this movie as it totally f***s them up. two stars from me.

Review title: Do not deride this movie for being enjoyable...
Review_body:
Van Helsing is, if nothing else, thoroughly enjoyable. No one in their right mind would have gone in expecting 'Interview with the Vampire.' This is, in truth, an action movie - and the plot reflects that. It is there, undeniably, to feed the action.And the action is good. The special effects are a bit cheesy at points (the brides-of-Dracula in flight, for instance), but it evokes adrenaline. It is fun to watch! What could be more important in a movie, really?
Now, this may destroy any credibility that I still have in the minds of some, but I also liked The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen - for similar reasons. Van Helsing is like LXG on steroids: better effects, better plot (admittedly, that is not saying much), and - most importantly - even more monsters. It is like a fun ride at an amusement park.

Review title: This one did NOT live to it's expectations
Review_body: I loved Stephen Sommer's "The Mummy" and I liked the sequel. This movie however, are among the worst films I've seen this decade. The worst acting comes from Richard Roxburgh (Count Dracula) and his three wives(?) they overact and can't seem get one sentence right.I can't understand why Sommer could cast these people, maybe the budget went to the effects (which aren't too lame, but not as good as in "the mummy"). Sometimes in the movie they have parts that just don't belong or make any sense, It just takes up time. Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale do what you expect of them, the're good and true to their characters. I sure hope they don't make a sequel out of this one, but if they do, I hope Hugh makes the right decision of passing on it.

Review title: A Very, Very, Very, Very Good Film!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Review_body: The people that commented on here thought Van Helsing was a terrible and horrible movie were wrong. I liked how all of the universal monsters came back to the big screen including Dr. Jekell/Mr. Hyde. Count Dracula was awesome. I liked his accent. The Frankenstein Monster was awesome. I liked how he was put together. The Wolf man and other werewolves were awesome. I was surprised Van Helsing became a werewolf.Jackman was awesome playing Van Helsing. There would of been no one better. THE MUSIC WAS AWESOME!!!!!! This was the 4th time that Dracula, Frankenstein Monster, and The Wolf Man was in the same film.They were in only  House of Frankenstein, House of Dracula, Bud Abbott and Lou Costello Meets Frankenstein, and Van Helsing. Almost everybody i talked to loved this movie.I didn't like Kevin J. O'connor as Ygor. (Bela Lugosi is the only good Ygor). That's the only thing i disliked. I had no favorite part it was all good. I like who the begging was black/white. Awesome film!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This just felt like an "ehh" kinda movie. There were so many special effects that I felt that the theater seats should have moved around, like in those amusement park rides. Dracula's wives were, IMO, the WORST part of this movie. I've seen better acting in high school plays. Campiness is good at times but they were beyond campy to being just dreadful. And those things that help Dracula, whatever they're called, looked like evil, demented Umpa Loompas. And Igor just had a horrible make-up job. And this Mr. Hyde business, can anyone say Shrek rip off?Okay, now to what I liked. Yes, shocker, I liked parts of this movie. The score was THE BEST part. While I may never buy the movie I'm seriously considering purchacing the music. I also liked the camp, when it was done well. But I found myself laughing in weird places.
*SPOILER*
I couldn't help it when Kate Beckinsale's character dies. The howl of the wolfman/Van Helsing just made me giggle. I thought it was incredibly funny. I don't know why.
*END SPOILER*
AND I liked Hugh Jackman although his accent threw me. I wasn't sure if he was trying to go for German or English or what. I've heard people say Kate's accent was bad, I think his was worse. Ah, but I didn't mind the way he looked. That HAIR! *faint* It's funny that anyone who had good hair never seemed to mess it up. Again, camp. Too bad there wasn't more of it, the movie would have been better. Campiness is what makes the Mummy good and that's why I like it. This movie just didn't seem to have enough or the camp it had just didn't seem to fit.IMO, this movie gets a 5.5 out of 10. It wasn't horrible but it wasn't great either.

Review title: no one knows how to kill Dracular.
Review_body: This story is set in Transylvania where the people have been terrorised by all kinds of evil creatures and monsters. But above all these is the deadly count Dracular. For four hundred years the Valerius family have protected their country from the vampire and his three brides. At the beginning of the story, King Boris Valerius has been missing for twelve months. When Velkan Valerius is turned into a were wolf only Princess Anna Valerius is left. Because of a promise made to the gods four hundred years ago, if Dracular isn't killed before Anna dies, no member of the Valerius family will enter heaven. Only one can vanquish Dracular before it is too late. Van Helsing. But can the pair save the world again? I would recommend this film to anyone looking for adventure.

I must admit that the lukewarm reviews here where rather discouraging to me, notwithstanding I watched it today (08 May 2004)and found it really entertaining.I believe it is somewhat underrated here so far. May be the expectations were too high. To me if we avoid comparisons to the Mummy or the Indiana Jones movies "Van Helsing" could be enjoyed on its own merit. It is, certainly, not a classic (some more humour would have done substantial impact in this regard) but still it worths watching. It is not overloaded with thought provoking sequences, while the action scenes are both dynamic and surprising. Altogether...enjoyable. 7/10

Stephen Sommers is a pretty tongue-in-cheek guy. In case you hadn't noticed. Van Helsing is high-camp, high-action, high-effects, and utterly, utterly fabulous. If you want to see a cunning, suspenseful horror, then go watch Ringu. This isn't it. This is a way fun, high-octane monster romp with delightfully god-awful accents -- don't take it too seriously, because none of the cast or crew have. They're all way too busy having fun.I'm not going to go over the plot -- there isn't all that much of it to go around anyway, and you already know as much as you need to just from the title and the main image.Oh, and look out for the guy who played Beni from The Mummy... :)

Hollywood blockbuster summer has started undoubtfully with this over produced CGI catch me if you can scramble of x-men and spider-man.A big production without a doubt. How could it not be?5 Months of shooting and 9 months of cgi post production, this is ought to be a blow your ass of your seat rollercoast ride, right? Wrong!Looking at great trailers that have been released I barely couldn't wait to see if they've outdone themselfs by putting something commercial but nevertheless GOOD on the screen. As I've seen a pre-screener last night I can tell that the trailers aren't the best this movie had to offer. CGI-wise this is big fun. The movie starts out with this black and white sequence that ends up in an old windmill which I couldn't help to remind me to the Sleepy Hollow windmill scene. However, from this point on the movie just didn't slow down actionwise. It was fast, kept on going, looked really great and sounded even greater. A really amazing soundtrack with some catchy tunes danced 'round and 'round in my ears wich made this movie into a fairly enjoyable piece of expensive FUN.As expensive as all of this might be I think they saved a lot plotwise. The story is like 'Dracula for dummies'. Thinking that Spider-man had a lame storytelling I didn't think they could go even more wrong with this, but guess who got it all wrong? That's right, it was me.Don't expect to much when you go and check this out, but allow yourself to sit back, don't ask any questions, and enjoy this amusing ride. I wouldn't say it's flawless or great, but it's not bad either...my scores:plot: 2/10 fun: 8/10 effects: 8/10 soundtrack: 9/10 total: 7/10

It's as if Stephen Sommers wanted to do a Dr. Eldritch movie without violating copyright laws, so he picked a monster hunter in the public domain!    But this Van Helsing has received a modern upgrade: He's stylish, supercharged, fast and loud.  To make it fair, Sommers has done the same with the monsters he battles (their lumbering counterparts from the 30's wouldn't have stood a chance).  Just like James Bond, Van Helsing roams internationally, fights evil, uses specially-designed gadgets from his techo-geek friend, and wins over the voluptuous love-interest, all at a breathless speed.  The film hardly pauses for some perfunctory back-story and character development, hurtling from one melee to the next.  In keeping with the breakneck pacing and dizzying visuals, the thundering score makes a full-throated `Carmina Burana' sound like an Enya CD.  If you love fast, loud, mindless summer movies teeming with CG monsters, this is a film for you!  If you can't stand sketchy characters, plot holes, or period anachronisms, you should probably pass on `Van Helsing.'

I personally found the movie too long and overall disappointing.Hugh Jackman from X-Men is completely wasted in this movie. I found him excellent in X-Men movies: here he does his best but his performance gets diluted in the poor quality of movie (read below).Kate Beckinsale "acted" or better, after seeing Underworld where she was fairly good, she was not at all properly directed.The script and dialogs were also lame and overall there is a lack of tension and involvement you would expect in a movie like this (at least as it is presented from the trailer). Moreover, it tried to be funny, but as I said, it tried...If it was really funny and ironic (a la Charlie's Angels) it would have been much much better. Some actors and vampires speak with a supposedly Transylvanian accent - they could have spared us that - quite useless.Special mention to David Wenham from LOTR: he was really good and funny - wasted as well like Hugh and unfortunately has a too a smaller role in the movie.Directing was not really good and wasted all the money and special effects (quite good) used in the movie. The plot is a transposition of Underworld (2003)...is about the SAME story just brought back to 19th century with the added (and to me completely useless) icon of Frankenstein...I will not buy the DVD. Disappointing. 4/10.

Review title: Probably the worst movie since Battlefield Earth.
Review_body: Probably the biggest mistake most people make is excusing crap action movies, as "popcorn" or "mindless" flicks. Wrong. Bad movies are bad because they are badly made. Van Helsing prompted me to register on this site because my disgust could not be contained. This movie is utter crap.Lets do a rundown. Van Helsing (Hugh Jackman, again, doing a moody, withkept ragged drifter character) is a monster slayer. He travels around Europe, with the support of the Vatican(?), getting rid of those that are deemed evil. After defeating one of these creatures (Dr. Jekyl, in a completely dumbed down, and, unfortunately, one of the better fight scenes in the whole movie), he is sent off to kill the ellustrious Dracula (Played melodramically by Richard Roxbury). Along for the ride is a no-name actor friar, as he repeatedly liked to be regarded, supplying such 19th centure weaponry as an automatic crossbow and a light grenade (anyone who DIDNT see when this would be used deserved to be shot), and awful "comic" relief.We're treated to about 10 seconds of backstory, which is just to introduce Kate Beckansale as the helpless heroine, and we're off on a ride of plot holes, bad CGI (except for the werewolves), horrible scriptwriting and just as horrible directing. Besides ripping off every single classic monster movie ever made, Director Sommers managed to turn the stuff he stole into complete dredge. One liners like "We transelvians tend to see the bridge side of death" and "She's DEAD" occupy the intelligence of 95% of anything said. It's all cringeworthy. As the movie wears on, fight scenes are repeated over and over again. The evil deeds, in which Dracula and his 3 wives (screeching away) wish to re-populate their dying kind, are repeated. Twice. We've never told why they need to electrocute wearwolves to do it, nor why Frankensteins monster, but they do. Twice.We also see our heroes plummit through walls, bounce off trees (without as much as a scratch), swing on ropes far, far too much, and manage to accomplish jumps and flips that would make the chinese midget from "Oceans Eleven" look impressed. But I'll be fair. The production values were enormous, and the sets, costumes and some of the CGI look fantastic. But thats it, they only look fantastic, when put into practical use, you can almost see the $130 million fall down the drain.I won't bother to go into any more of the movie's "story", since there isn't much more to say. The so called "surprises" are rolled over by explosions so you won't notice them, what happens to Kate Beckansale is simply retarded, and the ending is nothing short of, well, lame. Which, co-incidentally, sums up the entire movie.All in all, save your money. Do not see this movie. Do not even rent it. Instead, rent out some of the classics like "Dracula" and "Frankenstein" that this movie shameless tries to rip off. They may not be modern, but they are a hell of a lot better then this piece of commercially manufactured dredge.

I, apparently like many moviegoers this weekend, had high expectations of this film.  It took all of 25 minutes into `Van Helsing' before I knew that I had made a titanic mistake.  Horrible CG, atrocious dialogue, slightly better than amateurish acting, and a totally predictable plot made this the worst movie that I have seen in at least a year.From the opening battle, though the ridiculous boxing match between good and evil near the end, the viewer is subjected to constant cartoon-like CG which made the monsters only slightly more realistic than a good Xbox game and far less frightening.  Even if I had been able to get around the action scenes-which seemed to always include someone falling from an absurd height, controlled by a series of impossible flipping maneuvers, and saved by a last minute grasp on a rope or a ledge-I could not forgive this film for ruining our classic monsters.  Dracula, by the way, was the least scary example of the character that has ever been seen. For me, bad accents ruin a movie as quickly as anything else. Most of the action in this movie takes place in east Europe creating an obvious need for actors who sound, oh, eastern European.  Here too `Van Helsing' falls way short of the mark. Kate Beckinsale (Anna), though stunningly beautiful in her early 21st century black tights, caused my ears to ache whenever she spoke.  Though not accurate, it may have been less intrusive if the director had made her speak with her native English accent.  Dracula (Roxburgh) was simply unable to render anything remotely passable.  The rest of the characters were so thinly defined and poorly acted that one soon loses interest in them or what they are saying anyway. Finally, though the story is illogically convoluted and poorly conceived, the viewer never wonders what's going to happen next since everything is given away before it happens.  About halfway through, the ending is spelled out right in front of the viewer and I still have no idea how so little story was stretched to two and a half hours.  My standard for a good story line is asking myself `Could I have written this?' If the answer is `Yes' the movie is a stinker....`Yes'A generous 4/10.

Review title: The first movie I fell asleep during... EVER!
Review_body: There's no doubt about it, Van Helsing is the type of movie you go to see if you are extremely bored and need mindless entertainment. With that being said, you will only get this mindless entertainment if you are mindless...Being a big fan of classic horror tales, I feel this movie butchered the awesome stories that it takes characters from. Do I think the idea was bad? Not at all, in fact, I think Stephen Sommers had an incredible idea for this movie, but it wasn't pulled off. The animation wasn't believable in the least, and the acting (with exception of Jackman) was disturbingly bad. Not giving much away, there is a scene where a womans brother dies, and the only form of sadness she can show is a slight frown. I honestly don't plan on seeing this movie again... except maybe to see the 5 minutes I zoned out.

Review title: I'd really like to punch Steven Sommers!
Review_body: How many production errors can you have in one movie? One second he's got dripping, saturated  hair.. the next it's puffy and drying! She kisses Dracula with her really glossy red lips and not one spec of the gloss is left on him! Dracula asks the guy whose family was murdered by him to join him, and all he says is "I'd rather die and than join you!" talk about stating the obvious! The guy sees his fathers dead-for-a-year-or-more corpse and all he says is "NOOOOO!!!" no crying or anything... but then again.. he's been dead FOR A YEAR!!Suffice to say, that's the worst movie Hugh Jackman has ever done. Main role or not, that's a big bad chunk out of his popularity meter.

Review title: Silly fairy tale with too many special effects
Review_body: I thought this movie was a bit too stupid. It's just not my taste... I only went because my wife likes this kind of movies. And, my God, what did they do to Kate Beckinsale?? In Serendipity she was such a sweet girl, and here she looked like a baywatch babe wearing a corsette and 15 layers of makeup. The way she was doing that accent was horrible: i guess it's not her fault, it just doesn't suit her. In general, her persona would fit better for romantic flicks or even serious dramas, but not for a$$-kicking dominatrix type roles. If not for Hugh Jackman, this movie would be absolutely and utterly pitiful, but he saved it just by his presence. Hope KB doesn't wind up doing this kind of movies permanently.

The acting in the movie was great. :)  Not to mention I'm a big Hugh Jackman fan (grin)But seriously, I really did enjoy the Hugh's portrayal of Van Helsing, especially his sarcastic wit.However, I made the mistake of watching this from the front row right after getting new glasses.  For, as wonderful as I liked the acting, the humor (even a hint of a wolverine joke here and there) I felt the action was too "busy".  I'm not saying I don't like action, but it felt like there was just too much at once, so instead of concentrating and getting pumped up by the action, I tended to blank out a little from it.Personally, if it was up to me, there'd have been a little less action, and a little more about Van Helsing's past.There was however one part of the movie I felt was useless.  Do we really need to see a Friar having sex?  Sure, it was just hinted at (them waking up together, basically clothed) but enough already. GAK.

Review title: Don't waste your time and money on this dud.
