Review title: Amazing what special effects does for people.......
Review_body: After reading most of the people that say this is an "awesome" movie I find it hilarious how people get awed by special effects. The movie itself was just OK. Sure special effects are hard but they shouldn't make a movie good or "awesome". I was hoping a lot better of a movie. Acting was nothing special, plot sucked, and some moments that were suppose to scare people actually made me laugh... (like when Dracula screamed at his brides) Only decent part of the film was the special effects. Everything else was lacking. I left the theatre thinking that movie sucked. There is a lot missing in this movie. If the movie is so amazing might as well buy it on DVD instead of paying $16 bucks and the theatre and another $20 for the DVD.....

Review title: Is it too trite to say that this movie sucks?
Review_body: While I can't say I'd nominate the leads in this film for Academy awards in their previous roles, (XMen & Underworld) I did enjoy those films. Ditto both Mummy films, which I thought were carried more by the cast's charisma than the FX or the less than stellar writing. So I was optimistic about this film.I hate it when I'm disappointed. This film has very few redeeming qualities. I had thought that the second Mummy film had pushed the cartoonish action limit about as far as it could go. Wrong, it can go farther, but it shouldn't have.This film would have been much BETTER if they had spent $50M less on FX and $100K more on a single talented writer. And the same amount on nearly any other director.This completely cliché', wholly unoriginal and derivative weird mishmash of steam punk, vampire, werewolf, James Bond and superhero film is ... a mishmash. It has all the appeal of a cold plate of goulash combined with cabbage and ice cream, all topped with mustard.So, given its name, I think one can best sum up this film by saying, it sucked!

Review title: Horrific script. Nice sets. Mainly rubbish.
Review_body: How not to make film: 1. Inherit stable of well loved horror characters from Universal, each with their own fascinating (literary and cinematic) heritage and decide to throw them all into a film. Sounds promising....2. Ditch virtually all the well established lore and tradition surrounding these characters in favour of stupid unsatisfying premise and threadbare plot. 3. Receive 200 million dollar budget and decide to spend *all* of it on special effects. 4. Ask video game designers to come up with a dozen or so set-piece action sequences(shooting vampires with repeat action crossbow, swinging from rope to rope, obligatory coach-and-horses 'driving section'). Base entire film around these. 5. Cobble together a "story" that attempts to fill in the occasional few minutes between these action scenes with some sort of coherent narrative. Fail. Badly. 6. Realize story is so bad that film is actually a comedy. Sprinkle disastrous hotch-potch of story with lame attempts at humorous one liners. 7. Add 'comedy sidekick' character in vain attempt to distract audience from gaping holes in plot. 8. Add Kate Beckinsale in tight black trousers for same reason. 9. Demand all actors speak in a ridiculous "generic foreign accent" for that 'school play' hammy feel. 10. Throw in a few references to other films (Bond, X Men) etc. in final desperate attempt to engage audience interest.I genuinely feel sorry for the art designers on this film. They came up with some very impressive and visually stunning sets, only to see them employed in the service of a truly rubbish, rubbish story. Dracula had all the menace and charisma of an insurance salesman, and Van Helsing himself looked mostly bored. The only character with any semblance of interest was a sympathetic portrayal of Frankenstein's monster. Stephen Sommers needs to watch a few decent films, and take notes on how they establish and build characters and construct a narrative (almost any Spielberg would prove very instructive). Spewing out a dumb action film for yeah-haaah simple-minded teens with no attention span is soiling the horror canon. Please don't let this man direct or write anything else till he's at least mastered some of the basics of making a film, rather than "some stuff that will look good in the trailer".

Review title: You have to see it to believe it!
Review_body: I was skeptical about this movie from the very beginning. All of my fears and trepidation were soon allayed. This movie is great! It has action, special effects and it keeps you interested. Universal did a wonderful job bringing the gruesome threesome back for a modernized "period" piece. Hugh Jackman is great as Van Helsing and Kate Beckinsale is always a pleasure to behold. If you are a fan of the old Universal monster movies you should enjoy this one with out a doubt. I know I will be looking forward to the sequel! Another topic of interest is this movie was made by the same people that did the two recent Mummy movies....you will also note a couple of the supporting actors from those movies have roles in this movie. See if you can spot them.

Review title: Werewolves, vampires and lots of monsters.... Yep it's a B-movie
Review_body: First of all, I don't write many reviews. I only do the best movies...or the worst, So give me a break, it is just my point of view.Hugh Jackman is Van Helsing, a badass dude who travels around the globe to kill everything that has to do with evil. He has been sent to transylvania to kill Dracula that has been tormenting the country for centuries. Of course, things become complicated when he has to handle werewolves and a 500 pound Frankenstein. Owkay, this movie IS the badest movie of 2004. There is nothing good to say about Van Helsing. Bad sfx, lousy acting, and a plot that even the biggest moron would figure out. When you hear that Stephen Sommers is the director you always have to be very careful. We know that he likes to make popcorn movies like the mummy 1 and 2 and deep rising. So after the ridiculous mummy returns you should have been warned. Van Helsing is like a bad roller-coaster trip that lasts for two hours and when you finally get off you have the feeling that you wanna throw up. As for the special effects? My god, they are absolutely horrible. When Dracula's brides fly off, or when a man turns into a werewolf or even Mr. Hyde, you feel that there is something missing. They actually spend 160 million dollars and they didn't have decent sfx. What a waste.And how about the acting? Well there is not much to say about that either. It's completely rubbish and you will never believe that Kate Beckinsale is a roemanian (xcuse me for the spelling) gipsie. "He is the firrrrst one to kill a vampirrre overrr a hunderrred yearrr, I say let's buy him a drrrink". Yeah, Swallow that! As for Richard Roxburgh and Hugh Jackman...Guys what were you thinking? Conversations turn to the worst and the one-liners are really laughable.So now, you know. This is crap. Do not buy this movie, do not even rent this movie, do not watch it while you're drunk or stoned. Forget it, it will only be a waste of money. My star rating: 1 out of 5 p.s. I didn't say anything about the plot c'ause there isn't any.

**Some Spoilers**£5.80 that's a small fortune. There are several different things I could have spent this amount of money on, maybe a burger king meal, a paperback novel, a small amount of petrol, a large bag of jelly bellys, a fun fest in my local arcade or even some cotton wool to stuff in my mouth, eyes, ears and bum. All the above would have been more fun than Hugh Jackmans whack movie.Van Helsing is about the famous vampire hunter and his efforts to beat up Dracula and his cronies. Jackman play the rough tough vampire hunter, Richard Roxburgh plays Count Dracula and Kate Beckinsale plays a pair of breasts also known as Anna Valerious the female sidekick of Van Helsing. Also to mix it up a bit is David Wenham of the Lord of the Rings fame as the Q of the catholic world, oh how the mighty have fallenBasically the movie is about Jackman running off to Transylvania to kill off Dracula and save the world from all things undead. It's about two or three hundred years ago and old helsing is running around with laser guided crossbows and other ridiculous gadgets supplied by the lumbering monk David Wenham. When they get there it turns out Dracula's causing trouble, putting cats up trees and other minor offenses. On comes a battle with Dracula's three ladies at the night who attack in the afternoon. What results from this is a battle between Hugh Jackman and three goofy bat girls with big teeth. To make sure he takes these flying money-grabbers down to funky town he uses his ultra automatic crossbow which according to the manufacturers guide will 'Pin a donkey to a fence in seconds'. A ba-gillion bolts are sent shooting in every direction and before you can even say 'CGI-Fest' the fight is over. As the film goes on it turns out there is actually a reason for Frankensteins monster, wolfman and Dracula to be in one movie and it isn't a good one. So let me try to unfold this twisty and very stupid plot, Dracula needs Frankenbolts to somehow give life to his off-spring and wolfman is there to ermm, hmm I forgot. Anyway, Dracula wants to take over the world, yeah that's it! Take over the worldThis film boosts a massive budget, the amount of money that funds a small countries civil war! $4000 billion dollars last I heard, and it amazes me how a studio can throw so much money in the direction of such a idiotic project. Even more reason to fear this movie as an entertaining item is the fact that it's directed by Stephen Sommers of the dire 'Mummy movie's'. Oh god, this movie was never gonna be good.As I previously mentioned the film is a CGI fest, there are so many computer enhanced graphics in this movie that it's rumored that Jackman didn't move his arms during the shoot because it would have been more expensive and a cool fact to create CGI arms. Given the huge budget it would have been safe to assume that the CGI would at least be good to look at, but even this fails. The special effects range from pants to plain over-the-top, right up to Frankensteins neon head!This movie just sucks, it's Hollywood crud super-sized! The budget to stupid, the plot is even stupider and it's so over the top and as unbelievable as Big Dave tidying his room. I generally hated this movie and found it too hard not to laugh out loud at the dire dialogue and silly effects. I spent most of my time in the cinema making jokes at the films expense and counting the sweets in my bag.A classic example of Hollywood throwing stupid amounts of money into a crap summer blockbuster. No brains or good looks, this puppy doesn't have much going for it.

Van Helsing, the arch-nemesis of Dracula, is reincarnated in this sloppy movie as a Victorian James Bond whose job is to be an all-purpose monster killer for the Vatican. Sounds bad? It's worse than that.As bad an idea as this is, it is poorly executed, with dreadful dialogue, underdeveloped characters, and computer generated monsters that are scary...not!The story is heavy on action, but since we don't really care about the characters, the villains are camp rather than menacing, and the suspense (it there is any) is constantly undermined by hamfisted attempts at humour (not funny) none of it counts for much. Which just about sums up the film.

Review title: The producers of this film should be shot.
Review_body: I was in total shock at what i had just witnessed when the film was over. It was a mess. The action was directed awfully and the story was told very poorly. The pacing of the film seems to try to intentionally swallow up the boring story that sets at the base of the film. Hugh Jackman (which i don't like that much anyway) is dreadful as van helsing. They've turned him into neo from the matrix. I mean 21st century weaponry in the 19th century, come on! Kate Beckinsale who was great in "Underworld" (even though that wasn't the best movie) was very stale in this role. She almost seems to be auditioning for the part of frankenstein in the film.The ultimate poor excuse for a performance in this film belongs to Richard Roxonbourgh who plays count Dracula. He plays Dracula with a coe sense of fun, but it's not fun. In fact it's the fartherest thing from fun. He parades around with no emotional control and delivers his "Wonderful" dialogue. He changes shapes and acts a little too femine at times as well. Enough said about the acting either that or my head will implode. Well at least the special effects were great, right? NNNNNNNNNNNNNOOOOOOOOOOOOPPPPPPPPPPEEEEEEEEEEEEE!God these effects were freaking terrible. Why cgi everything? Why not go back to the great films of the 30's and 40's. Like "Frankenstein vs The Wolf Man", that was a classic piece of storytelling and the acting and special effects are great. Well oh well Hollywood has managed to squander another great idea.

Review title: No academy award performances here, but a great film nonetheless.
Review_body: If you're looking to see great acting, this is not the film for you. It is done rather tongue in cheek and has some very funny moments. But what makes this film so interesting and entertaining is the breathtaking special effects and superb action. While to some viewers it may be flawed (for example the leading lady's hair is always perfect despite many altercations and assaults!), those of you who, like me, prefer to just sit back and enjoy as opposed to judging won't be disappointed. The vampires are the best yet, depicted with awesome detail and move about like nothing you've ever seen in vampire movies. Hugh Jackman (Dr. Van Helsing) is great for the part and Kate Beckinsale (Anna) looks terrific. The camera angles are spectacular and that combined with great action sequences keeps the movie moving at a perfect pace. If you get bored, you'd better stick to dramas and to those who feel they have to pan it, lighten up will ya! This movie does not take itself seriously, nor should you. It's just great fun and one heck of a roller coaster ride!!

Review title: The biggest movie disappointment in a century
Review_body: I had heard some not very flattering things about this title, but thought I'd give it a chance on DVD.Together with a friend - who like me is also a big fan of the genre - I had made the perfect setup. It was the day after a party, the one thing we were in mood for was a good movie on the DVD. We didn't have high expectations, but were sorely disappointed anyway.*** the following may contain SPOILERS ***It started out reasonably, until the so-called special effects took over. The scene in France with Mr. Hyde almost made me stop the movie. It was like putting in a cartoon character. At first I thought it was Quasimodo.Unfortunately the movie did not get better. The "machine-gun cross-bow" is a joke, so is Van Helsing's marksmanship - until, of course, he has to hit a bride, then he is suddenly very accurate.Another scene that was really bad was the brides chasing the carriage over several hours, flying up high in the sky, and yet they seemed to miss the other carriage 100 yards away - please... I could go on for quite some while but will stop now. I had high hopes for this title initially. They went down due to bad reviews from friends - so I decided not to watch it at the cinema. Still with my hopes being down, this turned out to be my biggest movie disappointment in a century :-(

Review title: Eye candy so sweet, it'll send you into the fantasy film buff's equivalent of a diabetic coma.
Review_body: Eye candy so sweet, the sugar shock will send you into the fantasy film buff's equivalent of a diabetic coma. As a medically necessary antidote, follow this movie up with a chaser of "Dancing at Lughnasa" - or some other equally slow paced yawner - so that you can bear to make it through another unfantastical day of your normal, boring, real human life without unconsciously resorting to wrapping your teeth around some hapless unsuspecting co-worker's neck in search of a desperate shot of excitement - vampire style.No sh**, man! This single movie has enough computer generated graphics special effects to power a thousand pyrotechnical, body-morphing, fantasy world conjuring, beast-enabled fight scene plastered, adrenalin pumping, camera swishing, sorry-we-forgot-the-storyline action spectaculars. It's wall to wall on this one. Not content with a mere two hours of non-stop CG assault on your senses, they even found a way to squeeze entire full length computer generated action movie features between each frame. Try it. Slow down the movie enough on your player and you'll see what I'm talking about. It's insane! (OK, made you look. Nye, nye, nye-nye, nye) You need to watch this movie inside a hyperbaric chamber, being bathed in high pressure oxygen rich air osmotically carrying oxygen into your bloodstream, because there's just no good moment to take a breath. I'd like to see a version of this movie cut with 5 second pauses at 1 minute intervals. That way you could take a deep breath and hold it for every step of the way. Every minute there'd be a black screen with huge text saying "Now breath in deep". It would be released as "Van Helsing: Survival Edition", with the catchphrase "Now You Can Breathe (TM)".Alright, nuff said. Not suggesting that you avoid this movie. It was actually quite delicious to look at, and I had fun with it (I'm sure someone's going to ream me for admitting that, but WTF). By far the star of the show was Dr. Frankenstein's monster - the only real compelling emotional element in all of it. Van Helsing's sidekick also adds a bit of flavor, of the levity variety. Otherwise, it's just eye candy. But ever so schweet! It's kind of like in that episode of the Simpsons where Bart and Milhouse score a $20 bill and immediately proceed to the Kwik-e-mart to order a squishy from Apu that's made entirely from 100% syrup. Ingestion of said squishy sends Bart and Milhouse on a psychedelic sugar-induced trip and, next morning, Bart discovers he's joined the Boy Scouts. NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO! I won't bother to go into the plot of this movie, since it's so minimal that even a mere sentence on the plot could be considered a spoiler. You have to see this movie to believe it. The visuals are just so unbelievably out of control. Who needs 'shrooms when you can trip out on this kind of stuff? Sure, the dialog is stooooooopid. Sure, the story is no more than a wee teeny tiny little idea adorned with a katrillion dollars' worth of effects magic. But, sweet eye candy... arrrrrrgrgggrghhghhhhhhhhhhhhhhh......

I think this movie was very under rated by most critics.Most of this unfair criticism was due to the amount of over hyped publicity before the film's release.The plot line had enough deviations from the original Dracula/Werewolf/Frankenstien movies and was a really nice mixture that added depth to the character development process. Even after several viewings of the movie I still see things that were missed in previous viewings.The casting was very good and Hugh Jackman fans will really enjoy how he takes this character to it's extreme edge. The special effects were well planned and only in a few spots did I think they could have used live action more effectively.The use of black and white cinematography in the beginning was actually a very nice technique.The costuming was appropriate for the time period yet stylish enough to tie it to the modern era.The comic relief was well placed and the friar being similar to Q from the bond films was very entertaining.Overall it's a good movie for people that have very limited exposure to the horror film genres.

Review title: Abbot and Costello get a modern melodramatic makeover.
Review_body: What this movie lacked in originality was balanced quite equally with it's futile attempt to redefine the vampire genre. Color coded filters will hold your hand in an attempt to convey the mood of each scene while dragging you to the end of the movie, unless of course you are lucky enough to break free and run away.Like so many movies being mass produced, hyped up and pumped out, Van Helsing weaves an incongruent story around a painfully puerile script and ceaseless onslaught of special effects. The curse of Van Helsing is a strange combination Gothic science, metaphysical vapirism, and lycanthropy, a vision that goes not only unrealized, but becomes quite tedious early in the movie.I highly recommend warding off Van Helsing.

Some people may say that this movie is bad, but I don't think so! I guess that's because I like vampire films. The thing I liked about the film was the details. Hugh Jackman had cool clothes with a mystic hat! The village looked like it WAS in the middle-age, and I guess that was the meaning of it! Sure, I got a bit disappointed when Frankenstein was the "Problem of the world"! That Frankenstein was important. I have always seen him as just a monster. Dracula was a cool character in this film. He was almost as I could imagine him. Almost! The Wolfman was scary the first time I saw him. Well, how would you imagine of a dangerous row of teeth would come against you in a rush? Anyway! I liked this film a lot, but I never would have guessed that Universal was "responsible" for it. I have always seen Universal Studios as a "Kid Film Makers", but since this movie, I guess I need to change my meaning about them!

Review title: The movie does what a movie is supposed to be.
Review_body: Awesome first watch movie, and rewatch revisiting after few years. Superbly entertainer.

HeyDoes anyone no if there is going to be a Van Helsing 2, i hope there is because the first one was awesome. If so i hope they don't go overboard on the visual effects.If there is going to be a Van Helsing 2 what do you think the storyline will be and who will be in the cast for it?For those who didn't like Van Helsing, Why? Besides that the movie rocked big time!!!!!!!!1

This movie really isn't all that great. If I could sum everything in the movie into one word, it would probably be horrendous. There were many problems I found, such as the animations, the plot, and the things with the monsters. Let me start by talking about the plot. This movie is far too easy to follow, as in, you can tell what is going to happen. It is not a movie that draws you in and keeps you interested, as I was wanting to stop watching after the first few minutes. I can not believe that people have claimed this to have wonderful action. There was not much thrilling action in it, and if there was, it was with animated characters, so the action lost most of its intensity. Also there is the problem of the animations. It is far too easy to tell that they are animated. When you animate something into a movie, aren't you supposed to make it look like it's real? These animations gave themselves away completely, compelling me to laugh when they were talking to the actors. It made me feel as though I was watching a children's cartoon. The biggest problem I had with the movie, however, was the monsters. The so-called "vampires" seem to follow every folk lore about vampires that exists (such as stake through the heart will kill them, they have no reflection in mirrors, etc.), yet they can still go out in the sunlight? Yes, most of their time is spent in the dark, but I don't understand why they can attack in the middle of the day. Finally, Van Helsing is rescued from becoming a werewolf by Anna, but yet, while she is giving him the antidote, he kills her. So, in the end, he ends up with nothing. Mainly all that occurs is Van Helsing going off to look for and kill Dracula (who really wasn't ever a vampire... another problem I had) and his "children" or all of the monsters that he has created. This movie is a fun, action packed adventure, where you can see animated creatures, go off to fight childhood monsters, such as Dracula and Frankenstein, and in the end, have nothing because the girl that you have (sort of) fallen in love with, dies.

I don't know why so many people didn't like this movie. I thought it was one of the best movies I've ever seen. I guess other people just don't know how to use there imagination and go into a fantasy world full of adventure and lots of action. I loved this movie and watched it about a million times. It's great. I just loved the actors they were great and very talented. It must have been very fun for them in this movie. I want to become an actress when I'm older and I would love to do a movie like this. I didn't think any part of it was dumb. After watching this film i came away feeling quite disappointed, i think however this may be because i had much higher expectations of it.Being a fan of most films of this genre, especially those involving Dracula! Although the storyline itself was good, the actual film seemed quite disjointed. A lot of the script dialogue was pretty awful and corny, for example when one of the vampires says "too bad, so sad" maybe it was the failed attempt of the actress, or maybe the dialogue was just truly terrible, either way it made me cringe! The effects were good, the majority of the acting was well done, but i wouldn't really consider recommending this to a friend.

Review title: A no brain flick for the masses
Review_body: I saw this film in the cinemas with some Buddy's as we thought vampires and werewolves? what can be better? impaling ones eyes with a pitchfork thats what. On to the review. The film is just a mish mash of all horror movies of old and to a lacklustre effect,i wouldn't say the acting is awful but there wasn't any breakthrough performances and I'm sure the script didn't help much. Kate Beckinsales accent wasn't that bad but i believe the writers/director/producers only wanted her in this movie as eye candy which is wrong Kate deserves a lot more than that. Her character also seems to be invulnerable to all forms of pain and can Fall through tree branches from 30-40 feet and get slammed into walls without consequence. Then it looks like she forgot her cheat codes as she was killed by bring pushed onto a ....sofa..? wait wait wait hold up was her character allergic to velvet or something? i found this pretty ridiculous. Hugh Jackman comes in with the stereotyped cheesy one liner action hero which is what has been the norm for summer blockbusters to be honest. CGI has been a main gripe with some people I'm with Spielberg's FORMER conclusion of the less you see the better as too much cgi takes away from the connections with the characters. That along with the lack of character development really does pull this movie down. Watch this film if your in the mood for a cheesy popcorn flick but otherwise give it a miss.

Review title: A nonstop action flick for the fan of the unusual!!!!
Review_body: Yes the plot is as thin a single hamburger at McDonalds, but who needs a plot when you have this much fun. This movie all your favorite monsters rolled into one story line. The effects were incredible and the sets were imaginative and striking. This is also a movie that pays homage to the classics as well as the comics. The lines were as fun as the movie and although predictable at times this movie takes you to a new high with the age old vampire tale. Hugh Jackman played the lead perfectly. The minute you see Kate Beckinsale you can't get enough of her. Richard Roxburgh plays Dracula up a bit but when given an opportunity to play the worlds most famous monster who wouldn't. I have seen many different spins on the Dracula story but this one ranks up on the top of the bunch for me. It is a great ride and I loved it. Not a kids movie.

Hugh Jackman could have spared himself the trouble of trying to act among an otherwise cardboard cast and settings that fit the special effects - it all looks as tasteless as is barely acceptable in something like a Hulk-sequel. The script is mainly an inconsistent sequence of clichés from various, unrelated and hardly compatible horror traditions, turning the eponymous vampire-killer into a universal monster-slayer trained by a secret Catholic order as an orphan, with some other implausible twists. The genre normally requires accepting a few unrealistic premises, but here there is almost nothing beyond that to make it worthwhile. The result is rather infantile, hardly good enough even to be mentioned in the history of Dracula-movies.

Possibly on3 of my favourite films- I've watches this so many times and still don't get bored of it. Great family entertainment film, which does nothing more than set out to provide some light entertainment and it's all the better for it. Not every film needs to be a masterpiece

I don't consider Van Helsing as a wonderful movie, but it's not very horrible either. Some parts of it are entertaining to watch but you take a nap or daydream about something else during the other scenes. The problems I have with the movie are: storyline (not very good) and TOO much CGI and action scenes. I think Sommers intended for this movie to be scary, but unfortunately, it's not. It seems to be a LOT more of an action movie than horror.The problem with the storyline is, well, vampire babies??? Why couldn't the vampires just sire a bunch of people and start some kind of chain reaction. The only good part about the storyline is Gabriel's background and amnesia and connection to Dracula, but we don't see enough of that. Sommers tries to combine the stories of vampires, werewolves, and Frankenstein's monster all in one movie, but it just seems like everything is simply thrown together. The only reason Frank's monster is there is for the vampire babies and the only reason the werewolves are there is because they are deadly to Dracula. Speaking of which, the issue of the werewolf antidote and Dracula's control over werewolves is very confusing. The acting wasn't bad, but the accents certainly were. The brides acted over the top at times.On to the good points. Visually, this movie is great. The architecture of the castles and buildings is beautiful. The monsters are all taken to the next level. The vampire brides turn into harpy-like beings and Dracula transforms into a gargoyle/bat-like demon (though it looks very CGI). The design for Frank's monster was really cool. The werewolves have huge fangs, move very fast, and transform by ripping their skins off! (But they also look CGI).Overall, I give it 5 out of 10. It would have been great if there were less over-dramatic action scenes and explosions and more attention to a better story that actually keeps you interested. I keep wishing that Sommers had made some kind of a psychological thriller with these characters. That would have been awesome and we would have a deeper understanding and appreciation of the characters and events in the story.

Review title: A straight up action movie with excellent effects and a witty script at times.
Review_body: Another review says almost the same, this was fun to watch, a mix of the old stories, Dracula, Frankenstein, Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde etc...I'm biased, Hugh Jackman is a fellow countryman and he never fails to deliver. Looking past the action, you see humanity, humility and mans capacity for cruelty but not in your face preaching on those things, just nuanced and subtle reminders of our being human and therefore capable of good and bad. Like I said, fun to watch, easy to follow and you can get the message pf your mind is open about humans and how we act.

I was really looking forward to this movie. My friends and i rushed to the cinema to finally see it. We have all been bombarded with the advertizing of this movie, and the expectations were extremely high.The effects and sound were amazing, the storyline and the acting poor. I like Hugh Jackmann, he rules x-men. The effects in are as i said incredible, the digital stuff almost incredible, the humor is almost funny, the end is very predictable. I enjoyed the movie, but it doesnt go down as a classic for me, like x-men.TB

Well, this film really reminds me of the Star Wars movies. Why?The main theme is the fight between good and evil, but otherwise there is no real plot. You´ll see lots of fights, explosions and chase scenes, but not much else. The film anti-climaxes every ten minutes, usually because of uninspired (over)acting or extremely ridiculous dialogue. The CGI is flawless - it´s actually way too flawless - in this setting it should have been more organic.Oh, and the hero is totally unaware of his background, while the heroine is constantly dressed in sexy outfits, not particularly suited for fighting.Both Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale are talented actors, but unfortunately the chemistry between them is lacking. Richard Roxburgh is miscast as Count Dracula and fails completely to bring sinister qualities to his role. Fortunately, David "Faramir" Wenham as ´Q´ provides comic relief and something for the Lord of the Rings fans. And Dracula´s brides are rather fine eye candy.Maybe this is 2004´s first blockbuster, but it will not be the start of a new franchise. Too bad. But then again, at least that´s one thing it doesn´t have in common with Star Wars.
-+ Asparges +-

I looked forward to seeing this film for months.  The film editors that handled the trailers should get an Oscar! Hugh Jackman is appealing- as usual.  But he alone, cannot carry this film. Some of the dialogue was meant to be funny- but we laughed at parts that were meant to be serious. The picture of Frankenstein's monster escaping on a home-made raft was just too ridiculous. And Kate Beckensale's Transylvanian accent was horribly laughable. Has anyone else noticed that her hair was never out of place?  Even after she was hanging upside down.  We actually laughed and applauded when her character died. I think that this film was meant to be a merchandising tool-video games, toys, etc.  Even so, I think that the film could have been much better.

Van Helsing is great fun, but I fear that the humor is not always intended. It's sort of a cross between Indiana Jones, Tarzan and a James Bond film with vampires, wolfmen and Frankensteins monster. Weird, overlong and with a lot of ropeswinging... The film rips of pretty much every film ever made, but it's done so openly that it somehow gets away with it.Van Helsing really don't have a real script. The film is just a collage of actionsequences and scenes were the characters explains the plot to each other. There is really nothing for the actors to work with. That aside, there is no excuse for putting Kate Beckinsale in a film. She is a terrible, terrible actress. Yes, I know she is stunning, but she doesn't do anything but moan through the entire film. She is well on the way of becoming the female Ben Affleck, and that is not a compliment! The only character with a hint of charisma is Frankensteins monster. And that says a lot.Even after all this I kind of likes Van Helsing. It's so stupid and silly and really quite entertaining. It's boring at places, but that only serves as a pause to buy more popcorn. It's a fluffy, childish summerflick that is perfect for a ballyhoo crowd. In short: It's a Stephen Sommers film!

Well first of all I have to say that probably this movie targeted the 13 to 16 age group, because if not, then it is very sad. What ware the creators thinking? But just if you look what kind of movies Mr Sommer made before it all somehow comes back to you.Why did I watch this film? Well only because of Kate. I was more or less impressed with her Underworld so I was thinking this movie must be so much better. Sadly it wasn't.The biggest problem of this movie is that it doesn't know what it wants to be a comedy, kids/fantasy, a thriller, scary, CGI, horror/history or crap movie.There are only 3 good things about this movie: 1.Kate 2.special effects 3.soundEvery thing else spells disaster! 1.Budapest in Transylvania (since when) 2.Carl as Mr Q 007 3.Helsing as James Bond/Inspector Gadget/Buff 4.Big reunion, every body is here from Igor to Vladislav-who is he?On my scale this movie scores only a marginal 6 out of 10.Alex, ICQ 42208766

Review title: Lots of noise, snarling, effects. Low on story
Review_body: I was really looking forward to a good story. I got the impression quarter of the way through the story that they were trying to beat their story home with a very loud stick.Even the transitional frames were filled with loud background noise. They barely giving you time to breathe. I like a good adventure and this had it's chances to deliver.But it came up short on story. If it were a peanut-butter and jam sandwich, it was almost all red-jelly, and very little bread and peanut butter. It wasn't satisfying, and didn't leave a good aftertaste.Not Hugh Jackman's fault, he's a hunk. And Kate Beckinsale has never looked more delicious.

Review title: If you liked this movie, you must be in middle school...
Review_body: I'd heard from multiple sources that Van Helsing was a stupid movie, that they hated it, that they wished they could have the time back that they wasted on it. I thought they were exaggerating, and since I'm a sucker for vampire movies or anything else a little out of the ordinary, I decided to watch the movie anyway. This was my biggest mistake... It is all true. It is really is one of the most idiotic movies ever made. I am embarrassed for Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale. Were they blackmailed into doing this movie or something? It is almost like the director and writer were TRYING to make the worst movie ever made, (or if they were trying to make it like those silly 'B' horror movies from fifty years ago, they didn't even do that well). It had all of the ridiculous clichés, horrible special effects, and was just plain dumb. I was increasingly annoyed as the film progressed and kept thinking, are you kidding me? Did anyone spend even one cent to produce this ridiculous piece of crap? I most thoroughly do NOT recommend that anyone waste any of their time on this movie, perhaps one of the dumbest movies I've ever seen.

I sat down expecting a cross between Draclula and Frankenstein and what i got was Barbie and friends. The film was so poor i cant express it in words. Coming out of the cinema i feel like I've been punched in the stomach and had £20 robbed off me, i cant believe i have just paid MY money to watch this crap. First of all the storyline was a load of rubbish. Secondly the acting was rubbish (Jackman shone in bits but the storyline was that bad he couldn't have even looked decent.) The film has took bits and pieces of the best horrors and rolled them all up into a poor excuse for a film and waited and watched gullible people go to the cinema and spend their money on it

'Van Helsing' is, in my opinion, a very good film that stands on it's own. I realize that the director's intention was to tie this in with the Universal horror films made in the 1930s and 1940s, but he failed. For example: 1. In the 1931 version of 'Dracula', the famous monster-killer's name was Abraham Van Helsing, not Gabriel Van Helsing.2. In the 1931 version of 'Frankenstein', The Moster doesn't talk at all. The Monster in this film, however, speaks perfect English. This is a homage to Mary Shelley's original Gothic-novel first published in 1818.3. 'The Wolf Man', released in 1941, was not a topless creature that stood God-knows how many feet tall. The Wolf Man's hair is a brownish-hazel, and he wears clothes. The Wolf Man in this film has a brown-like color to him, and he is topless. Just a little thing I found.4. The Kate Beckinsale roll is not in either 'Dracula', 'Frankenstein', or 'The Wolf Man'.Visually, this film is stunning. However, I would have liked more make-up for The Wolf Man, and less CGI for Count Dracula (in human form). The acting is bland on Kate Beckinsale's part, but Hugh Jackman was believable.Overall, I give this film an 7 out of 10. If you are a fan of the horror genre, then you might like this.

Yes, this movie is a mess, lot of cgi, mix up of characters from vintage horror b-movies, restless action but not so thrilling... but this is just because the audience this film calls for is not really the target of what the story is about. In this screenplay I found a very interesting and original tale of good versus evil, full of subtle and deep insights. The presence of the Vatican is particularly important in this sense: the Catholic Church has investigated evil more than any other religion, for some reasons I can't reach. I would say it is a kinda religious movie. I would pair it to "Stigmata", another not flawless story about a very important religious issue, mistaken for just another horror/fantasy movie. While waiting for the masterpiece, I greatly appreciate that these movies tackle some important and neglected religious issues... even if this happens beyond authors' intentions.

Van Helsing is a reunion of classic monsters set to Stephen Sommers' signature roller-coaster pacing. It is a Saturday matinée treat which pays just homage to the Universal and Hammer studios chillers of the past, while introducing a new (and vigorous) slant on the title character. Thankfully, this is not a new era horror film, wherein traumatizing the audience is considered to be critical accomplishment. Instead, a likable and very capable cast usher the audience through this creepy fun-house of trapdoors and eerie shadows. When the lights come back up and the popcorn bags hit the floor, all is well. Especially recommended to those who built the Aurora model kits of the Universal monsters as kids and wish to introduce their preteens to the old school "Creature Features" flicks.
Genuinely the worst film i have ever seen it is awful, everything about it is bad. Delete it from the internet.

Well, most of my friends hate this movie, but come on, it's great! ^^ Lol, it's got not just vampires, like most vampire movies these days, but Frankenstein's monster, a more convincing Dracula, Dr Jekyll/Hyde (Matter of personal opinion what you call him eh?) and more. The Vatican is an interesting touch, gave me a good laugh. It starts off the film in black and white, so you know it's the past, not the present, and it is true to both Dracula, by Bram Stroker, and Frankenstein to some extent. It provides laughs, moral issues, and hide behind the sofa moments to please any taste, and with the animated prequel, The London Assignment, what more could you want? However, much as I love the film, I was so confused over the whole Angel Gabriel affair that I just rented the book from the library today. In the book, he introduces himself as Gabriel Van Helsing near the end. So, 10 out of 10 to this awesome film, and ciaos!

Review title: Movie is SO bad... You should see it to believe how bad it is
Review_body:
Movie have good premise, but execution is one of the worst ever.
Screenplay, dialogs... There's no words to describe it. Have to watch it yourself. Few times i genuinely started to laugh. (Maaariskaaaaa, Noooo he killed Maaariskaaaaa!!!). And guy playing the main vampire, his acting is so bad and annoying. Just a little worse than this priest guy. All in all, movie is borderline parody. And one of the biggest cinematic fails.

Review title: A Specialist beats a generalist, and this is not a specialist
Review_body: This movie tries to be too many things.  It tries to add way too many monsters into it.  The whole movie is CG and that's all it has going for it. The plot is only furthered by occasional dialog.  The Special Effects are LOADED with over the top explosions and pyrotechnics.  The sound effects are repeated over and over throughout the movie.  I honestly didn't think the movie was going to end.  The goths sitting behind me in the theater laughed at the movie the whole time...it's not a comedy.  And the worst part, think of every cliche in every movie that's been done a thousand times and they put it into this movie.  From the jittery comic relief guy trying to walk away when it gets frightening, to the cheesy walking off into the sunset ending.  Do yourself a favor, if you must see this movie, wait for a rental.

To whom it may concern, I am at this very moment watching Van Helsing. I've been watching it for over an hour now. I honestly want to know, if you've seen it, is this for real? This is a joke right? Come on. Is this movie as bad as it looks to me, or is it just me? Why is it so bad. Why. WHAT audience was intended for this movie? What audience?! Its like the corniest fairy tale I've ever seen! "Nothing is faster than Trannsylvanian horses, not even vampires." ARE YOU KIDDING ME!? WHO WROTE THIS SCRIPT!? It makes me so mad. If you think my comment is unfair or extreme then there are two possible causes for that:1) you haven't seen the movie2) THERE IS NO OTHER REASON! There is no sensible reason for liking this movie.There.

Review_body: This movie was expected by me deeply, but my very short opinion is, never seen this kind of awful sh*t in my whole life... All of the spended money way useless, Sommers made his biggest shame, besides I liked Mummy in its category really... Theres is a lot of spectacular scene, but it hasn't got enough own part during the cinema, because the ridiculous conversations surpassed everything!!! I was really looking forward to seeing this movie. Really. Silly me. It's not that I am a purist. I could handle that they Van Helsing into Huge Ackman - I really like the guy and I liked his look. But they crammed everything in here but the kitchen sink. It was like Frankenstein Meets the Wolfman and Dracula on Ecstacy. All the old monsters were here and amped up. They just pumped so many effects in here (Frank's monster with a hinged face??? and just about everyone climbing the walls at one point or another) they lost sight for story quality and continuity. It was just too excessive to be pleasurable. I think they were going for the Mummy (which was a hoot!), but forgot that even though that fill fill was elaborate and expensive looking, it was still simple and fun. If they are cranking out a sequel, count me out...

I had such high hopes. But this thing was ALL CG and no substance. What a waste of gifted actors. What an insult to the Dracula lore. I'd say the original author would be turning in his grave, but this monstrosity was so over-wrought, the weight of it alone would prevent any risings.This movie stole from so many different different movies, that theft of this magnitude should get someone sentenced for life. And that's what sitting through it feels like -- a sentence.It stole characters from Star Wars, super strength fighting young thing from Buffy, special crime-fighting tools from every possible 007 flick (my goodness, who knew that M was a friar in a previous life?)It was an effect guys wet dream -- not a cohesive movie.
Avoid it at all cost!!!

Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale. Were it not for these two gifted performers, this movie would be beyond silly. As it is, the plot is almost pretextual for the special effects.The Eye Candy factor is high, though. Hugh Jackman as the tortured hero, filmed in the dark all of the time, makes us weak in the knees. Kate Beckinsale does magnificent physical feats while squeezed into a corset.The story: Van Helsing (Jackman) is essentially a bounty hunter of supernatural monsters, a job he took on at the request of the church as apparent penitence for sins he cannot even remember. As a reward for his centuries of service, he hopes to make his way to Heaven instead of Hell.Anna (Kate Beckinsale) is the last survivor of a family of Transylvanian vampire hunters. Her brother has become a werewolf and she is conflicted about whether he should live or die.Naturally Anna and Van Helsing team up to rid Transylvania of the evil vampire overlord. Van Helsing has a tool kit Batman would envy, and Anna maintains an arsenal of monster-killing weapons that would make a survivalist proud. Between the two of them, the monsters don't stand a chance.Put your mind on hold, suspend disbelief and intolerance for the occasional leap of reason, enjoy a slightly randy friar (Van Helsing's sidekick), and go along for the ride. Van Helsing is a great Sunday afternoon video.

Review title: I compare all horrible movies to this one.
Review_body: Quite possibly this is the worst movie I've ever seen. Sometimes I'll see very bad movies and I'll say to my friends, "It was almost worse than Van Helsing," and they get the hint. I actually saw this in theatres thanks to a friend of mine, and at some points the entire audience would burst out in laughter at parts that weren't supposed to be funny. I personally left the movie before the end because I was so bored. The plot and blending of different stories together just doesn't do it. I actually hated it and found myself in an awful mood the rest of the day. Trust me on this one as someone who loves movies, don't waste part of your life watching this film. You'll be asking for those 2 and a half hours back.

I can totally understand the criticism about the plot and character development. But I don't think this film was aiming to be a serious. Its a movie about vampires and werewolves after all. Despite the simplicity of the plot, it's so fun to watch. I watched this movie 10+ times when I was a child, which makes me extremely biased. However, I rewatched it in a more conscious age, and I was surprised how creative the visual part of the movie. The iconic look of the vampires, laboratory with little dwarfs full of steam punk devices, the beautiful masquerade scene. It is such a well-put universe with its own remarkable features.And of course it has a few facepalm moments, but if you compare it to other action/adventure movies, I can't think about a better example.It is for sure in the top of my favorite movie list, and I don't see a problem having it among Shutter Island, Interstellar and The Killing of a Sacred Deer.

it would have been pretty good if the script was decent, but there you go. the only real reason 1 would watch it again is because Kate Beckinsale in that corset outfit looks SO DAM HOTT!!!! GAWD she also wears a red dress at some point so look out for it...DAM she looks fine in that....some of the vampire girls aren't bad either. Anyhow back to the film, set in Transylvania this dark looking film is about the time when Van Helsing (the vampire hunter) is a swarthy young guy instead of the stereotyped old doctor as seen in most Dracula films, basically he's been told by the church to hunt down Dracula and kill him once and for all, after meeting the gorgeous Kate Beckinsale (who plays Anna valerious)they go trampling around Transylvania trying to find Dracula and kill him, bumping into Frankenstein's monster and the wolf man on the way.....on the whole the film is OK, special effects are pretty cool but script sucked a bit hence only 6/10 from me!

This film is terrible, it really is film making at its worst! The film tries to play on stories we've all been brought up with, and then throw in some mysticism and tries to be Gothic but it just doesn't work.Why have Frakenstein's monster in a story about a vampire hunter?, and not only that but a werewolf? Really this is just trying to taking the mickey out of us, maybe some time writers and directors will realise that this kind of rubbish is just not acceptable.To give the film some credit the acting is OK if at times a bit hammy (obviously the actors knew what kind of dross they were in), the special effects work but really the storyline is just MINCE!

Review title: A waste of two hours and 10 dollars
Review_body: I did not expect Stephen Sommer's "Van Helsing" to be an epic, Oscar-worthy piece, but I did have hopes that, with a cast of such talent, it would at least be entertaining. I anticipated the witty humor and intriguing action of Sommer's past film, "The Mummy." I was extremely disappointed. The plot, or should I say lack of, is simply a device to propel continuing action scenes. The characters are flat, undeveloped and uninteresting. The attempted witty dialogue fails miserably. It is the most awful screenplay I've ever encountered. The directing was beyond horrifying, reducing the performances of Jackman, Roxburgh, and Beckinsale to cheesy, overacted stereotypes, and what is with Dracula's brides striking "vogue" poses in the background all the time? The only saving graces of this film are the special effects, action scenes, and the wonderful comic relief performance of David Wenham. And, unfortunately, these are not enough to make the movie worth the time or money required to see it.

Review title: Most entertaining movie of 2004 so far......
Review_body: This movie will leave literary purists and film students around the country crying and moaning this films existence. Ignore them, it wasn't made for them........ as the spearhead of the 2004 summer blockbusters this movie does the job. If you're looking for a film that leave you pondering deep meaningful thought afterwards this isn't the movie for you, I can't stress that enough. If you want to lose yourself for a few hours vicariously fighting monsters as Van Helsing or the lovely Anna then this IS the movie for you.Jackman does an excellent job as Gabriel Van Helsing (not to be confused with Abraham Van Helsing), monster hunter extraordinare and Kate Beckinsdale suffices as the female herione and eye candy. Part Indiana Jones part Mummy Returns and all fun this movie is a great lead-off to the action junkies cinemaniacs summer 2004 blockbuster wetdream.

Review title: Great premise, familiar and well loved characters, awful movie. Huh?
Review_body: It is amazing to me how much of an enormous waste this film is. The art design is phenomenal, the shots are well placed and excellent use of lighting and color and some of the best horror characters of all time. Yet, the script, acting and special effects are all equally horrible. There are two modes of this film: Standing around over explaining the plot Or engaging in clichéd action sequences with no decent payoff.Don't bother with this title. Or any other Stephen Sommers title for that matter. He has proved to be one of the most inept directors of all time.

Review title: why oh why aren't there real vampires????
Review_body: they could hunt sommers down to prevent him from making a sequel to van helsing.... this movie is bad...not only bad its worse. i knew it would be bad, but i believed universal to be wise enough to not develop pure moviecrap...but instead they did! wow, at least interesting. i heard rumors real actors had been involved in van helsing, but i haven't seen any. there is someone who is giving "paleface" a new meaning. i believe him to be someone called hugh jackman and really acting in at least one other movie. his sidekicks beckinsale and wenham are far from beeing worthy to mention. oh and another dummy playing dracula, he at least is funny, cause he is everything else but dracula and this is giving the character dracula a complete fascinating and new meaning. he looks like a highly embarassed kid playing his hateful part in a cheap schoolplay. you could take pity on roxburgh if he hasn't been paid for this. the cgi is like a monster itself too big, too ugly, too loud, but poor thing he's not even scary hes just ridiculous-a complete waste. as the rest of the movie. the score is near to be a pure punishment, spanish guitars in a vampiremovie is too much! i recommend this movie to every moviestudent whose idol is one of those action-monster-why bother over story and quality?-directors to get to see first hand what never to do when making a film. everyone....please stay away go see everything else but this one!

Review title: Somebody deserves to be staked for this...
Review_body:
Five minutes into this film I was already squirming in my seat. I've never walked out of a movie before, I think it's foolish to judge a film unless you have seen it in its entirety. Van Helsing almost had me running for the door. Many people have pointed out that this was only intended as a summer blockbuster, a no brainer with big SFX, lots of one liners and plenty of merchandising possibilities. That's no excuse for this pile of poo..."Oooo, you cynical folk are being too hard on it" I hear some of you deranged individuals cry...The Mummy had the same pitch as this movie, including the use of an old Universal monster. I liked the Mummy. The Mummy was good. The Mummy was fun. The Mummy was a well put together movie, its characters were pretty much one dimensional but everybody liked them. It had none of Van Helsing's frankly sloppy plot devices. A couple of cases in point:"Ooo, we're all going on a werewolf hunt""Right lets plan this all real careful, like. We got the cage we got the bait we got our rifles. Anything else?""Silver bullets?""Good idea. But I tell you what, lets not put silver bullets in all of our rifles, lets just put them in one measly little revolver so that Beckinsale can almost get crushed by the falling cage as she runs to grab it."
Dracula. He's Romanian. The Gypsies come from Romania. Lets be really clever and give the count Gypsy earrings and a pony tail! Wow that'll be really authentic and won't make him look like a god damned idiot in any way shape or form!These are just two criticisms out of the many that I could level at this film but frankly i don't want to spend any more time discussing it! Please save your money don't go to this movie and don't give them an excuse to make a sequel. It would be a terrible terrible thing to inflict on the world.

Review title: A monster hunter seeks out, who is hated by Europe, is ordered to hunt and kill Dracula.
Review_body: "Van Helsing" is the most awesome movie I have ever seen. It had a real creative blend of Count Dracula, Frankenstein's Monster, and The Wolfman. Hugh Jackman, Kate Beckinsale, and the rest of the cast did a fantastic job of luring me into the monster movie country of Transylvania. I know why people consider it to be a horror film, but I really think it was more of an action film. The only part that startled me was the time that on of Dracula's children popped out of the cocoon, so the visual effects were real to me. The sets in the film were made perfectly and looked very real. Stephen Sommers, a great director, once again, hasn't let me down. I really wish action flicks like this could be Oscar(R) winners.

I thought Van Helsing was an excellent film, good story line, laid out perfectly and that was the best incarnation of Dracula. However the film could have lost one thing, the idea of Van Helsing. And The "left hand of god" however the film was greatly done. Sommers is a great director, for films like the mummy and the mummy returns. Those films, are a classic. And So is Van Helsing, i don't understand why people don't like the film. Why are people into "gore", its just boring to see that, its better with action/horror. Great visual effects. Perfectly done. I give the film 9/10 stars. The films introduction to Dracula was a great masterpiece and very well done, it certainly beats the other Dracula's along with their "come and soon you well become a creature of the night!"

This is the first time I am commenting a movie and it's not because I was positively impressed. I value my time, but I wanted to warn you that watching this movie is the worst way you can spend 2 hours of your life.I thought Spiderman, Daredevil and several other movies are the worst cinema can get. Well, today I understood that some people have a ferocious talent for creating awful movies.I didn't expect anything from the movie, yet the screenplay, acting, effects, love scenes, conversations... everything was so lousy, so plain, so pathetic.... Sometimes bad movies get so bad that they become funny. Well, this movie is a rare exception; it did not! It was pathetic and if I were not stuck in the middle of the row with people on both sides, I would have left after the 20th minute.If you are not a person who enjoys pain, DO NOT WATCH THAT movie and cause yourself so much suffering.I regret that I can't give it a rating of -10.p.s. I prefer not to use strong words and exclamation marks in every sentence, yet I am so p***ed off that I could not stop myself.

I thought this movie was excellent. It had everything...Action, horror, drama, romance, suspense, and comedy. I loved the changes it made from the normal way we view the classics. Such as the change of the werewolf. Ripping the skin off is quite different from just sprouting hair. Dracula and his brides were great, too. The change from human to demon--the way they feed. I would not want to be bit be them.  I did think that Igor was scarier than the Frankenstein monster and I had hoped that they would have found a way to save Anna instead of killing her. I hope that in the sequel they explain more of who Van Helsing really is as well. The character of Carl was an enjoyable one. His added humor was a welcome touch. Overall I loved it and would recommend it to anyone.

I love this movie. At first glance all the plot holes and cheesy dialog are enough to make the purists run screaming into the night; but then you realize it is INTENTIONAL. Could they have made it uber-slick, uber-deep, and a character study to boot? Yeah, they could have. But it would have eliminated the point.The one-liners and escapism are in fact the point. Sometimes all the drama gets to be too much, a little campy humor is more than appreciated. Devotees of the Rocky Horror Picture Show might get a kick out of this. I am, and I did. It practically screams for similar treatment, it's that kind of a movie. I find myself saying lines along with the characters, and talking back to the screen a TERRIBLE amount, but if you can suspend your disbelief, that's FUN! No, it's not a serious look at Dracula. It was never meant to be.

Review title: One of the best scary movies around
Review_body: I'll admit I'm not usually one for scary movies, and I'll also admit that the only reason I really went to see Van Helsing was for the eye-candy. However, I was pleasantly surprised; Van Helsing turned out to be a good mixture of special effects, romance, suspense, etc.I lost count of how many times I jumped out of my seat when Count Dracula appeared out of nowhere, but other than that, Richard Roxburgh made a good Count, as Hugh Jackman plays a very good Van Helsing. Even with his faults (and he had a few), I found myself liking his character. David Wenham provided comic relief and more than once me and my best friend were in violent fits of giggles from some of his lines (we're only fourteen ... you do that at our age).The special effects were amazing, my favourite being the werewolf transformation. It was a bit gruesome, but very well-done a even lifelike I thought.In conclusion: for anyone into this genre, Van Helsing is defintitely a must-see!!

Ridiculous stunts that defy the laws of physics and a simple one-dimensional screenplay drag this down. The action sequences could have been trimmed a bit, but it is surprising how well the single plot-line with short, go-nowhere subplots keeps its momentum. The atmospherics of the movie are good -- think Sleepy Hollow meets Two Towers. Jackman plays a very Wolverine like character. So most of this is a derivative hodge-podge of cliched eye-candy from other better sci-fi, fantasy and suspense films -- Matrix, Alien, X-men, Batman, James Bond, etc. Even Silvestri's Gothic-Wagnerian score sounds familiar from other movies. Nevertheless, it is fun to watch Jackman tackle various monsters. His female sidekick does an adequate job, but plays up arrogance and vulnerability and downplays the sort of intensity that the character needed, more in the direction of Linda Hamilton in T2, Sigourney Weaver in Alien(s).

Review title: Fun monster movie without all the gore
Review_body: This movie is perfect for casual watching. It's fun! No oscars and I'm sure the critics hate it, but they are paid to overthink movies and this is one that cannot be over thought. It is simple and enjoyable.

Borrowing from a wide-spectrum of films, including James Bond, Rambo, Bugs Bunny, comedies and classic horror, Van Helsing is a film that does not bring the viewer IN.  You are never engaged.  Instead, you are disengaged by a goofy and thin storyline, almost never-ending noise and gratuitous special effects and ridiculous action scenes that are more filler than story progression.  Van Helsing is less film and more lengthy promotion for a future 'thrill' ride at one of Universal's parks.  As a ride, Van Helsing would be fun -- not scarey, not eerie, just an entertaining few minutes of fun.  As a film, it is very cartoonish, sometimes boring, often repetitive -- and a huge disappointment.  Or is it?  To be disappointed, one has to have certain expectations.  If you are aware that the director (Stephen Sommers) of Van Helsing also directed the recent films The Mummy and The Mummy Returns, your expectations were probably not that lofty.  If you loved those movies, and many did($800 million plus worldwide), you will be thrilled with Van Helsing.  If you thought those films relied too heavily on special effects and not enough on story or character development, you will see the same flaws in Van Helsing.  If you are a fan of the vintage horror films of the 30's and 40's, you will see glimpses of some outstanding visuals that harken to the images of those films.  And, you will see many of the famous monsters of those films, including Frankenstein's creation, Dracula and the Wolfman.  However, you will see only fleeting glimpses of what could have been a return to classic horror -- with the benefit of a huge budget (estimated to be in the $150 million dollar range).  Van Helsing is devoid of the creepy and eerie spirit of the vintage films and the frights of more recent offerings.  Special effects are the primary focus of Van Helsing and, as such, turn the film in to a lavish cartoon/video game, with no depth and not even any real thrills.  Even the aforementioned monsters are disappointing, with the Frankenstein monster looking pretty plump (he garnered laughs at the screening I saw), Dracula hamming it up and the Wolfman, looking less like a wolf-MAN, and more like an artist's rendering -- which is appropriate since he exhibits the ability to survive tremendous falls much like Wyle E. Coyote.  Unless you are a fan of loooong cartoons, Van Helsing, at more than two hours, will bore you more than entertain you and leave you wishing that the filmmakers had dug deeper -- not in to their pockets -- but, in to their imaginations to create a film that would have at least creeped us out and at best gave us some jolts.

Review title: Indiana Jones meets Vampires: Los Muertos
Review_body: I must admit that I am sadly disappointed to see this film produced in the manner it was.  It appears to me that Hollywood is focusing more on FX than story these days.  This film had the curse of a weak storyline being supported by a cast of actors that couldn't help resurrect it any.  If you are a fan of the modern works of Hugh Jackman (X-Men and after) you will find his acting to be on par for this role.  However, the character he portrays is not one that is worthy of Jackman's overall talent.  It is sad for me to say the most realistic and heartfelt acting in this film is done by Shuler Hensley (Frankenstein's Monster).  The role of Dracula is not what one might come to expect for a true lover of vampire movies.  A poorly written script offset with weak comedy cannot save this film from its most certain demise.  Unfortunately, it will most likely settle well with the younger crowds and the FX of the film and it's PG-13 rating will allow the younger audience to carry it to the upper ranks in the box office. However, I wouldn't waste the time or money investing in this film as an evening of entertainment.

Not a masterpiece but an great popcorn flick. People who go to see blockbusters expecting an oscarworthy plot are usually going to be disappointed. the action was excellent. I found the plot and story easy to follow, and actually a rather intriguing look at all these myths. Overall I enjoyed it and will be adding it to my collection, It will probably become a haloween tradition to watch this movie, and I hope there are sequels, though what mythical monsters are left for him to hunt I'm not sure.I gave it 10 stars, it has what I look for in adventure movies. Save the plot for the Oscar contenders.

Review title: The stupidest movie i have seen since 'Underworld'
Review_body:
After watching this movie, you'll ask yourself, 'did they even read the script?' 'Was he(Stephen Sommers) even awake when he wrote the script?' SPOILER WARNINGThe movie starts out in b & w. Personally, I don't think it really needs it, but ok, sure. It's basically telling Dr. Frankenstein death story. Anything that happens in the first ten minutes of a movie, if told, i don't consider to be a significant enough spoiler to ruin the movie for somebody.The windmill that it happens in was made to burn. The whole interior is decorated with stuff that will help it burn. They are also in places, that would be pretty dangerous. Well anyway, that's the end of that.
Now, onto color. It starts out with, this was my first guess, one of Jack the Ripper's victims. Van Helsing investigates, and looks back at some big, huge, building. Ok, now I'm thinking, The Hunchback? Scene cuts to him up there, this entire scene contributes nothing, absolutely nothing, that I could tell, to the story. Once up there, you find out it's Mr. Hyde. Now, for the record, just about anything and everything in this movie is ripped from another one. Now, IMO, Mr. Hyde is just the opposite of the Hulk. He looks like he's there, but he doesn't look real. For Hulk, switch 'real' and 'there'. The scene that ensues is straight from any 007 movie. The people in this movie are also extremely slow, the monk/Q character has a device that is basically an artificial sun, he says he knows what it does, but not what it's for. It takes him till just before they really need it to figure out what it is for. For me, it took me negative two seconds to think, 'that can be used to kill Dracula, I don't see what the problem is.'I'm going to skip a lot of the movie till right before Anna and Van Helsing meet Frankenstein's monster. Now, i had totally forgotten he was supposed to be in the movie and with the dialog before the meeting I thought that there was about 10-20 min left in the movie. About 20 min later, with no signs of ending anytime soon, i thought, 'What the sh!t, this crap isn't done yet? F*ckin A.' It isn't even close to ending. You have about another hour left. Once you have though 'Ok, now the only reason i'm staying in this movie is to see it get better,' walk out. It'll get exciting, somewhat, and more stupid, but not better.Now for the major spoiler: For the plot twist, Anna dies, yeah. Then, if you think back and replay some of the things she's done in your mind, you realize that she could've took it. End of major Spoiler.Now for the special effects. Awesome. Dracula looks a little clay-ish, in his vampire form. But again, like Mr. Hyde, he looks like he's there. They work best in the dark where they don't have to put in much detail. And the transformations look pretty good, except for Anna's brothers when he's on the wall, i was asking how in hell he could stay up there. Kate Beckinsale looks great in the movie by the way. But it's not enough to save it by the longest shot anybody could ever take.Another thing, this movie is suppossed to be funny as comic releif. I counted five times i laughed. 2 of them i can remember. When Helsing asks Igor why he shouldn't kill him and when Anna says she'll cut off something. You'll get it. Oh, and His children look like Gremlins3/10 (Special Effects-2; Kate-1)

In my opinion they put a monkey in a room with boxing gloves and a typewriter to write the script, they also gave him a video camera to film it... this movie is by far the worst movie I've seen this year (out of about 70). I would give it negative numbers if i could! AVOID THIS PIECE OF CRAP!!!!!!!!!I wouldn't say this is as bad as the Mummy Returns but is still a piece of crap. EVERYTHING WAS BAD ABOUT THIS MOVIE.When you think they are going to reveal the cool backstory... They make up a lame excuse to avoid it and it never gets revealed.If they make a sequel/ T.V spin off like what is rumored i will cry.

This Movie doesn't have anything worth watching, it ain't even a rental. The plot doesn't make sense, the whole idea is just to grab all of the famous horror characters, put them together in some kind of doom-scenario.casting was oke (beckinsale is goodlooking as always (note the corset she's wearing) acting however was dramatic, and also the special effectes weren't as good as you might expect. all in all this was actually what i exptected it to be, and it turned out as bad as i was afraid it would be.really, try watching something else instead!*1/2 out *****

I went into this movie knowing nothing about it other than what I had seen in the TV trailers. It looked great, and, feeling I have to give credit where credit is due, I must say that it did not disappoint in that regard. The visuals and effects in this movie are, hands down, a 10 out of 10.It's a shame it has so little going for it otherwise.The plot, what little there is, takes forever to get going, and, once it does, sputters and dies shortly thereafter. From there on, it's your typical rescue-the-princess and kill-the-monsters romp that would be better suited to a late 80's video game than a blockbuster movie.The characters themselves aren't much better. David Wenham's Carl gets some good lines and comes across as likable, but the rest of the cast don't have much going for them, although I think that, perhaps given a script with a little more meat in it, the players could have sunk their teeth into the roles better. Another minus to the closing pyre scene, easily one of the cheesiest movie moments I can recall and really had no place in a movie such as this.So if you're the type that feels CGI and a bare-chested Hugh Jackman are the ingredients of a good movie, see it and you'll go home happy. But if you prefer fare such as plot development and three-dimensional characters, you would, in all honesty, be better off watching an episode of That 70's Show.Overall, a 6 out of 10.

Review title: Best Vampire Movie I have seen.
Review_body: One of the best movie I have seen in vampire category. The CG effect is very cheesy. Its not like its just filled with computer graphics. There are many other elements as well. The acting was superb. There was a bit of balance between comedy, action and horror. There was not a single instant where I was bored or lost interest. It was all very superb. I wonder why everyone have given this movie a very small rating, just 5.5 ? I was very disappointed to see such low rating for this great movie. I recommended to my friends and they all loved it. This is the 4th time I have watched this movie, and I will watch it again. If Underworld can get a better rating, then why not this one? For what I have seen is that IMDb raters usually rate on fast movies with lot of action, and I hate slow movies.

Review title: All it needed was Billy Bob to suck completely!!!
Review_body: This movie is the worst movie I have ever seen that did not have Billy Bob Thornton in it, with the exception of Torque. There is no originality in the plot, just a jumble of other movies(LOXG, The Order, Underworld, Any vampire movie, Any werewolf movie, Any Frankenstein movie, Any James Bond movie, etc..). The acting is ok, not including any of the vampires, and the special effects were bang on. It was predictable and horrifically corny. Even the werewolf poem wasn't original. I've known the words to that little piece since I was a child. They couldn't even get a girl who wasn't cross-eyed to play a vampire! I will be writing the production company to ask for my money back. I know I won't get it, but at least I will complete the feeling that I was just robbed of money and 2 hours of my life.

Review title: Great on effects, laughable at times though
Review_body: Hello everyone,Just happened to get a chance yesterday to see this film and knowing this was a Stephen Sommers film, had a kind of movie on my mind.I wasn't far off. Van Helsing has quite some similarities with movies like The Mummy. A hero (Van Helsing), a heroine (Anna Valerious), a goofy fellow (Farmir...uhh...I mean Carl) one MAJOR badass (Count Vladislaus Dracula) who is helped even by the same goofball that also played in The Mummy (Igor, Beni in the Mummy)The movie had some great effects and you can laugh a lot during it. Because I had a feeling that I was to expect a movie like this, I was not dissappointed. I'm sure it will do quite well in Box Office.I have read some reviews that totally burned Van Helsing to the ground, but I cannot say I agree on that. It wasn't the best I've seen, but it was by FAR not the worst either.

Review title: Van Helsing is a good Film.
Review_body: Even if I've read so many bad comments about this Film, I'm able to say that in Italy it was a success. The plot is very original, and is simple to follow, therefore it is in a way different from the other films about vampires, werewolves and "monsters". Obsviously there's always the same theme: fight between good and evil, but I've to admit the locations are really weird and the film has - in my humble opinion - an high level starring, apart from some bit players. Anyways, I saw the film twice: the first time in 2005 and the second one last year, and it was still exciting, I enjoyed so much watching it, and if anybody asked me to spend a night watching it again, I would: it's always a pleasure to watch this film, it's a mix of adventure, action and legendary creatures (Dracula, for example). So, if you're looking for an original and simple film, which has the mythical or the magical element and you like action and fantasy this one's for you. Of course this is not a colossal, but I think that it's incredible how it has such a low rating. I can firmly assort that many films which are marked as awesome or outstanding - I don't wanna mention them - are rather worse than this one.

Not even having great actors like Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale could save the awful story line of this film. It didn't help that Beckinsale's accent was distracting at best. I love classic monster films but I am not a purist in stating that Frankenstein's monster couldn't be pseudo-insightful, but thousands of vampire offspring that look like Spyro flitting around after being empowered by energy harnessed through Frankenstein's monster??? I think they were obsessed with how to get as many monsters into one film as possible and not very worried about how to make an exciting story. I gave it a "3" for the special effects which were decent even by today's standards.

If you are a fan of old sci-fi and horror movies, I recommend giving Van Helsing a try. There were some great shots in the film that were so reminiscent of other movies that I love--from the older Dracula movies to the contemporary James Bond flicks. (However, if you are put off by guts and gore, then this is not your movie.)I wasn't looking for excellent acting in this movie, and so was not disappointed with the some-what canned performance of some of the secondary actors. I found Van Helsing's sidekick quite funny, and would have loved to see more of him in the film.
