Some viewers have been put off by Van Helsing's invincibility, but there is a softer side--emotionally-- to the monster- slayer that I enjoyed seeing in the movie. The special effects may not have been very original, but I thought that they were well done and added to the overall experience of the movie.

Review title: Should have been a good movie
Review_body: This could have, would have, should have been a good movie. There were scenes that were worth watching but then there were scenes that were so poorly written that they made you forget the good ones. The mystery of who the characters were didn't even come close to compensating for the horrible dialog and weak attempts at comedy relief. One scene alone sums up my opinion of the movie.***Possible Spoiler*****You live in a town that loses a couple people a month to vampires. These vampires come at night and everyone knows it. So...A noise is heard in the middle of the night and every person in town goes outside to investigate. I guess maybe they felt safer running screaming through the streets than they did behind locked doors. All they needed to top it was to send someone out alone to save a cat.I really wanted to like this movie.

OK so, i can move past the borsh (meat soup) they did of many myth stories all in one, i can get past the confusion of it all, but what really bothers me (and most Romanians) is that Hollywood almost always gets the myth WRONG and all the simple details WRONG! Is it really THAT difficult to pick up a map, or google it? Budapest is the capital of Hungary, Transilvania is a region of Romania. WHY is is that difficult to get it straight? I've seen this mistake in SO many vampire adaptations. Besides the fact that the myth is messed around with in so many versions no one knows the original one anymore, they get simple geography wrong? that's not something you invent, it's on the world map! And if you DO chose to have your characters speak Romanian, ASK a Romanian guy to tell / teach you! Seriously, most of them sound horrible and make NO sense at all. I'll volunteer if that! I'll translate it for you for free. Just get ONE movie right. This movie made NO sense to me, and i probably seen them ALL. Now please stop messing the myth up and get some other one to screw and bend!Or at least accept the fact that you're continuously and knowingly insulting a few million Romanian people.

Review title: Why I like this movie as much as I do
Review_body: . . . I just came back from the theater and have to say I really really enjoyed watching this film. How I judge whether or not a film is suitable to my taste is generally speaking, limited to subject matter and how I feel during the actual act of watching it. Obviously I am into monster stories/fantasies, so the reason I love it is because it moved me inside. The graphics were incredibly realistic, the scenery and characters (WOMEN) beautiful and horrible (the good kind) all at once, and the plot reasonably complex such that I was immersed into the whole world. My heart was racing.I honestly feel that this is a movie made by a man who is so passionate not only about movies, but beauty and horror. He was inspired by his father as a child to love the whole monster genre, but in the process to cultivate himself in the art of imagination. . . (he dedicated the movie to his father)I feel Roger Ebert describes the movie well when he refers to Van Helsing as having "a world that is violent and hectic, bizarre and entertaining, and sometimes very beautiful." I definitely want to hear Stephen Sommers explain why and how he created this world. Hopefully the DVD will supply some great commentary.sonb

C'mon guys! This movie wasn't bad AT ALL. And believe me, I know bad movies - last week I had the unexplainable urge to go to the theater and I saw "The Punisher" (man was that awful) and later on, since VH was sold out, "The Alamo" (you wouldn't believe it, but it's actually worse than "The Punisher").Now, compared to these movies "Van Helsing" was a MASTERPIECE. I mean, come on, nobody expected a well-thought story! Yes, the story is stupid. Yes, there are more than a few plot holes. Yes, the romanian accents were awful. BUT that's not what this movie is about. This movie is supposed to be an enjoyable action flick, and honestly it is. The action sequences are more than just good, the CGI is unbelievable and there are more than a few breath-taking scenery shots(the mountains/the canyon/the river/dracula's castle etc.). Even and the music was ok!So why bash this movie ?!? If you expected more than it delivered, it's actually your fault, isn't it? Just admit that as summer action movies go, this one is OK (at the least), and stop trying to prevent people from going to see it - I'm sure I'm not the only one that finds this kind of flicks enjoyable.

Review title: Mmm, I didn't like it *Spoiler alert*
Review_body:
I apologize for all typos in advance! Again, this review contains many spoilers, so please don't read if you don't want to know. And, I really didn't like the movie, so there are a few (many) things in here which could be considered as mean. So, again, don't read if you cannot handle emotional criticism. The movie really frustrated me.Do yourself a favour, take the money you save for the ticket and treat your friends to dinner. Seriously, that was a bad movie. Period! Maybe I should stop here, mhhh, no!If it was meant as a bow to all the classic movies, they failed. A bow honors and maybe nodds with a twinge of irony but it does not try to copy. That is really the thing, they tried too hard to make it exactly like the classics but seemed to be very undecided if it should be parody or a serious remake. They took all the classic elements, threw them into a blender, fed the mix to a worm plagued dog and made the shit that came out into Van Helsing. (*that would be the mean part on my side)E.G. Dracula's brides were neither sexy nor overacting in a way that would count as a parody, they looked like the director dragged some gogo girls out of a cheap table dance bar and told them - be sexy, scary and uh, dunno, whiney?? And they did, except they tried to be that all the time and at once. The scene where V.H. gets his weapons is not even James Bond, its a Triple X copy except that it lacked the self-irony of the last mentioned. (and I grant XXX here more than it deserves, in my eyes)Here is my next question: was there a script?? If yes, please, Sommers, do the world a favor and transfer to stock exchange or tax attorney. I'm just trying to help. A plot somehow shined threw about one and a half hour into the picture but dissolved circa thirty seconds later. And the fact that I can't even remember what the plot thingy was, stands as a comment on its own. It seemed to me they cut together scenes from the classics without really thinking that it might puzzle or in my case bore the audience to death to see somebody or something falling from impossible height into a broad stream which happened about every fifth scene, they gave wolfie hell that way, but Igor got his share in the end. Now that I think about it, the movie would be perfect for a drinking game: take two drafts everytime somebody or something falls from a great height, take three if it falls into water. You would be dead drunk after an hour.Speaking of plot, Dracula's castle. The only entrance was in the gipsy's house and except for D. and his brides the rest were unable to fly. I wonder how they got the equipment to the place without looking a little suspicious. I see the track of little helpers trampling through the house: "Hello", "Hello", "Sorry about your carpet", "Hello". And you know what, if they had made it like this, I would have considered it funny, but they didn't. There were so many holes in the story, it makes a mash shirt look warm and cozy.
Dialogue *sort of: "Thank you" says Kate Beckinsale's character, with way too much make-up marring her otherwise pretty face, and the monster goes "AWWWWWW" with a look on its mask, that may have meant "Aw, nice" but somehow felt like "Aw, kick in the nuts". Which leads to the absence of, well, acting really. The actors either were to busy wondering "How the f*** did I end up in this crappy s***" or looked like "Have to fire my agent", I got this notion everytime Mr. Jackman's character fired his gun. And wasn't that character build up nicely or what: The Arcangel Gabriel lost his memory of who he is and turns into V.H., monster killer for all religions in the world and turns wolfman, kills his arc-nemesis and his lover *tackle - oh my, she  is dead awhooooooo - I laughed so hard* and than lights up a funreal fire, like a beacon in the night. And than came the clouds.. and I fell off my seat positively hysteric by then.I seriously hope the pay checks were obscenely high otherwise - go kill yourself or buy a shirt which says: "I was in Van Helsing and can still get a job in the industry...You want to touch me? I'm a miracle."
Granted, you don't go and see a picture like that for fine acting or the plot. The Special effects were in fact nice,.. except it was too much. Why did they even waste money on actors at all? And sorry, but if there are actors I expect at least some sort of acting and some sort of plot - both were hard to find in V.H.Not even David Wenham who was the only one who really tried and did good, could turn this movie around into a passable parody. I'm sorry for all lovers of the classics and I'm certainly sorry for the fine actors who were wasted in this crap. And I'm really sorry because I was forced to waste more than two hours of my life which I will never get back.

Being a big fan of Sommers two Mummy movies, I was really looking forward to this one.  The Mummy movies were poorly reviewed, as Van Helsing was, so I wasn't discouraged.  While I can't say the movie was bad, it wasn't great, I'm afraid.I think the great weakness of the film was that Sommers just had too much money to work with and didn't have to make any decisions.  If you listen to the director commentary for the Mummy and Mummy Returns, you hear him talk about the choices they had to make and the tricks they had to pull because of limited budgets.  I think Sommers did very well with those constraints. After seeing how he behaves on an essentially unlimited budget, I think he needs the constraints of a tight budget to be effective.As a general case in point, CGI was limited in the Mummy movies and Sommers comments on how much it cost to get effects shots done.  This time around, the effects shots are so numerous and overwhelming that they detract from the overall experience.  Instead of being there to advance the story, they are there to simply impress.  It's unfortunate, because the price paid is in plot and character development, of which there is sadly very little. There's just not enough substance to make a connection with Van Helsing and Anna, the way you do with O'Connel and Eve in the Mummy movies.I'd recommend this one as a rental.  I own the Mummy movies on DVD.  I don't expect this will be joining my DVD library when it comes out.

Review title: If you have seen one you have seen them all sort of...
Review_body: I think that the hype for this movie has billed more as a horror than it truly is.  Truth be told it comes off as a cross between Adams Family Values and Underworld at best.  Many of the effects are interesting but not necessarily appropriate.  Some of them threw off the time period of the movie especially the Frankenstein `monster'.  Then there is also the fact that the costumes are never right for the time period but this one took the cake, especially when it came to the Masquerade Ball costume of the sidekick.  Then there is the drawing from a thousand other films.  The Brides of Dracula rather reminded me of harpies as portrayed in other films. This film is at best a film for renting and watching when you are sick and tired of watching Friends or Buffy the Vampire Slayer.  Although I must say that I did see at a sneak preview and it was nice to not have to pay for it, even at the cheapest rental price.This isn't to say that it doesn't have entertainment value but I guess I have become spoiled over the years.  If you can handle a vampire ridden, Mark of the Rose-ish Melodrama then you are good to go.

I don't know why this film was doomed by critics and people. I am not talking about box office collection. This is one of the most underrated movies of its genre. I like this movie and I love huge jackman, plus supporting cast was good.I personally love this kind of tongue-in-cheek, change of the usual film.Maybe movies timing was bad, because pf spider man.If people looked at them more as just visually entertaining with a bunch of sharp one-liners, and tried to stop making them the next big action movie, or trying to read a life change message somewhere in there, they'd have more fun! I loved the real mix of actors appearing in this movie - I was straight to IMDb after watching it to see if I was right or wrong about who played who. I especially liked the straight-in beginning - no credit break to kill the run of the film. The black-and-white beginning, going to color soon after, was not new, but echoed nicely with the old Hollywood movies that the start was echoing. Altogether, a great fun watch.

Review title: The first scene was great, except for the rest of the movie
Review_body: Note: See Scorpion Kingsaying that, I have to say that the very first scene in B/W was absolutely fantastic.  I was so thrilled to see what was coming that I almost missed the entire movie because It was just bland.   No well developed plot twists or plot for that matter.  Hugh Jackman running around trying to kill dracula for two hours is not very entertaining when at the end,  he kills dracula. Kate Beckinsale was in the movie for some T and A  even though there were three other as gorgeous if not even better T and A already in the film. There's your ubiquitous comedic characters.  The lowly monk who gets sent into the field after been inside for his entire life.  Ends up helping to end this horrible film.my favorite part of the movie was when it ended.  not the end.  but just the last second that it ended.  I got to run out of the movie theatre as fast as my feet could take me.

A lot of people have criticised this film for being too cheesy and not loyal to the original characters, but I think it is one of the best films so far this year. I'm a big fan of classic monster movies, and director Steven Sommers has taken the best of the big bads and modernised them to make a great kick-ass actioner. The costumes are great (a certain Miss Beckinsale looked fabulous in those boots and corset), the sets were breathtaking (I won't spoil anything but those of you who have yet to see it, keep an eye out for Dracula's Masked Ball!) and the movie even succeeds in making the audience jump out of their seats several times. Well, it worked on me anyway!I only have one quibble and that is about the dialogue. Some of the lines are a little cringeworthy when heard, but there is always some great action sequence just round the corner to distract you. And though the characters don't exactly stay true to their legendary status (Sommers bent a few rules here and there) the movie still works well, and to be honest, I don't really care if it's not like the previous monster movies, and I'm sure many others won't either. Change is good, after all!In short, this is a great action adventure film that's fun and fast-paced, with added eye candy for both guys and girls! So damn the critics, go see Van Helsing, you'll love it! It's just pure entertainment!

Review title: Put a stake in this movie, PLEASE!
Review_body: Quite possibly the worst movie I've seen. Ever. Worse than LEAGUE OF EX GENTLEMEN, a movie that also really ticked me off. I went in hoping it would be fun, and be an homage, in a way, to the Universal films of the past. But no. VAN HELSING is a bloated, wasteful, soulless,bone-headed and arrogant mess - a perfect metaphor for everything that is wrong with the film industry, and, dare I say it? with our country today. Instead of loving and honoring its source material, this movie is disdainful of it, and uses lame, over the top,in-joke references from Aliens, Terminator, Rocky Horror, Star Wars, and yes, XMen to try to elicit humor. It is a noisy, shrieking, clanging, exploding CGI mess of a movie. God forbid there be any characters with any depth, or a plot that doesn't telegraph every cliche that it is about to commit, or that any iconic logic regarding Vampires, Werewolves or Frankenstein monsters be maintained. And it perpetrates perhaps the greatest sin of all - an annoying and completely uncompelling Dracula. And don't even get me started on the ending. OMG. The ending. People in the preview audience were HOWLING with laughter, it was so unutterably bogus. I am playing Hammer's HORROR OF DRACULA right now in an attempt to clear the miasmic haze of stupidity that VAN HELSING left in my brain.Peter Cushing, Chris Lee and Terence Fisher, we need you now, more than ever!

If you are a fan of the classic horror films, you will enjoy this film. Van Helsing does its work with its epic soundtrack, lively characters, and jaw-dropping special effects.  However, there are things wrong with it. The best way to give it an honest review is to break it up by its characters.
Van Helsing: Well portrayed, but the back story was rather choppy, and made little sense.  Anna: Kate Beckinsale makes a viewer fall in love with that face, body, and physicality.  The trailer does not give her justice--the accent is much improved.  Dracula: Richard Roxburgh had the opportunity to perhaps be ranked in the top 3 Draculas of all time.  Though, for what he had (another illogical storyline and at times lackluster lines), he did well.  His CGI was above average.  Frankenstein's Monster: An overdramatic portrayal by Shuler Hensley.  Get past that, and you have another fine character.  The Wolfman: Will Kemp is very good in his movements, but reminds the audience that this is his first hack at a big film.  Note: The CGI werewolf had me swearing and pounding everytime I saw it.  Carl: Whimsical, at times charming fellow.  Most would say he stole the show, but I will leave that for the werewolf.  The Brides: Sexy... gorgeous... vicious... well done.If the viewer can get by the director's overdone CGI (save the werewolf, of course), and choppy scripting... then you have a good film.  Dracula and Van Helsing's backstories are not well thought out. The Monster was a little over the top.  The werewolf will blow your mind. I'd see it twice, thrice... (Note: Dracula-fanatic reviewing the film)8/10.

Review title: Lighten up, kick back, and enjoy yourself!
Review_body: Something I seriously dig about Stephen Sommers: He's honest as a director and a writer.  In THE MUMMY RETURNS, Sommers dressed Brendan Fraiser in a leather jacket and Fedora as a response to critics of THE MUMMY that said Fraiser and Sommers were trying to be Indiana Jones. When he made THE SCORPION KING with WWF sensation, The Rock, over half the film included brawling or one-on-one fighting of some kind.  So with VAN HELSING, Sommers opens the film with an angry mob wielding pitchforks and torches. The first spoken dialogue: "It's alive! ALIVE!"  And finally, it's shot in black and white.Come on, folks, if you don't know EXACTLY what kind of movie you are about to get, then you are expecting way too much from VAN HELSING.This movie does not disappoint. It delivers exactly what it promises: a monster mash! Dracula.  The Wolfman.  Frankenstein.  Igor. This is a "Who's Who" of movie monsters, and while a story featuring so many Hollywood heavy-hitters could come across being contrived, Sommers cleverly works it all out in a tight little story.  Unlike HELLBOY which had so many plot holes (provided you could figure out where they were going with it) you could drive a battering ram through them, VAN HELSING unfolds the plot layer by layer and then takes you on a massive roller coaster ride with everyone hanging on for dear life. This movie will make you jump, it will make you laugh, and if you're not careful, it might put a lump in your throat.But Sommers, while doing all this, is being VERY HONEST as he does all this. Much in the same way PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN did not think itself anything other than a pirate movie based on a them park ride, VAN HELSING does not try to be anything else other than what it is at its core: a salute to monster movies. And not the over-the-top-gorefests like David Cronenberg's THE FLY, John Carpenter's THE THING, or any NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET offering...Sommer's salute are to the classics from Karloff, Chaney (Lon, not Dick), and Legosi.  There are also some nostalgic salutes to the classic Hammer House Films that featured Price, Lee (Christopher, not Bruce), and Cushing.  There is even a little nod to James Bond.  And while all this is going on, Sommers adds in dialog at the beginning of the film that clues you in...Igor (to Dr. Frankenstein): Master...you have been so very good to me, you have been so very kind...(points to Dracula) but HE pays me.This is your clue that this movie should not be taken seriously.VAN HELSING is coming under a lot of fire from both critics, moviegoers, IMDB users all screaming "it lacks originality" or "it's a mindless mess of special effects."  These are people who are approaching this film as you would approach Kenneth Branagh's FRANKENSTEIN or Francis Ford Coppola's DRACULA .  Approach VAN HELSING like that, and yes, you'll be sorely disappointed.  Approach VAN HELSING as you would ARMY OF DARKNESS or BIG TROUBLE IN LITTLE CHINA, and you'll have a ball.  Let MATRIX:RELOADED/REVOLUTIONS and HULK try to be important, poignant, and meaningful...VAN HELSING is a monster movie... ...and it's having a great time being one!

What in the world were they trying to do with this movie.  It was a great idea, and good action, but the dialog was absolutely horrendous.  "But you're suppossed to Die"  "But I want to Live"  "Okay."   It was either a 6 year old wrote this script or they didn't bother to write a script at all. I won't even get started on the incredible amount of errors in this movie. The writer/director might have well smack the viewer across the face with some of the mistakes they let slide. Needless to say I was extremely disappointed in this movie after looking forward to seeing it for some time. I can only hope that we will not see a sequal to this mistake. Or at least get a new writer and director who can actually do this good idea justice.

This movie is absolutely atrocious.  I had high hopes that Van Helsing would kick off the blockbuster season, but my hopes were dashed as I sat through this mindless drivel.  The movie was extremely disjointed and had too many things going on at one time.  As such, it seemed like they changed from scene to scene every couple of minutes which never allowed any part of the storyline develop satisfactorily.  With such a poor script, the actors were working at a major disadvantage from the outset.  Hugh Jackman (X-Men, X-Men 2) did as well as he could in the title role, but this movie was so poorly plotted and written that no actor had any hope of saving it.  Kate Beckinsale (Brokedown Palace, Underworld) portrays Jackman's love interest, gypsy princess Anna Valerious.  Beckinsale's role appeared to be to walk around in a tight leather outfit and to talk in a horribly stereotypical "gypsy" accent.  Richard Roxburgh (Mission Impossible:2, Moulin Rouge) plays a horribly ineffective Dracula.  Roxburgh's Dracula comes across as wimpish and not as the embodiment of evil that past movie Draculas have been. David Wenham (Lord of the Rings) is horribly miscast as Van Helsing's assistant, Carl.  The only saving grace of this film is its use of CGI to create visually stimulating scenery and monsters.  If the film had been written and produced by a Hollywood novice, I could understand.  However, Stephen Sommers wrote 1999's The Mummy which is one of my favorite films.  Of course, taking into consideration that I was disappointed with his follow-up efforts in The Mummy Returns and The Scorpion King, I shouldn't be surprised.  I give Van Helsing a meager rating of 1.5 out of 5 stars. Save your money for some of this summer's upcoming films and wait for Van Helsing to hit video if you really must see it at all.

This movie has exactly two good thingies in it: the talent of Hugh Jackman and the nice looks of Kate Beckinsale. The rest - well, no story, awful effects...I should have spended the money elsewhere. For a movie that was that expensive it looks like a B-Movie. It also feels like one. It was a great idea somehow. To bring all the old monsters together, against a newish Van Helsing. Besides him, a beautiful lady with a real task. But the director wasn't able to do anything good with the script which as well was full of holes. If there just were good special effects, then i would have said, great action movie. But even this failed. The guys of ILM didn't have their best day at all.

Review title: shoulda woulda coulda been A LOT better
Review_body: Don't go into this movie expecting much. In all honesty I'd wait for DVD or cable. There's not much here except for eye candy: even that looks like it belongs more in a video game rather than a movie screen. The movie tries very hard to weave together subplots and to build some amount of compassion for the characters but fails miserably. Comparisons to last year's equally disappointing League of Extraordinary Gentlemen are not far off. Both films lack substance and rely mainly on flashy visuals and predictible stories to occupy their audience's time. A lone high is the film's opening, which only serves to make the rest of the movie an even bigger disappointment. A big letdown of a summer movie but not all that surprising given that writer/director Stephen Sommers is also responsible for the equally vapid Mummy movies.2/10 (2 points for a rather decent opening sequence)

Review title: Gorgeous special effects and rareness in transformation
Review_body: I don't know why people gave it such a bad rating. I don't recall a lot of movies that have pushed the transformation process of Dracula from it's human form to it's vampiric form. Nor have we seen a human transform to a werewolf with tearing flesh. And the final fight where Van Helsing as a werewolf transforms from one another and Dracula constantly transforming is just well done. Oh, and did I mention that this is NOT done in dark environments like any other such movies? We actually SEE in full light the transformation process of human to beast! It loosed it's points for the music and the outside churchy story but the rest was just fun to watch and, and I bought the blu-ray disc so that closes it pretty much!

Review title: Saw a Sneak Preview - Loved it - Load of fun.
Review_body:
1. Oscar caliber?  No.2. Enjoyable? Yes.3. Special FX are better than Spider-Man or Hulk, which is surprising considering the budget the other 2 movies undoubtedly had.
4. Cool ass monsters?  Yes.5. Scary?  Not really, but there are about 3 scenes that will make the entire audience jump.6. You know how most summer blockbusters, like The Mummy, show you too much in the trailer, and when you see the movie, you feel as though you've already seen the cool parts?  Not the case with Van Helsing.  Even though we have been inundated with trailers, they have wisely left out a LOT.
7. Jackman? Awesome.8. And thank GOD he doesn't use martial arts.  I'm kind of sick of EVERY vampire hunter knowing Tae kwon do.  And the only thing worse than the vampire hunter knowing TKD, is when the vampires he's hunting know it as well.9. Does Beckinsale redeem her incredibly beautiful self from Underworld? Believe it or not yes.  She is good in this.10. Every humorous moment is actually HUMOROUS, and the entire theater will erupt in laughter, almost to the point where you miss the next line because of the noise.  Now that is well timed humor.11. Is Frankenstein cheesy?  Only in the trailers.  You will be surprised at how cool he is.12. Same with the Wolf Man.  He looks like a goofy CGI cartoon, but once you see him in action, he's a little creepy, and the end result is, it works.Chances are, if you're even CONSIDERING going to see it, you will like it. You already know what it's about.  The plot is pretty good, but by no means is it tight.  But who cares?  It's fun enough to enjoy.

Review title: more than 2 hours non stop action
Review_body: First I want to say that it is rather unique that a movie is shown in the Netherlands before it is even released in the U.S. , even though it is just for 2 days. I just got out of the cinema and I am still feeling the adrenaline rush into my veins. There is not even a single moment of rest in this movie. Just when you think that Hugh (Jackman) and Kate (Beckinsale) can rest for a bit after being chased by some vampires, another monster appears before them. Don't go to this movie for the story, see it because of the awesome special effects. I just wish there was a little more gore in it. In such a movie as this a bit more gore would be appropriate. Unfortunately Sommers made this movie PG 13.

I was really looking forward to this - it sounded like it had all the ingredients for a fantastic monster movie. Saw it on Thursday preview night - couldn't wait. What a waste of time! The ideas were there, and there was the glimmer of the movie it might have been shining through from time to time, but for the most part I laughed with incredulity at how poorly it was executed. The CGI was terrible, the design of the monsters left an awful lot to be desired, and there was no dialogue or characterisation beyond what was necessary to move on to the next "big set-piece". I can't believe actors of the quality of Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale were wasted so completely on roles which did not require them to act. Somebody stop Stephen Sommers from making movies - or at least stop me going to see them - please.

I am a long-time fan of horror movies, and I like Hugh Jackman.  The previews for this film looked pretty good, and the premise sounded interesting as well: monster hunter takes on some of film's most notorious bad guys.  I figured this would be a fun ride, so I plunked down my cash for an opening-day matinee.  I wish I hadn't....Unfortunately, Van Helsing is one of the worst films I've seen in years. The plot is surprisingly uninspired, character development is weak, and the major conflict of the story is so dull that I couldn't wait to get out of the theater.  The action is like a bad video game, packed so full of miraculous stunts and escapes that it is utterly absurd.  Any sense of tension when the main characters face monsters is lost fairly early in the film and never recovers.  Halfway through the movie I was checking my watch and counting down the minutes left in this 2 1/2 hour long disaster.Was anything good?  Well, some of the special effects were OK.  There were a couple funny lines.  That's probably about it.  Frankly, it's not even worth a rental.  Save your money, or use it for a better breed of horror film like Bram Stoker's Dracula or even Fright Night.

Tonight, I saw possibly the most artistically barren movie ever. Why was this movie made? The acting was flat, the story line practically non-existent, and there was zero chemistry between the characters, especially the male and female leads. Not that the actors had much to do. The CGI effects completely dominated and doomed every scene. With every explosion, every hideous metamorphosis, every miraculous near-miss, I kept thinking, "Well, there's another ridiculously expensive special effect that adds nothing to the movie." After a few minutes of this, I started dozing off. IMDb readers, don't waste your time or money on this. If you crave CGI effects, watch "Pirates of the Caribbean". At least that movie had a story, good acting, characters you cared about, and benefited from the special effects. "Van Helsing" looked like a 2-hour CGI sales pitch for rich investors. Zero stars.

1) Somers seemed confused as to whether he wanted serious or campy. Within the first minute I found myself singing "Puttin on the Ritz" ala Young Frankenstein.2) Kate Beckinsale and Richard Roxburgh both OVER-ACTED their little hearts out.  C'mon guys, you weren't doing Hamlet.3) Dracula's brides........like nails on a chalk board.4) The story itself?  More holes than a dozen donuts.There was some beautiful cinematography and I got a great scare when Van Helsing was initially confronted by Mr. Hyde but other than that, it's difficult to find anything positive to say about this flick.

Stupid plot, Bad script, Bad makeup, Bad acting, Bad accents and 2ndrate special effects. It is truly unclear as to what they were looking to do with this mishmash. why was it ever green lighted. I hope that Sommers goes back to writing and leaves the directing to grown-ups next time. He even managed to make the lovely and talented Kate Beckinsdale look like a low-rent B movie actress. I'm sure Jackman got big bucks for this, but his agent should be fired. Please stick to Wolverine. I hope the study exec who authorized this one is back fetching coffee for the suits. The money would have been better served going to charity.

This movie, quite simply, is the worst movie I'd ever seen.  Some people have made comparisons between this one and "League of Extraordinary Gentlemen."  Let me tell you that 'League' is a masterpiece compared to this movie.Hugh Jackman actually does a pretty good job, by himself.  Everyone else just reeks of overacting.  It's not necessarily their fault either, as I'd be more inclined to blame the horrible script.  The first hour is simply bad, and after that it only gets better because you've already invested that first hour; might as well see how it ends.This movie fits the definition of "mindless action" to a 'T'  Go spend your time, and your money, somewhere else.

It's one of the most action movie I ever seen.This stories takes,always us to a time of fantasy with monsters and heroes.The fantastic work of the actors with the story makes this movie one of most entertaining movie such like last action hero.My vote is only 9 in 10, because I would like to see more,like a squeal and is always possible to see better, but in this case I doubt.The weapons,and the atmosphere of Transylvania is other beautiful thing to the movie, with castles and the endless battle between the good and evil.

I saw the movie yesterday and i have to say i hated it. The dialogs were crap an the special Effects looked like in a computer game.I thought Hugh Jackman will be good in the role of van Helsing but he looked and talked like 3rd class actor. Also the performance of Richard Roxburgh as Dracula was laughable, thought he he should be scary, sexy, and intimidating but i thing he is nothing of these things.There are so many more things i hated in the movie:Kate Beckinsale as Anna Valerious, David Wenham as Carl, Shuler Hensley as Frankenstein's Monster, Elena Anaya as Aleera, Will Kemp as Velkan, Kevin J. O'Connor as Igor, Alun Armstrong as Cardinal Jinette, Silvia Colloca as Verona, Josie Maran as Marishka,
and the whole story.
So one thing.Don't watch this movie.

Van Helsing was a man who couldn't recall his past. Working for the Vatican, he has to hunt down supernatural creatures and it is to Hugh Jackmans' credit that Van Helsings' reticence at killing these once human beings came across.The rest of the cast are good, particularly David Wenham as Karl, Gabriel Van Helsings' Friar sidekick. The banter between the two characters provides the many funny parts of the film. Karl is also the provider of the gadgetry and weaponry used by his friend Van Helsing.Richard Roxburgh surprised me. Before seeing the film I thought he was badly cast as Dracula, but his performance was a mixture of mad, aristocratic menace and camp egomaniac. The role actually seemed to suit him.Kate Beckinsale was the feisty heroine. As Anna Valerious her ancestry indicated a long-standing vendetta with Dracula. She thinks she can handle things on her own, but after seeing Van Helsing in action, she reluctantly agrees the Van Helsing can remain in her town and eventually, together, they set about "vanquishing evil".Will Kemp as the Wolf Man didn't really have much to do with the role, except writhe acrobatically about, which was a shame. I would've liked to have seen more screen time given to both the Wolf Man and Shuler Hensley as Frankensteins' Monster. Although Frankensteins' creation was supposed to be a "monster", he was in fact quite the opposite, an emotional and sympathetic character.The sets were very atmospheric, dark, gloomy and Gothic, perhaps a tribute by the Director Stephen Sommers to the old Hammer Horror films?The only thing I would've changed about the film? Well, at times, it felt like the film was trying to cram too much in. It would've been nice to have a plot that was less crowded and maybe that would've allowed for some interesting development of the characters.Yes, there are a lot of things that could've been done differently, but I enjoyed Van Helsing. It's a film that is funny, scary, action-packed thrilling and entertaining all rolled into one.

Review title: Dracula wasn't the only thing that sucked
Review_body: The first thing I can say about VAN HELSING, is that for the first time I have witnessed a side effect of vampirism  not only do they suck the blood off of you, they also suck your acting skills. What was Sommers thinking when he casted that group of community-theatre z graded actors, who cannot even maintain the same accent for more then one scene? The name of the title should be VAN HELSING  ADVENTURES IN OVER ACTING. It was the first time a fantasy movie can be accused of bigotry  the use of monsters stereotypes was borderline racism! What's wrong with some originality, why not try to, I don't know, something that wasn't done for a gazillion times? Couldn't Sommers find a new perspective for an already repeated Dracula/Frankenstein/Were-wolf story and outline? He did such a great job with THE MUMMY, why didn't he take the same great formula he had and just transferred the monster plot to it? For god sake, they didn't even a little bit of comic relief  nothing to ease the pain! You just cannot maintain a PG monster movie with absolutely no blood and gore without something for the soul! The lack of humorous relieves, combined with a bland story line that features nothing new, added to one of the most bad and ridicules acting performances (I am talking especially to you Kate Beckinsale and Richard Roxburgh), and you have one of the worst movies ever made, a stale experience at best, with a lesson to be learned for future directors  CGI is not a substitute for a plot or for acting quality. If I want to see that  I'll go play a game on my PS. I can only hope Dracula didn't see that movie, because if he saw it, I'm sure he'd want revenge. 8.5 on OMEGA DOOM Scale.

Review title: Van Helsing meets lots of other movies
Review_body: Don't read if you want to keep all the surprises. *little spoiler alert*Great movie if you like the scared by surprise effect. In Van Helsing we see the Mr. G van Helsing as a lean mean vampire ass-kicking fighting machine. There are a lot of questions in my head after seeing this movie like:-Where have I heard before something like the bad guy's father is the good guy? (I thought it was the other way around somewhere in a galaxy far far away...)-Same moviesixtology; since when do we always burn the bodies of dead people? (Qui-Gon Jinn it was if I remember correctly. A pity ending for Ms Beckinsale.)Wasn't there another movie in which the good guy had the ring of the bad guy, while the bad guys ring finger was chopped off? (In both the bad guy won't get it back by the way...)And so on, and so on.You should really go for the effects, it is quite a shooting, hooters helicopters-film, only no helicopters... guess they weren't invented yet then.But in stead you get loads of other flying thingies.

I was very reluctant to see this film, but my family dragged me off to see it(It was better than the other option- Scooby Doo 2). However, I was drawn into it immediately, and rooting for Van Helsing all the way. I loved Dracula, his wives were incredible, Anna was awesome, and Van Helsing? Well, let's just say that my previous love for Hugh Jackman has intensified tenfold. I will buy this on DVD as soon as it comes out! Go See It! It's Incredible, and the stunts are soooo cool! Kate Beckinsdale, who I haven't really seen much with her in, was such a cool Anna, and I loved her interactions with Van Helsing.

You'd think it would be impossible for Stephen Sommers to sink lower than the cinematic abomination that was The Mummy Returns, but somehow, he's done it - this endless barrage of phony CGI effects is a tough slog to get through. The effects (particularly the animation of Dracula's brides and the werewolves) are atrocious, but the shockingly poor animation of Mr Hyde at the beginning made the Hyde from League Of Extraordinary Gentlemen seem like Gollum. This basically comes off as a poor mans League, right down to Richard Roxburgh prancing about as a hammy villian. Hugh Jackman is okay, but less charismatic than usual - and Kate Beckinsale is wasted in a role that again requires her to do little more than pout and look pretty (that's pretty much all she did in Pearl Harbor and Underworld). But it's really Sommers who should take the blame for this - relying too much CGI and ridiculous action scenes that never seem remotely real (especially the carriage chase scene) that you really don't care. I'm all for a good, dumb, tongue-in-cheek blockbuster (the first Mummy was one of the best in recent years) but I really hope that this isn't where this type of film is going - movies that are little more than souless video games.

Easily one of the worst movies that I have recently seen. Good effects, but every movie has good effects nowadays. Terrible plot, terrible acting/script, and it was SO long. This one ranks with the "League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" as one of the biggest bombs I have seen. There was not much plot development and the story seemed to jump a bit. However, when good met bad, the scenes took FOREVER. It seemed like Dracula just kept getting away and the movie kept going. Dracula seemed to be a bit too campy and Frankenstein was one of the wimpiest/most sensitive monsters I have ever witnessed. If this was Hugh Jackman's chance to make it as a leading actor, then he certainly picked the wrong film!

This movie was absolutely awful. When Hollywood is set to invest 160 million dollars in a project one would imagine some small fraction of that would be spent on a decent script....evidently not. Everthing...the look, characters, and plot points of this film are lifted from other, better movies. The director seemed to feel that no exposition was necessary, we would all go along with whatever preposterous premise he chose to splash on screen. So the fact that Van Helsing is part of a secret organization headquartered at the Vatican which employs Buddhist monks and Muslim mullahs didn't need any explaining, it passes by with barely a mention so that we can get to the next chase scene. It all went down hill from there. YAWN!!!I left the theater feeling I had been duped by the Hollywood spin machine into spending my hard-earned money on drivel.

What in the name of all that is sacred was that about? The company is only interested in getting a bigger audience(reducing the certificate, hence depriving us of what could have been a decent, if certainly not great monster movie), Stephen Sommers - he made Stargate, didn't he?, Hugh Jackman wants to be the next Bond so badly he obviously couldn't wait, Kate Beckinsale should start acting at some point in her life (what with Pearl Harbour, Underworld and now this), Richard Roxburgh tries too hard ... and I could go on. Apart from that, all the questions brought up by the screenplay are left unanswered (I won't reveal anything), the dialogue is plain awful, and to be honest the whole premise in which the movie is based is preposterous - I can't believe the Vatican hasn't reacted. As for the special effects, I seem to be the only one that noticed the blue screen pretty much throughout the whole movie. And, what's with the music? Could be the most irritating score in (and for)a long time - certainly not what I expected from Alan Silvestri. I tried to sleep through it, and I couldn't, so I decided to wait and see if something good would come (it does, without revealing anything, it's the wolf man transformation), then I tried to get my money back, but working in a cinema myself, I never paid in the first place, so now I am aiming to sue all the parts involved for emotional distress. The worst movie in history? Surely not. But pretty close, nonetheless.

Review title: Glad I didn't pay to see it!
Review_body: This movie was soooo hokey. The characters, the special effects, even the story line was hard to follow. It definitely didn't live up to the hype. Even Hugh Jackman couldn't save this one. My only thought as I watched the movie was, "I'm glad I didn't pay to see it in the theater or I would be upset at the waste of money."Thank Goodness I have a Blockbuster Pass and so this really was a "free" movie. I would have hated to spend a nickel on this one. The ONLY good thing was that Hugh Jackman had a cool costume, and one of his weapons was pretty cool too. The acting and dialogue were horrid, clunky and all around bad. This is a razzie contender for sure.

one of the best films i've seen in years. I took my mum to see it in may for her birthday and she loved it. The effects were amazing and jackmans portrayal of Van Helsing was brilliant. The man is a natural. Some of his fight scenes reminded me of him as wolverine in x-men. The atmosphere in the cinema was amazing. Van Helsing has such a dry sense of humour. When Helsing turned into the werewolf then back again all the women in the cinema had to catch their breath as it's not every day you see jackman in shammy leather. Jackman even did the voice over the animated film. I hope there will be a sequel to this as i will be first in line to see it.

Review title: van helsing is an action packed spectacle with basic story.
Review_body: I watched van helsing at the cinema after the mixed reviews my expectations were it should be enjoyable at the least, boy was i suprised it sets itself up very quickly and then on with the effects packed setpieces which are fab. if you enjoy comic strip style cgi action movies with plot that is kept to a minimum, but enough to get you envolved this is top notch popcorn cinema. hopefully sequels will follow as i have no doubt this will clean up at the box office, hugh jackmans acting skills are hardly stretched in the movie and richard roxbura is camp but a pretty good dracula, mimics gary olddman a little though. go see have fun.

ahh so bad.. even worse than charlies angels full throttle. if you haven't seen this movie DON'T! don't waste your money it's soooo awful. there was barely a plot, everything was stolen from other stories and some things were wrong(like who the real Dracula was). and, to top it all off, the "vampires" looked like marilyn manson! i couldn't even believe that it was the worst movie ever(but it was) because i've seen some pretty terrible movies. DON'T go see it, you'll be sorry if you do. and i didn't even get a refund for leaving in the first half hour because i thought it would get better. my friend and i had to spend the next hour and a half or so that it dragged on talking about how retarded it was. so don't see it.

Review title: A must see and a must buy when it comes to DVD / Video
Review_body: Even though I was doubtful in the very beginning of the movie before even setting foot inside the theater. I sat there and took it to mind to look at it as in the whole. As the movie begain and took on giving the viewer the information and jist of everything that was happening. One moment I was like okay... slap-stick hummor, but... but then; it's like 'holly *&%^#'... I jumped here and there even though you could just guess what was going to happen. The music of the moive, the effects, the story line, everything was well worth every penny of it, and I'm even going to see it a second time next week !!Thumbs up all the way!!

I must say I was really disappointed in this film. I can't say that it was a complete waste of time but it certainly wasn't what it could have been.There were simply way too many attempts at "cuteness" in the movie. The little comedic moments occurred far too frequently and seemed forced. The frankenstein monster was more reminiscent of Young Frankenstein than of the monster of the classic sense. In fact, the opening scene of the movie made me think I was watching a Mel Brooks moment. The little window with the neon lights over the monsters heart would have been more appropriate in a Wizard of Oz remake.Jackman did a respectable job and I thought Beckinsale delivered a good performance as well. Roxburgh unfortunately was one of the most unbelievable Draculas I've yet to see and Igor looked more like Nick Nolte's mug shot from his DUI.What was up with Mr. Hyde? That was possibly the worst part of the film. Whoever thought a 10 foot tall Incredible Hulk clone was a good choice to model Mr. Hyde after should seriously be looking for a career change.Okay, maybe I was wrong. Maybe it WAS a complete waste of time.

Review title: Badly written, badly directed and badly played.
Review_body: The movie consist of constant stream of rip offs, in fact it is similar to Scary Movie, except the lack of humor.Firstly the manuscript seems to be the first draft of something, maybe about vampires nobody really knows. The story is inconsistent, mixed-up and with no hesitancy to use stereotypic techniques to underline the story.Secondly, the directing is based on making lots of cool scenes without any content. You have it all: Large castles, mountains high and valleys deep, a sequence with a masquerade ball - of course with no really meaning. Fight scenes that last longer than a big box with pop corn.Thirdly, the acting is unbelievably poor, especially Kate Beckinsale - it is unbelievable how bad the accent is; in addition the she comes out and says this stupid things again and again during the movie.
Critics are robots. Silly and fun haven't been programmed into them yet

It wasn't that worse like many wrote. It was a typical Steven Sommers film. A lot of FX, many action, nice beauties trying to act and a more or less acceptable story line. I think, the worst thing was the syncro into german, or some silly dialogues. But, there were also some good things to mention: The end was surprisingly, the characters are interesting and overall it was a good pop-corn-movie but only a second class film. I was a little bit disappointed about some silly parts, especially the questions "Why Count Dracula tried to get children?" or "Why only the Wolf Man can kill the Count?" or even why the story of Van Helsing's past hasn't been answered completely. Perhaps, there will be some answers in a sequel?...It has failed to be as good as "The Mummy" (my quote: 8/10), but it wasn't really disappointing.7/10

The movie Van Helsing starring Hugh Jackman, who has had a pretty good career so far by doing such films as X-Men, X2 and even Kate & Leopold, fails miserably to impress even a monster loving enthusiast like myself. The story gives no respect to the actual historical events and connects three different stories of Wolfman, Frankenstein's monster and Dracula into a mixture that no one should have to swallow, if they haven't already. I'm starting to feel nausious. There is much to say about the movie from fail-to-impress script to the misfortunate directing job done by Stephen Sommers etc etc.... I personally could not believe how many times I wanted to get out of my seat and leave thinking that someone out there has approved such an atrocity to be released as a motion picture. Life is unfair and so are the previews that made this movie seem decent enough for an evening out. Au contraire mon frére! I will go now and forget all about this sad, sad night. Thanks for ruining not one, but three different fairytales. Anyone sees Stephen out, do let him know! Two thumbs waaaaaaaaaaay down for Van Helsing. Hugh, what were you thinking?

Granted this movie was not as great as it could have been--the vampire teeth were cheesy and the wicked witch of the west laugh got old--it was still a good movie, based on the tradition of the monster movie.  Considering Bella Lugosi worked with rubber bats on strings, this movie is a lot better. For those of you who hated it-did you actually watch it or are you being obnoxious and just making posts?  And if you did hate it that bad, why did you stay for the whole thing.  The fight with Jekyll should have tipped you off as to what kind of movie it was going to be...and yes, I do think there will be a follow up movie, but it will more than likely be a prequel as there is more material to work with there.

WHAT IN THE WORLD HAPPENED!????I know what happened, reviewers have lost it. I cannot believe some, excuse me, most of these reviewers, what they said about this movie. This movie was a great movie! It had all the action, story(looks like some were to thickheaded to get it!), great CG, and so on, that you could want. I applaud the designers of set, costume, makeup and so forth.(too many to name) I just don't get these people's problem? This movie was not "cheesy" like some said. I'll say again it was great! You know some people think movies are supposed to make sense(by the way, other than actors/actresses being thrown against walls,etc. and getting right back up, IT DID MAKE SENSE!) that's NOT I REPEAT NOT, what Hollywood's about!Hollywood's only for a dollar and that's all most care about.I REPEAT I'm in "Unbelief City" because of what these reviewers said about this movie!(but hey thats your opinion and this is mine: I DON'T CARE WHAT Y'ALL SAY BECAUSE I LOVED THIS MOVIE, LOVED IT WITH A PASSION!)

This Movie is awesome. I love it. The computer graphics weren't as good as I thought they would be but the story was amazing and interesting. One of my favorite characters was Carl. He was great and hilarious. My folks and I thought it was an 11 out of 10. The one problem with this whole story is that when I was coming out of the theater, people didn't get some parts like who Van Helsing really was ( which i got) and why only a werewolf can hurt the Count (Which I got)? So other than that, good job. The actors did a great job, but the whole vampire thing was over doing it. For example, the baby thing was over doing it and the death scene of one of the characters was so fake.

Review title: Good action....But the story is weak at best
Review_body: The Story is weak, predictable. The Action and SFX were good, but thats all this movie had going for it. There were corny scenes like every ten minutes. Richard Roxburgh was a horrible Dracula, Kate Beckinsale did not give a good performance. Hugh Jackman was okay. If you are looking for a good vampire movie with action, blade and blade II are good. Angel the TV series is good. Interview with a Vampire is excellent.If you wanna see this movie for its action, see it, but don't count on the story. If you want a movie with story, check out man on fire, an excellent movie.

Review title: Better than I thought and I'm not a monster movie person.
Review_body: I just saw this at the New York premiere.  Stephen said we were the first audience to see the final version and I have to say, it is pretty good. I'm not a monster movie person, generally, but the story and effects were good enough to overcome that.  Unlike the Matrix, the effects didn't look like a Playstation game or overdone.  There are elements of an Indiana Jones battles Dracula vibe, but not plotwise.  There weren't many slow parts as the action seemed to role right along with the story without seeming forced. There is a bit of James Bond technogagetry involved and similarly delivered through a comical character, whose lines throughout the story add a little balance to the monster genre.

Van Helsing was an entertaining movie from start to finish. That is all I ask of a movie. Dracula, Frankenstein and The Wolfman all make appearances. Hugh Jackman is great as the tough guy monster fighter. Of course he's had plenty of practice in the first two X-Men movies. Kira Knightly can no longer complain about wearing a corset after seeing the outfit, Kate Beckinsale is forced to wear throughout the show. I have heard that Universal wants to make a franchise out of this movie. Luckily for us, this move isn't made like that. It is a complete story not a set-up for future ones like the first Spiderman. Go to this movie and you will have fun. Unless you are a stuffy movie snob that feels that a movie must be moving, touching, and/or thought provoking to be good. Have a swell day.

I enjoyed this movie a lot. Great effects, cool story the locations was spectacular. Hugh Jackman does a great job as the"Indiana Jones" of vampire hunters. Kate Beckinsale has incredible carisma and really givesHugh a good fight for leading role. She did a excellent role in Underworld and she is also perfect in Van Helsing. This movie is meant to be fun and entertaining, it` s not a classic but, hey, so what? One critic, i would like to have seen some other actor playing the role as Dracula.

Review title: the worst movie i have ever seen
Review_body: i don't even know where to begin. the acting was terrible. the plot horrific. a slug keeps a faster pace than this movie. Dracula was horrible. the sidekick dude was worse than jar-jar binks. frankenstein is an amateur existentialist after being alive for a few weeks. if you like this movie you are a sad sick person. this movie made me want to quit living. and by the way i did not see it on my own, my family and i have a tradition at Christmas time that we buy the worst movies we can think of that we have not seen and we sit around and make fun of them. its kind of like a mystery science theatre 3000. i knew this movie was bad but i had no idea it was this bad. i don't know how this is not on the top 100 worst movies because it is clearly worse than TRON or even BattleFieldEarth.

Review title: Either too much romance for a horror/action movie, or too much horror for a romantic film.
Review_body: Van Helsing is a great movie for horror/action buffs.  The special effects are top notch, and the storyline is easy to become immersed in.  Will Kemp's acting seemed over-dramatic in some scenes, but his role was integral to the plot.  Richard Roxburgh does a great job in his role as Dracula, making the Count an easy character to hate.  Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale shine in their roles.  However, the gratuitous romance scenes seemed out of place. The cast of characters (monsters) are well though out, and mesh with the story well.  Some comedy is thrown in, but not too much - just enough to get a chuckle every so often. The end leaves something to be desired in my opinion, but this is definitely a movie worth watching!

Review title: do not waste your time or money
Review_body: Please heed this advice: UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SEE VAN HELSING. Not as a matinee, not as a rental and not for free. I know what you are thinking, it's what I thought, how bad ultimately can it be? REALLY REALLY AWFUL THAT'S HOW BAD IT CAN BE! And, for those of you who are now saying to yourselves, if it's that bad it might be fun to watch you are wrong. This isn't like Ross Hunter's musical remake of Lost Horizon which was fascinating in it's badness, it's just stupid. It's not even worth watching for the action or the effects, they suck too. Why is it so bad? Hmmh. There is no plot, no dramatic arc, no interesting characters, no interesting character interaction, no redeeming good performance by one solitary actor and shot after shot after shot was cribbed from other films including Alien 3, Alien, Terminator, The Killer, etc etc etc. It is not even an homage to the old Universal films. It's obvious that the "writer/director" (I use those words because technically that was what Stephen Sommers was hired to do) had nothing but contempt for those films, and a complete misunderstanding of what makes those films work, or he couldn't have possibly made this film based on them. He gave Frankenstein's creation the power of speech to make him a whining self martyring pain in the ass. Vampires can walk around in the day time. A werewolf would turn back into a human if there is passing cloud cover over the moon, no really cloud cover, a Vampire hunter who can shoot hundreds of arrows and not hit a moving target in the heart, another vampire hunter who never carries stakes or any weapon that can destroy a vampire and cannot fend off a vampire by herself, and a village full of people living under the constant threat of being a vampire's next meal, who when they hear the sound of hundreds of beating wings at night, go outside en masse to see what's there!

Just got back from seeing van helsing, it was awesome, I don't understand why some of the critics didn't like it. It had action and a lot of suspense. It was like the mummy but with twice the action.From the beginning I knew this was an action adventure movie and treated it as such. The action started from the beginning of the movie and just kept going, stopping just long enough for me to catch my breath. Don't expect a movie a deep movie with lots of dialogue and character development but rather expect rollercoaster fun with the movie.With the wolfman on his back and the brides of dracula attacking him from the air makes you wonder why is it so hard to kill him.Even a dracula that can't be killed by stakes through the heart, holy water or crosses is no match for Van Helsing.The special effects on this movie was better than movies in the same category just watch the final sequence as proof.

Review title: I wish I had never seen this movie...
Review_body: Recipe for a movie...several well known monsters - some beautiful women in "boy get here" clothes - some nicely done background. - a grotesque story line - dummy dialogue - bad actingMix everything in your blender and press the start button, you've got Van Helsing.At first I though the idea could generate a really nice movie if it would have been done with some intelligence but this is not the case. Despite the nice introduction sequence the whole things turn out of control with "Dracula meets Frankenstein meets Aliens". You can't just add characters like this togeter and hope it will work.

It was good, they had good effects and Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale did good but Richard Roxburgh didn't. He was trying to make his accent to much like the original Dracula instead of making his own. Now to the effects. The effects were very good although the movie relied on it too much but it still made Van Helsing a good movie. The female vampires were really scary by the way. The lines were also not very good because they mixed our time with the time in the movie. And also in near the end when the moon was blocked and Hugh Jackman turned back into a man Dracula didn't kill him or even run away like he was trying to do when Hugh was still a wolf, that part didn't make sense at all. Also didn't you notice that when Van Helsing was a wolf he was bigger than all the other ones, that also didn't make sense. Thats all I have to say, It was good but not really good, because it was actors versus the effects, and lets face it some of the actors didn't do too good but Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale compensated for that. That's why it is only good and not really good.

Review title: The Best I've seen this year so far(some spoilers)
Review_body: If you like movies like Lord of The Rings, X2, Matrix, etc, especially a fan of Vampires, you'll definitely love this movie, I personally rate it 4.5/5, its CGI doesn't lose out to movies like X-men and Spiderman, and the plot has lotsa twists, the only few parts that's kinda is the clothes of the Vampires changes with their body.. =S, some parts are a little too fast that u cant catch the story, but overall, it's a reeeaaallyy great movie, the creatures are brilliant and Dracula's brides are really cool, I esp like de part when Kate Beckinsale says "Next time when you kill people, don't talk so much"  2004 doesn't have many movies that makes people cant-wait-to-see it, unlike 2003's Matrix and LOTR, but this is definitely one of the best I've seen this year, and Hellboy, supposedly its 'nemesis', p-a-l-e-s in comparison

Badly acted, too much CGI, no heart, this a laughable poor mans The Mummy Returns.The audience laughed at all the wrong bits, particularly at the end which was supposed to be the most emotional part of the movie.At two hours, this could have been cut by at least 45 minutes as it drags on too long.From the opening scenes, you can see how bad this is.Dracula himself is as scary as Dale Winton, Frankenstein's monster is camp, only the werewolves are any good.The main problem with Van helsing is that it takes itself too seriously, and this can't be backed up by the CGI or the script.Either it should have been made as a kick ass scary 15 cert, or as a PG.With a 12 certificate it flounders in no mans land.The only saving graces are Kate and Hugh who do their best with a script which is, at best, apaling!Avoid like the plague!

Review title: LXG vs X-Men vs Underworld vs James Bond
Review_body: The movie didn't live up to the hype whatsoever.  To boot, it also reeked of last years Summer movies.If you take LXG, X-Men, any James Bond movie, and Underworld, put them in a bag and shake, you get Van Helsing.There was very little in the movie that was original, and there was very little in the movie that was memorable.Once again, we see Kate Beckinsale fighting supernatural creatures.The special effects were good, the plot was non-existant and the characters forgetful.  After the hype, I was expecting this to be a new path for future Van Helsing movies, but, I think i'd skip the others.This definately one to wait for on DVD.

I just LOVED this movie !!! it had lots of action and i truly enjoyed it !! i love Hugh Jackman and he did a Wonderful job !! it would be worth your while and your money to see this movie , even if you arent a Hugh Jackman fan , it is a great movie , it was scary and it had very good special effects .. it is a totally awesome movie !!! it deserves more than a 10/10 !!! Hopefully if there is a sequel to this movie i will Definitely be the first in line to see it !! i am surely going to see it again , i cant say enough about this super movie !! Hugh Jackman is a wonderful actor and he did a wonderful acting job in this film !! the supporting actors did a very good job also and this movie is well worth the price of admission !!

Written and directed by Stephen Sommers (known for movies such as `The Mummy' and its successful sequel) one would expect `Van Helsing' to run along similar lines as its predecessors.  Unfortunately, this next installment in the Sommers Saga, somehow does not live up to standards set by the previous hits.  The main characters in the film appeared to be one-dimensional adaptations made for the popcorn/ bubblegum audiences that Hollywood counts on for Box Office success.  Whilst this formula seemed to work on `the Mummy', there is something missing of the '6 parts Action, 4 parts Comedy, 3 parts Horror and 1 part Romance' recipe of preceding attempts.Dracula was portrayed as a garish, over-the-top revision of a character whose infamy had once made him one of the more feared creatures of literature.  Here, he felt to me simply as a cartoon version of the real nature of what many of us will recognize.  His Brides on the other hand were irritating - I'd always come to think them as being frightening, yet seductive beings, being the underworlds representation of sirens.  Here they are bad actresses disguised (poorly) by computer generated images, worse dialogue, and terrible accents.That being said, the title character himself was quite delightful to watch. Van Helsing's comedic talent, cavalier attitude and general Byron-esque heroic tendencies did leave this audience member rather pleased.  However, due to Jackman's earlier movie choices in X-men and X-men 2, the similarities in Van Helsing and Wolverine were of course made - no spoilers will be revealed here, suffice to say that the drums of imminent misfortune play faintly in the background.His love interest, played by the stunning Kate Beckinsale, is simply that - a love interest played by a captivating i-am-so-ballsy-stay-out-of-my-way sidekick.  A woman, who one might add, doesn't wear very appropriate clothing for wintry conditions.  There's comedic relief, in the form of Van Helsing's Little Helper (a.k.a. Carl - played by the talented David Wenham!) who I must admit got a few laughs out of me.  Other peripheral characters were much the same, that is, they were the stereotyped clichés that we are all accustomed to seeing.  The addition of further literary legends was a little absurd - Dr Jekyll/ Mr. Hyde for example?  Why is he involved here? Confusion abounds.All things considered, the film was relatively enjoyable, if by enjoyable you mean a night out where judgment and any reliable thought process must be left at the bathroom sink.  It delivered large doses of action and broad comedy followed closely by a few startled gasps (ok, maybe not a few). After all, what more can you expect?  This is Hollywood, where the men are men, and dollar signs rule their world.Rating: 3/5

Review title: Discussing the many things wrong with this film.
Review_body: Van Helsing, starring 'that guy' from the X-Men, 'that girl' from Pearl Harbour, and a bunch of computer animated monsters is one scary movie. What scares me the most is the fact that this movie was written, and then real actors agreed to play the various roles.  I can't imagine that this movie looked good on paper.  The plot is non-existent, the dialogue is awful, and the way the dialogue is presented by the actors is monotone and disjointed. Every bad movie cliche can be found in one form or another in this film. The plot just doesn't make sense, and it seems that the writer (Stephen Sommers) came to a couple points and didn't know how to get out of them, so some bizarre realization was made and everything worked out.  The chemistry between the hero and heroine is also non-existent, and the progression of their relationship is both confusing, forced and therefore, unbelievable. The only good thing about this movie was that I thought it was 2.5 hours long, but it turned out to be only 2.  I don't know if I could have sat through another half an hour.  Save yourself a few dollars, DON'T GO SEE THIS MOVIE.

Review title: You're supposed to suspend disbelief, not hang it by the neck til dead
Review_body: If you like frantic action and some really spectacular movie-making from a special effects point of view, see Van Helsing in the theatre and don't wait for it to come out on DVD -- it's too big for the small screen. However, if you like your action spiced with a good story and compelling characters, and you are bothered by glaring inconsistencies, see something else. The story is just barebones and dry -- go kill Dracula. The characters are all cookie cutter, with almost nothing at all original or compelling. Even Van Helsing's own story is hinted at but is left for the viewer to wonder, but is NEVER resolved (I hate that).There is an unexplained three-week skip in the storyline; how else do you account for there being two full moons separated by only two apparent days? (they handled a time transition very badly). Why is lycanthropy interrupted by clouds, but apparently a curtain won't work? How does the "machine crossbow" supposedly work, with no chemical or explosive reaction to drive the arrows out -- since crossbow works by the pent up energy of the bending of the prods, which NEVER MOVE (must be magic, because there's no other explanation). There are a couple semi-original ideas and a lot of unfulfilled possibilities with characters -- and the fact that not a single one of these ever comes to fruition just makes it more frustrating. As my husband put it, "too bad such great action was wrapped around such a crappy story".

Review title: One of the worst movies I've ever seen
Review_body:
Listen, I like pretty much everything. I even found some things to like in Punisher. But, this movie has no redeeming value whatsoever.
The story (what there is of it)is bad. The dialog is atrocious. The "acting" is directly from the Shatner school. The special effects are used too frequently and for no reason. The music in no way fit the action. All in all this is literally one of the worst movies I have ever seen.
The basic flaw with the whole thing is the fact that the movie couldn't decide what it wanted to be. First it was a comedy, then a special effects extravaganza, then an action movie, then a horror movie and finally a love story. Only problem is, it really is none of them. I found it very hard to care about anything that was happening on the screen. I almost fell asleep several times.On the plus side, the main characters are all very pretty and the music is very loud.This could have been a very cool movie if it would have just picked a genre and stuck with it.2 out of 10

What an excellent matinee movie! Aside from a bit of weak dialogue and a question I have about one of the major action sequences this James Bond/Indiana Jones meets the monsters of Universal Studios really delivered the goods for me.  Pure escapism and mind-boggling special effects from start to finish.  I felt that the film remained true to the spirit and heritage of the great classic Universal flicks with a clever nod to the Hammer Studio vampire films of the 60's. Van Helsing is not a horror movie so much as it is a monster/action movie. I particularly enjoyed the portrayal of the Frankenstein monster character.  I also felt that the sensuality of vampirism was deftly handled considering the makers were going for a PG rating. I can't decide whether two of the very final scenes were an homage or just plain pop-corny but given the spirit of the film I guess they worked. Van Helsing far surpassed my expectations so much so that I plan to go back to the theatre and see it again...something I haven't done in a very, very long time. Try to catch the DLP version it is visually stunning. I hope for a sequel!

Review title: Another CG film with no substance
Review_body: I knew what to expect going into this film and I could still barely stand to watch it.  They should have spent some of the CG budget on a decent script.  The lack of any intelligent dialog or character development leads me to wonder if the producers of this film think that special effects are all that is needed to make a film these days.  Someone needs to put a stop to these mindless comic book/superhero movies.  I don't ask a lot from movies, just that they are somewhat entertaining or have some sort of emotional impact so that I can become interested in the characters.  This film offers neither.  The CG graphics/stunts are so unrealistic that no one could possible be scared of any of the bad guys (including Hugh and Kate in the movie).  In fact the good guys seem to be as strong as the bad guys in this movie, taking as much if not more physical abuse and coming out of it with barely a scratch.  The only dialog in the movie is a few one liners to try and make the audience laugh (is this supposed to be horror or comedy?). I could sit and pick this movie apart all day, but I won't waste your time and neither should you.  My advice is stop giving these CG movies the benefit of the doubt by watching them like I've been doing.  Maybe if we all stop going to see them, the studios will start making some improvements!!

This film had the old action/adventure matinee feeling to it. I would have liked it more if it were more about fantasy/horror and less of a Hollywood-like formula. Even if I were a kid.In my mind the themes I found interesting had to do with evil forces within beauty, revealed in very frightening and sometimes uncontrollable ways. Some characters show a bit of the conflict within - vampiress controlling a cat-like nature to pounce, with jaws distorting to an elongated state. (This chilling effect reinforces how cats really are more frightening at closer inspection of their long fangs!) Also, the werewolf was not able to contain his animalistic changing nature - even among friends! Frankinstein's monster also touched on the polar opposite - the hideous creature is beautiful inside. Although done before, those timeless ideas offered the best scenes of the movie, frightening and sad. I thought that the credits at the end were creative and artistic.The worst parts include clothing for Van which seemed like it was taken from the Indiana Jones set (as well as the character), a gadget prop scene ala James Bond "What can this do, Q.?", and for Anna that typical vampire-fu, back-flipping Buffy the Slayer action!I would have liked it more if the movie had battled in the mind, not so much visually, and left the viewers figuring out how things connected for themselves. Sadly, for me there were just too many ropes setup in the right place at the right time. Leave the swinging to Spidey.

Van Helsing is everything that I hoped it would be. Awesome visual effects and tongue and cheek humor (much like The Mummy movies). The acting is superb and it never allows itself to be taken too seriously. Well done to all involved. For those of us who are Hugh Jackman lovers, he NEVER disappoints! A wonderful scene in nothing but some shredded underclothes (no shirt; no pants)!!! WHAT A PHYSICAL SPECIMAN HE IS!!! There are no sexual scenes (some sensual behavior from the vampire brides - some innuendos otherwise) - no filthy language and no real gory parts - excellent movie. Rating is accurate as some children may experience nightmares because of monsters.

Well, I have to say I liked it a lot. I just got back from seeing in on an IMAX screen. If you are going to go to an eye buzzer, I say buzz extra large.Repeating Crossbow. Mass mayhem. Excellent excellent ambience from a fantasy fan perspective. Worth seeing if only to see the awesome effects and scenery. Worth seeing just to ogle the vampire chicks, and Beckingsale.All the people poopooing it are the typical "ooh it is hollywood action tripe". The probably didn't even see it.Is it campy? Yes. Over the top? Yes. Fun? Yes.

I really enjoyed the movie... I expected to see vampires, werewolves and lots of fighting, and that is what I saw!!  I thought that the graphics were pretty good, and I did not leave unhappy, (like I did after A.I.) For those who said it sucked... obviously you are not into this type of movie, so please.. don't bother seeing this genre of movie.  THE MOVIE WAS REALLY GOOD!!  The cow was quite humorous, definitely unexpected.  I did not expect the heroine to die at the end of the movie, but it still ended well.
